PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. I ask: why did the Minister for Finance delay releasing the October statement of Commonwealth financial transactions, showing a serious deterioration in the Budget figures, until late last Friday night when he had had the statement in his office a week earlier? Is it correct that the Minister held back release of the statement until after the House of Representatives rose because he wanted to avoid being questioned about the Government's deteriorating Budget position?
—I will seek an answer from the Minister for Finance in relation to this matter and provide it as soon as possible, probably by the end of Question Time.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. When the Minister is getting an answer from the Minister for Finance, will he also confirm that the deficit for the first four months of this fiscal year was $6.9 billion, compared with only $2.8 billion over the same period last year; that Budget outlays have blown out by 9.5 per cent, compared with a budgeted change of only 5.7 per cent; and that revenue has fallen by 3.2 per cent in contrast to a budgeted fall of only 1.2 per cent? Given the fact that the Budget is now quite totally out of date, when will the Minister announce a full review of the Budget figures?
—Order! That is a lot of information for a supplementary question.

—Mr President, I do have some information on that matter. It is true that outlays for the year to October were 9.5 per cent higher than for the same period in the previous year, compared with the Budget forecast for year on year growth of 5.7 per cent. A number of factors have contributed to the strength of actual outlays in the first four months of this year. They are: the timing of major defence purchases to the cost of $367m; higher outlays on assistance to the unemployed totalling $813m—however, I make the point that beneficiary numbers are lower than those in the Budget forecast for October; higher outlays on age pensions, sole parent pensions and assistance to the disabled; and some other timing and seasonal influences.

PARA.TAB: The CFT reports the level of actual outlays and revenues. It is not used to provide regular updates of revised Budget estimates for months ahead. The effects of the Prime Minister's statement and other Budget decisions of approximately $308m were documented in the October CFT as a matter of record. Of course, I make the point, which we always make about these matters, that there is considerable seasonality in outlays and revenue month by month. The results for an individual month or a few months cannot be extrapolated to estimate the outcome for the year as a whole. At this stage, it is too early to predict any comprehensive revision in Budget estimates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs been drawn to an article in the Gold Coast Bulletin of 21 November 1991, in which it is stated that the Gold Coast's only Family Court counselling service will be shut down? Is it a fact that other centres in Queensland with a lesser population than the Gold Coast have permanent Family Court registries with full time counsellors? Was a proposal given to the Government this year that a permanent registry be established on the Gold Coast and, if so, was the proposal accepted and, if it was not, what was the reason for the rejection of the proposal? What are the prospects of a Family Court counselling service being made available on the Gold Coast?

—My attention was drawn by Senator Colston to the Gold Coast Bulletin article of mid-November, indicating that the Gold Coast's Family Court counselling service would be shut down. So I have seen the article. I understand that there are such registries, such services, provided in Cairns and Townsville, which probably do have lesser populations than the area of the Gold Coast that was serviced by the counselling service provided by the Family Court in that region.

PARA.TAB: It is true that submissions are made—always at Budget time—to try to ensure that the fullest range of registry services may be provided by the Family Court in areas other than the capital cities. Certainly, as a matter of principle, I support that type of extension of the services available from the Family Court, and from other voluntary agencies, for the provision of counselling, which is such an important part of an overall strategy to deal with the question of marital strain and breakdown and disruption of family arrangements.But in this instance it was not possible to provide all the funding which the Family Court requested in order to enable a range of services to be provided. I believe that it would not be possible to reconsider the allocation of funds to the Family Court until the next Budget process.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it a fact that the Prime Minister has asked the honourable member for Blaxland, the Hon. Paul Keating, to assist him and the Government to formulate an attack on Dr Hewson's tax and economic reform package? Have any negotiations commenced in relation to the special conditions surrounding Mr Keating's return to the inner sanctum of the Labor Caucus? Will there be special witnesses to the agreement between the Prime Minister and Mr Keating on this occasion?

—I saw that invitation. I think it was extended on the Sunday program, as I recall, which I happened to see. Of course, every member of the Australian Labor Party on being elected to this Parliament is required to support the Government.
—Required to!

—Of course they are required to; they have an obligation as elected members of parliament, something which those opposite do not understand. They have been dozing and dreaming away for nine years. It is the most lacklustre opposition in the history of this country, which the unhappy Dr Hewson has to drag up by its bootstraps—a volatile composition of a grandiose package and a lacklustre, miserable opposition. What a dreadful task he has taken on.

PARA.TAB: All senators are paid a salary in this place and they are expected to do their best. Every member of the Labor Party—that includes Paul Keating—will do his best to assist the Government in projecting its policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the words of the Prime Minister on the Sunday program yesterday, the Minister's answer is very confusing. Does the Prime Minister want Mr Keating to assist in the campaign against the Fightback program or not?
—I have already answered that question.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I refer to the so-called Fightback! statement in which the Opposition claims that it will privatise port authorities and promote competition within, as well as between, ports. I ask the Minister: how does this proposed strategy compare with the approach adopted on the Government's waterfront reform program?

—The Government has no intention whatsoever of adopting the quite idiotic suggestion that has been made by the Opposition in its port authority section of Fightback! for a number of fundamental reasons; none better than those enunciated by the New South Wales Minister for Transport, Mr Baird, in October last year. I have already pointed out a number of fundamental flaws in the factual base of the Opposition's document in terms of waterfront reform and the Opposition has extended those same errors into the area of the port authorities.

PARA.TAB: I was interested to note a fundamental factual omission in the document which I am made aware of on a daily basis so far as port authorities are concerned. It is mentioned nowhere in the section dealing with port authorities in the Opposition's document.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not at all.

—Not at all. It is the fact that the port authorities are under the control of State governments. That poses a fundamental problem and I will be very interested to see how the Opposition proposes to impose the privatisation of assets that are owned by someone else. It is an interesting point that the Opposition has not enunciated so far and it is nowhere in its document. The port authorities are not owned or controlled by the Commonwealth Government. I will be interested to see how the Opposition proposes to dispose of somebody else's assets.

PARA.TAB: I will be particularly interested to see how it will force this change on State governments which are unwilling to adopt this particular method, because the State governments know what a retrograde step it would be. According to the Opposition document, the people who actually own these port authorities will not get a say. The States do not like the suggestion. As I have mentioned, the only coalition State Government—in New South Wales—expressly repudiated the privatisation concept in October last year. Mr Baird was reported as saying that far more could be gained for the people of New South Wales from the corporatisation of port authorities rather than privatising them. I agree with that position.

The Government's waterfront program is encouraging fundamental reform of port authorities in consultation with State governments. One of the means of reform under the program is to improve port authority business orientation by corporatising their structures and operations, as Mr Baird has suggested should be done in New South Wales. Already, these reforms have led to an overall reduction in the work force by 21 per cent with the shedding of 1,470 jobs nationally from port authorities.

As I have said, nowhere in its document does the Opposition mention how it proposes to force privatisation of port authorities that are owned by State governments down the throats of State governments that do not want to embrace this particular matter. Perhaps it will adopt the same approach with reluctant State governments as it does with reluctant unionists on the wharves, and use troops.

Economically, there is no guarantee that privatisation would lead to reductions in costs to waterfront clients. There is a simple, mindset, ideological position that it must have that effect. Mr Baird does not think it will and neither do I. There is absolutely no guarantee that it will lead to these reductions in an area of port authorities where they constitute—as they do in Australia—a natural monopoly. The reason is the wide geographical dispersion of our ports and the fact that they are not in a position to actively compete as do ports in other countries that do not have as long a coastline as ours and as widely dispersed ports. The Opposition has totally ignored that fact.

The Opposition is similarly silent on just how it would promote competition between those widely dispersed ports and how this would benefit any port users, if it involves the replication—which it probably would—of already under-utilised port infrastructure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you telling us that our port authorities are the most efficient in the world?

—In relation to the interjection, I will conclude on this point: not only am I not saying that, I am saying precisely the reverse—that the cooperative approach we have adopted with the States has already resulted in a 21 per cent reduction of the port authority work force. I think cooperation, rather than coercion, is the way to go.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister take steps now to inform the various State governments of this outrageous grab for control and disposal of State assets?
—I will.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is the Minister aware of new rules concerning motor vehicles sold in California, home of 3 per cent of the world's cars, which will require at least 2 per cent of new cars to have zero emissions by 1998, a figure which will rise to 10 per cent of state-wide car sales by the year 2003? Given that California is making a radical attempt to control polluting vehicle emissions which will result in the more widespread manufacture and use of electric cars, will the Minister tell the Senate what steps are being taken by both government and industry to ensure that Australia is not left behind by this potential revolution in the car manufacturing industry?

—I have had my attention drawn to those reports about the Californian initiative to which Senator Sowada refers. The so-called initiative is driven by the smog problem of one city, Los Angeles. Anyone who has been to Los Angeles would understand the desire to take some drastic action there.
—Melbourne on a bad day is pretty awful, too.

—Senator, go to Los Angeles. I am advised that the Californians recognise that to some extent they will be shifting rather than solving their pollution problem because the generation of electricity for electric cars will, in itself, be an energy intensive activity, leading to the prospect of smog and greenhouse gases away from the city of Los Angeles itself.

PARA.TAB: The other point to make is that all major car manufacturers of the world are looking at the issue of fuel efficiency—I believe with very dramatic effects. I have spoken to people who were at the Tokyo Motor Show recently. The fuel efficiency of new models of cars displayed there is just enormous and mind-boggling. To some extent, this is market driven as well as government regulation driven, as people want to buy more fuel efficient cars for obvious and sensible reasons.

I make the point about the Australian industry that here all motor vehicle manufacturers are foreign owned. They produce cars for what is one of the smallest markets in the world. For example, we actually produced last year about 350,000 cars compared with a total world production last year of 35 million. In tackling emission problems, it is slightly onerous to say that one of the smallest motor vehicle manufacturing industries in the world, all of which is foreign owned, should be told by us or by anybody to involve itself in a lot of research and developmental work on emission problems. It is much better for it to collaborate with the international industry than to do it by itself.

Our industry cannot afford the huge costs involved and Australians could not afford to pay for the price of the cars that would result from such work. I am sure that many breakthroughs in fuel efficiency and emission standards will be made in the immediate future and they will be driven by international car companies and global strategies dealing with what is a worldwide problem but one particularly intense in places such as Los Angeles, as the question referred to.

That does not mean that we in Australia cannot afford to be concerned about vehicle emissions, particularly greenhouse emissions. An environmental policy that might have to be considered in this country is not lowering the price of petrol but in fact raising the price of leaded petrol to help control some of these problems and reduce the age of the motor vehicle population. That is something which might be considered by an imaginative government.

In October this year, the Government adopted an interim planning target of stabilising emissions of greenhouse gas not controlled by the Montreal Protocol. This target is based on stabilising emissions on 1988 levels by the year 2000 and attempting to reduce those emissions further by the year 2005.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. What is the Government's response to a report in the Australian of 2 December 1991 that Mr Justice Toose has claimed that Government Ministers and advisory bodies have become captive to pressure groups, particularly in the area of economic affairs?

—I have seen an article in today's Australian entitled `Politicians captive to lobby group infiltrators'. The comments are allegedly those of a former Supreme Court judge, Mr Paul Toose. I am afraid that the confrontationist, adversarial system in which Mr Toose operated for so long as a judge has led him to an unfortunate caricature of those who are in the consumer lobby groups around Australia and, indeed, those who give advice to Ministers.

PARA.TAB: Mr Toose has been hostile to representatives of the community view in regard to the advertising industry, which he is supposed to supervise through the Media Council of Australia. Indeed, not only does Mr Toose apparently want to vet those who might come from community groups and voluntary organisations as advisers and lobbyists to Ministers but also he has through organisations connected with the Media Council of Australia tried to veto—in fact successfully—appointments which I wished to make of members representing the public to various code councils in the advertising area regarding alcohol, tobacco, slimming products and therapeutics.

When I tried to nominate public members Mr Toose's organisation vetoed those appointments. It was done so on shifting grounds of justification, none of which impressed the Trade Practices Commission which reviewed the scheme and released a report in June 1991 on the activity of this body. The TPC made scathing comments about the lack of accessibility and timeliness in the response of the Advertising Standards Council and the Media Council of Australia, which Mr Toose supervises. The need for the former judge to set his own house in order in this respect is very apparent from any cursory reading of the Trade Practices Commission's report.

If the advertising industry is to be governed in the way that it is, largely by way of self-regulation rather than government intervention, it is absolutely essential that people such as Mr Toose, the Media Council of Australia and the Advertising Standards Council—which are formed by the industry in order to protect its operations—protect the industry with a lot more sensitivity for the views of the community, particularly consumer groups.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to a draft inter-departmental report prepared by senior officers from the Treasury, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, commissioned by the Prime Minister, which is reported to have highlighted the need for a goods and services tax by identifying Australia's narrow tax base as a key problem, criticised the existing wholesale sales tax for putting exporters at a significant disadvantage and compared Australia's business tax system unfavourably with almost all of our booming Asian neighbours in nearly all respects. Why is the Government pig-headedly refusing to wipe out the unfair and discriminatory wholesale sales tax and replace it with a GST, as is used by nearly all Western developed nations, and as is proposed by Dr Hewson to replace seven anti-business taxes, when its departmental advice is that it should do so?

—There are a number of points raised in Senator Baume's question. First of all, I think his question is based on a story in Saturday's Sydney Morning Herald which purports to be based on a draft of a business taxation review conducted by some government departments. Let me say that the review has not yet been finalised. When it is, it will, of course, be presented to the Government. I am certainly not going to comment on reported claims attributed to the story of an unnamed government source about what any reference to Australia's tax base in this draft report does or does not mean.

PARA.TAB: I have to point out to Senator Baume that the reporter who wrote the story in Saturday's Sydney Morning Herald wrote another one in today's paper. In that one he quotes the Treasurer as saying that the case for introducing a consumption tax `has been weakened significantly by a Treasury analysis that shows sales tax has a minimal effect on business'. Mr Kerin is quoted in the article as saying that the analysis showed that the wholesale sales tax adds less than 2 per cent to business costs in virtually all sectors. Of course, that does raise some questions about a consumption tax.

Senator Baume also asked what the Government was doing about broadening the tax base and made the point that a goods and services tax represents a broadening of the tax base. Of course, it does. But let me make the point that this Government through its life has broadened the tax base in a number of respects.

TALK.START.PARA: —You extended it to orange juice, flavoured milk and ice-cream.

—We sure have; that is right. We introduced a capital gains tax, which all honourable senators opposite opposed. We introduced a fringe benefits tax, which all honourable senators opposite opposed. We introduced the assets test on pensions, which all honourable senators opposite opposed in spite of the views of their then President, Mr John Elliott. Those were tax broadening measures. If honourable senators opposite are addicted to tax broadening measures, they might have thought about them some time a little earlier when the Government took these steps to broaden the tax base in Australia. By the way, now, in the so-called Fightback! document, they are quite prepared to pick up the benefits of all that tax broadening which they opposed at the time.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume asked me why we will not behave like other governments around the world and introduce a goods and services tax. There are many reasons for that but just let me give him one. The fact of the matter is, as he well knows, that every goods and services tax introduced overseas has been added to time and time again. Also, there is a compensation package the first time a goods and services tax is introduced and there is not one thereafter.

Let me make this point in terms of the proposed tax scales which would be introduced for income earners as compensation for a goods and services tax: if we look at the table 2.5, which contains tax scales from 1 October 1994, we find that a person on an income of $30,000 a year gets $30.40 extra a week as a result of those tax changes; a person on $70,000 gets $90. The person on $30,000 who gets the extra $30 a week benefit has to pay the same goods and services tax on vegetables, clothing, food and so on, as does the person who gets the $90 benefit. Look at what happens on 1 January 1996. The person on $30,000 a year gets exactly the same amount—$30.40. What does the person on $70,000 a year—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question was apparently concerning another leaked government report. If the Minister wants to debate our package—we have said before that we are happy to do so after Question Time—perhaps he might move to take note of the question at the end of Question Time. But he cannot conduct a debate; that is against the Standing Orders.

—On the point of order: I was asked by Senator Baume, who added this gratuitous tail to the end of his question, `Why won't you behave like other governments around the world and introduce a goods and services tax?', and I am giving him a reason why we would not do that.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. You will note that Senator Button said that he was giving reasons why he would not introduce a GST. If he is doing so, what is the relevance of dealing at great length with an income tax deduction list? I ask you to get him to return to the question.
—Order! The Minister is in order.

—The so-called income tax deduction list is what those opposite are saying they are going to provide by way of compensation for imposing a 15 per cent tax on everything people buy in this country, whether it be food, clothing or whatever. That is their compensation package. I am trying to show those opposite that the compensation package, like all the figures in this document, is a phoney. The compensation package is a phoney. It does not match the rhetoric. If we look at the compensation package—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. You have restrained us in our questions to matters relating to the Minister's portfolio. He is debating our package. If you decide that Question Time should not continue and we should have a debate, we will have a debate. But the Standing Orders say that he cannot debate the issue. I raise that point of order and I ask you to find whether it is being debated.
—In reply to the point of order, the Minister has been in order, but it is becoming a very long answer.
—I propose to conclude the answer. Let me make this simple point: a person on $30,000 a year will gain $30 a week compensation in 1994.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister is debating the issue.
—I have asked the Minister to conclude his answer and I believe he is doing that.
—Mr President, I raised the point of order subsequent to your last ruling; that is, the Minister is continuing to debate the issue of the coalition's package. I raise that point of order again.
—It is very difficult to decide when the answer to a question is becoming a debate. I have asked the Minister to conclude and I believe he is doing that.
—If those opposite ask silly questions of me, they are likely to get a sensible answer—that is the danger. By 1996, a person on $70,000 a year will be getting $140 in benefits. It is unfair.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his quaint response and I particularly thank him for not denying the report in the Sydney Morning Herald to which I referred, on the grounds, of course, that it was not finalised. I ask the Minister to table the report from this morning's Sydney Morning Herald that he referred to so glowingly, containing comments from the Treasurer. Has his statement been finalised? Will he, therefore, comment on it? In a letter from the Senator to the Prime Minister he is quoted as saying, `I am also yet to be convinced that we have an internationally competitive business tax environment'. Is that true? What is the Minister doing to fix up that situation?

—In respect of the analysis provided by the Treasurer, I do not see any objection to my getting that from the Treasurer because it clearly exists. As I answered the original question which Senator Baume asked me about the so-called business tax review, that is not yet in the hands of the Government. Therefore, I cannot accede to his request.

PARA.TAB: I do not retreat at all from what I said in a letter to the Prime Minister some time ago—that I am yet to be convinced that we have the best business tax system in the world. Providing an appropriate tax regime for business is an ongoing matter and it has to be done on the basis—

TALK.START.PARA: —Wayne Goss supports the GST.

—Wayne Goss supports the GST but the honourable senator did not in Townsville two months ago. He was up there making a big fellow of himself in the Townsville press, saying that a GST would damage northern Queensland. He was reported on the front page.
—Who said that?

—Senator Macdonald did. He does not know what he said. In answer to the question asked by Senator Baume, these matters have to be assessed in the light of comparisons with other countries from time to time.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. The Minister has defamed me in a most scurrilous way. I ask for your permission to answer that at this particular time.
—I am not in a position to judge whether the statements were true or not. If it is a personal explanation, it should be made after Question Time. It is a point of personal explanation.

—Mr President, on the point of order raised by Senator Macdonald: that is an outrageous statement to have been made against my colleague and he is entitled to clear himself while Question Time is still going to air so that the point that has been made by Senator Button can be refuted here and now. If there is to be fairness in this chamber, Mr President, you will allow Senator Macdonald to make his statement now.
—Order! Clearly there is no point of order. It is a matter for personal explanation. I will give Senator Macdonald the call at the end of Question Time.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services. In relation to families on equivalent incomes, has the Minister abandoned the notion of a two-tiered child-care fee relief system which discriminates against those families where the mother is not in the paid work force?

—I understand that the Minister, Mr Staples, has indicated that he has decided not to go ahead with the regulation which he was about to make concerning the implementation of a two-tiered child-care fee relief system. That has been done and he has indicated that the whole question, including all the representations that have made concerning the anticipated operation of that two-tiered child-care fee relief system, will be under review. As a result of taking all those recommendations into account, no doubt a fair and equitable system of child-care fee relief will be implemented.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Mine was a straightforward question to which I would like a straightforward answer. I would like the Minister to give us a guarantee that in relation to families on equivalent incomes the Minister has abandoned the unfair notion of a two-tiered child-care fee relief scheme which discriminates against those families where the mother is not in the paid work force. It is either yes or no. Has he abandoned it or has he not abandoned it?

—It is quite clear that the Minister has decided not to pursue the two-tiered child-care fee relief system because of the sorts of impacts which it is claimed it would have, as have been used as a premise for Senator Harradine's question. It is reasonable to draw very clear inferences from that. I believe that the review being undertaken now will ensure that the sorts of outcomes in equity which Senator Harradine is concerned to achieve will be achieved.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister to a set of minutes from the Prime Minister's country task force. In these minutes from the Prime Minister's country task force of August 1988 it is stated:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . freight charges to remote areas were particularly high and the requirement for sales tax to be paid on freight charges was considered an unfair imposition on people in remote and rural areas.

Why has this Government done nothing about the abolition of its hidden 20 per cent consumption tax on freight charges? Why is this Government now considering further increasing the impost on people in remote areas by planning not only massive increases in road registration charges but also further increases in its hidden consumption tax on other forms of freight services?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator O'Chee has to go back to a document from August 1988; I suppose he was still in kindergarten at the time. I make the point that there is no proposal to increase charges. The present sales tax collected on road freight inputs has been estimated by the Bureau of Transport Economics to be between only 2 per cent and 4.5 per cent of total operating costs. The costs involved in removing a wholesale sales tax from that sector would be very big. It is a matter of judgment, of course, as to what one decides to spend one's revenue on.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note, in asking this supplementary question, that the Minister said it was a matter of judgment. Why then is this Government judging to increase the road registration charges for semitrailers to $14,000 per year? Why is this Government doing nothing about reducing the level of taxation? Why is this Government doing nothing about reducing the level of fuel tax? Is it clear that this Government's judgment is that it does not care about people in remote areas?

—In so far as concessions are made to people who live in remote areas, this Government has a better performance than any Liberal-Country Party coalition that was ever in office in terms of the rebates that are allowed. In respect of the question of reducing taxation, I am not convinced that that is an end in itself. The problem that those opposite have got hold of, the tiger they have by the tail, is that they believe in a tax-led recovery in this country—with an additional tax imposed on the whole of the Australian economy, on every individual in this country—and they somehow claim to have turned that into some sort of visionary policy for this country. It is not a visionary policy; it is a myopic policy.

PARA.TAB: In so far as lowering tax scales is concerned, the honourable senator would know, as a top marginal taxpayer, that when this Government came into office the top marginal tax rate was 60 per cent. It is now 47 per cent. The honourable senator will know that in respect of the other tax scales this Government has broadened the tax base.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was in kindergarten, remember.
—The honourable senator was probably a top marginal payer in kindergarten; I do not know what his circumstances were. But this Government has no mind set about the reduction of taxes either way.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I refer the Minister to the notice of motion which I will give later today—a copy of which has been supplied to him—informing the Senate that I have been supplied with 90 statements and statutory declarations describing excessive use of force by police officers during the AIDEX protest and injuries sustained by protesters. I ask the Minister: firstly, does he agree that this information, together with television and print media coverage, warrants his considering initiating an investigation into the way in which the police handled the protest? Secondly, does he agree that this investigation should be a first step in consultations between representatives of the protesters, the Australian Federal Police and the Minister to develop a code of conduct for civil disobedience campaigns, with particular reference to the behaviour of both police and protesters?

—I am aware of the broad terms of the notice of motion which Senator Spindler apparently intends to give later this afternoon along the lines of his question to me. I do not agree that the sorts of matters which he indicates should lead me to initiate an investigation into the circumstances surrounding what he calls the police handling of the protest. If there were to be an investigation, it should involve all aspects, including the way in which the dissenters and protesters themselves handled the situation of what he calls the civil disobedience—and I will comment on that in a moment—outside the AIDEX exhibition.

PARA.TAB: I believe that it is my duty, if certain matters are brought to my attention, to convey any complaints to the Ombudsman. I believe that this Parliament has great faith in the Ombudsman as a person whose integrity, impartiality and independence of office are guaranteed by statute, and who can make the necessarily assessment of the allegations made about what Senator Spindler prejudges to be excessive police violence in regard to this demonstration. Neither Senator Spindler nor I should prejudge any outcome of any investigation undertaken by the Ombudsman in that respect.

Senator Spindler goes on to ask whether I believe any such investigation, if undertaken, should be a first step in consultation. The Commander of the AFP in the Australian Capital Territory region sought to and did have consultation early with some people who were prepared to identify themselves as leaders. One of the difficulties in this situation was that there was not the leadership provided, nor the acceptance of responsibility which goes with leadership, to ensure that all aspects of the protest and the dissent—the civil disobedience—remained in harmony with those traditions which accompany civil disobedience if one looks to Martin Luther King and the tradition which comes from that type of civil protest undertaken in the United States.

When one looks at the arsenal of weapons present during the demonstration, one sees that the leadership was ineffectual in curbing some of the protesters from creating a very dangerous situation. I believe that it is not a good thing for any senator to prejudge the outcome of the complaints, which will be properly lodged, no doubt, with the Ombudsman. I am meeting later this afternoon with four senators—Senators Reynolds, Childs, Spindler and Vallentine—and some of the demonstrators to receive their protest. I will not substitute myself for the Ombudsman, but I will be pleased to hear what they have to say and pass on their complaints for proper assessment under the authority established by this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In any subsequent investigation, which I believe the Minister still has a responsibility to initiate, there is absolutely no objection to investigating the behaviour of protesters. I believe it needs to be done on both sides and we need to find a constructive solution for the future. I ask the Minister whether in those terms he would be prepared to investigate.

—I believe the best course is to await the Ombudsman's report. If it were thought necessary, I would certainly support such review and amendment, particularly if the Ombudsman makes recommendations that standing orders and Commissioner's orders need to be adjusted to deal with this sort of demonstration, which ought to be held in a non-violent and peaceful way to take advantage of our peaceful and democratic society and its tradition of enabling protests to be conducted in a way which does not interfere with the lawful rights of others, and if there is any suggestion that the rules regulating police activities at these demonstrations ought to be reviewed and amended.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Defence, relates to the tragic loss of an RAAF Boeing 707 on 29 October this year while engaged in asymmetric flight at a relatively low altitude. Why was this training procedure being carried out when it is not normal to carry out these sorts of exercises in heavy transport aircraft? Were any air safety directives issued by the Air Force earlier this year either cautioning against or prohibiting such procedures? Was the aircraft flown with the airspeed decaying towards the V MCA, or minimal control airspeed, in the asymmetric state without the full authority of the rudder being available?

—In the first part of the question Senator MacGibbon asks whether it is normal. It is not as normal to do this sort of practice with a transport plane such as the 707 as with the others, but it has occurred in the past. As to the second part of the question, about the exact nature of air safety directives, I will get an answer on that because I have not seen them specifically. I will not speculate on the third part of the question until I get the board of inquiry's report, which I have indicated here in answer to a question from Senator Durack that I would be happy to make publicly available.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce been drawn to the article in the Sydney Morning Herald of Thursday, 28 November headed `Australia paying its way at last, trade data shows'? In light of the recent balance of payments figures, today's balance of payments monthly figures and last week's September quarter figures, can the Minister please advise the Senate about Australia's improving trade performance? Does the Minister agree with the conclusions in the article and do they contain encouraging news for Australia? Is there anything in these figures to caution against sudden policy shifts that could threaten this improvement?

—Any really good news is anathema to those opposite. They revel in higher unemployment because they think it gives them a better chance of being elected to office. I will outline the figures related to the two sets of ABS statistics which Senator Crowley mentioned in her question—today's October monthly balance of payments and last week's September quarter balance of payments. Both these releases indicate that Australia has improved its trading performance markedly. Not only are we now looking at the trade deficit being back down to about 3.5 per cent of GDP—that is, a ratio which we have not had in this country for more than 10 years—but also Australia can now be said to be paying its way in its trade with other countries.

PARA.TAB: For three consecutive quarters—March, June and September 1991—Australia has run a surplus on its balance of goods and services account. This surplus was continued in today's October monthly figure.

TALK.START.PARA: —What percentage is needed to stabilise?

—I know that Senator Crichton-Browne does not want to hear the answer. As I said, those opposite revel in unemployment figures, but they are not interested in any good figures. A goods and services trade surplus means that all goods and services which Australia now consumes, either from local production or from imports, have been paid for without adding to foreign debt. The current account deficit is now largely driven by interest rate payments on past debt.
—How are you going to solve that? Not with those figures.
—Certainly we will not solve it by adopting the model at page 325 of the Fightback! document; it will not be solved that way. It is a disastrous document for Australia in terms of its levels of debt.

PARA.TAB: Again, the improved trade performance has meant that economic growth will receive a further positive boost from net exports. This is expected to be confirmed again when the September quarter GDP figures are released later this week. This will be the fourth consecutive quarter when net exports have been positive, a result that is vital for sustained economic growth for this decade. Of particular performance has been the major improvement in the export of manufactured goods. Manufacturing exports exceeded rural exports for the first time in memory in 1990-91.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are no crops.

—If Senator O'Chee would just listen a minute, he would learn that manufactured exports exceed the value of exports of wool and coal together. Admittedly, wool was a bad year; coal was not a bad year.
—That somewhat qualifies the figure.

—No, one could just say coal. It was an achievement never recognised or approached in all the Opposition's 27 years of government; it never got near it. Of course, this growth is reflected by an average real rate of 14.5 per cent over the last five years.
—You tell the unemployed that.

—I will tell the unemployed this. I will also tell them that under the Fightback package of those opposite, if they were elected to government, their situation would be worse. That is what I will tell them. I will also tell them that this is a matter on which the Opposition vision is absolutely silent. The improved trade performance is having a positive effect also on the country's foreign debt situation.
—Why don't you resign and bring Keating back?

—I thought Senator Macdonald would be quiet. As I said earlier, we are no longer adding to our debt from poor goods and services trade efforts. The ratio of net foreign debt to GDP has levelled out at 34 to 35 per cent, leading to a fall in the debt servicing burden.
—This is a very long answer.

—It is a very long answer and very unpalatable to the Opposition. The most appropriate way to keep Australia's foreign debt stabilised and the trade performance improving is to increase the export orientation of the Australian economy. If we have a look at the Fightback package—forget the rhetoric—and at the graphs and at the tables, the Hewson package presents a big threat to the economy with an expected boost to inflation and interest rates and its totally fallacious claims on productivity which are identified in the table at page 325.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In the light of the Opposition's complete failure to hear any of that answer, I ask the Minister whether he would do it again.
—Order! There is no supplementary question.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Was the Government aware of the serious financial position of the New South Wales branch of the Australian Labor Party and the part the ALP Federal President, Senator Loosley, played in that financial collapse at the time of deciding to introduce legislation to ban paid election advertising?
—No.

—Can the Minister for Social Security explain the reason for the application of waiting periods before people are eligible for unemployed benefit? Would the Government consider extending the waiting time for Jobsearch allowance from one week to three weeks? What effect would lengthening waiting periods have upon people who are unemployed?

—To answer the question, it is necessary to look at what happens now. Obviously, waiting periods have been in the forefront of the minds of those people in the social security lobby now for quite some time because during a recession the claim always is that waiting periods create a great deal of hardship. Although at the moment we have a waiting period of one week, it actually means three weeks because the payment is backdated two weeks. So when people apply for the Jobsearch allowance it is backdated two weeks and they have to wait three. A great many people are inconvenienced and do suffer hardship because of the waiting period. As a result of that, some 20 per cent of applicants now qualify under hardship provisions. The hardship provisions are pretty simple: if one has in the bank less than two weeks of the benefit, which is less than $300, one would qualify. So 20 per cent now get it.

PARA.TAB: I am asked by Senator West whether the Government would consider a change to the rules from one week to three weeks, which means an effective waiting period of three weeks to five weeks. Obviously, that would be a pretty shameful thing for any government to do. One in five people applying for Jobsearch allowance are granted hardship. If the wait is three weeks, one has to wonder what would happen when the wait becomes five weeks. Of course, Senator West is right about there being suggestions that the period go to five weeks. People may have heard of a thing called the Fightback package which actually did suggest that.

But the problem with the Fightback package suggestion, of course, is that it claims savings of $186m. Why? Because it says that the percentage who would transfer to special benefit, which is now 20 per cent with a three-week waiting period, would be 18 per cent if it were a five-week waiting period. What one is talking about, of course, is a dead-set crook set of figures. What one is talking about is an Opposition claim that less than 20 per cent will apply when there is a 200 per cent increase in the time period. The reality is $186m ought to be $113m. There is a $73m hole in that one little item.

It is not just the Opposition which ought to have a long think about this. We now have more than half a million people on JSA. One wonders just how much misery this lot want to inflict on us. I would have thought that three weeks was a long time when one is down on one's luck and one does not have a job. Five weeks is an eternity. The savings are just simply crook; they are not there. It is about time people got a bit honest with the Fightback package. If the Opposition wants to fight back, it should stop trying to fight back on the backs of those who are poor, those who are sick and those who are needy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Now that the Department of Employment, Education and Training in Western Australia has admitted that the returns from the training guarantee levy have been consumed in the cost of collecting it, can the Minister advise—
—We knew that he could not manage his way out of a telephone box but this is crazy. I think I had better start again because Senator Cook was preoccupied with trying to figure out what he was doing.
—You weren't asking—

—I will finish the question: can the Minister advise the Senate as to how this bungling mismanagement by the Department of Employment, Education and Training has occurred and what will be the shortfall? The Minister cannot even understand the question, let alone give an answer.

—Mr President, I would ask you to stop Senator Knowles harassing my colleague. I have neither seen the report that Senator Knowles refers to nor do I accept her reporting of it. I will have that checked and come back to the Senate with an answer.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—During Question Time today, Senator Short asked me a question about the release of the Commonwealth financial transactions paper. The implication of his question was that the Minister for Finance had deliberately delayed the publication of these figures. There was no delay in the release of the Commonwealth financial transactions paper. It is normally released in the last week of the following month, as was the case with the October Commonwealth financial transactions statement.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short also suggested that the October CFT indicated that the Budget was out of control. This is totally wrong. As indicated in the paper, the deficit outcome for the year to October cannot be extrapolated to estimate the year as a whole. I just make the point that, as at October 1990, the figure was very considerably different from what might have been expected and bore no relation to the ultimate Budget outcome. So those figures cannot be used for extrapolation purposes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Short this day relating to the statement of Commonwealth financial transactions.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank Senator Button for the additional information that he has provided. But I ask him to confirm that the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) had the October figures in his office for a week before releasing them. That week was a sitting week. He did not release those figures until very late last Friday when, of course, the House of Representatives had closed down virtually for the year and, therefore, he did not give the House an opportunity to question him on those figures.

PARA.TAB: From my understanding of his response, Senator Button did not deny that the Minister for Finance had those figures for one week. He said they had not been delayed. But why on earth would the Minister sit with important figures such as those in his office for one week and not publicly release them? I also say, in response to Senator Button's further information about how the situation to October this year compares with the situation to October last year, that it was after October last year that the Budget for 1990-91 completely unravelled.

By the end of 1990-91, we had a deterioration in the budgetary situation of the Commonwealth Government of no less than $13 billion—the most massive deterioration that has ever occurred in the fiscal history of this country and a deterioration that occurred wholly and solely because of the enormous policy failures that led to the deliberately engineered recession that this country is still facing, the most serious recession in 60 years, the recession which has put almost one million people on the jobs scrap heap and has made half a million people massively underemployed. If Senator Button is prepared to say that there was no delay by the Minister for Finance, I would ask him to explain why the Minister for Finance had those figures on his desk in Parliament House for a week before releasing them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —For fear I might be misrepresented, I advise that I did not say that there was no delay; I said that the figures were published in the week when they are normally published. I find it extraordinary that the Opposition lot wander in here accusing the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) of delaying these figures for a couple of days when they have been sitting on the great package allegedly for 12 months—and even when it was published, they got it wrong. I do not know what the basis of this accusation is; I have no idea at all.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to take note of Senator Button's answer to Senator Crowley's question on Australia's balance of payments and to speak to it very briefly.
—Is leave granted?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before that, I seek leave to make a very short statement about constantly seeking leave to move to take note of an answer.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not proposing to refuse leave to Senator Short today. I just want to take the opportunity to say that this is becoming a new form of short term debate. I think it is appropriate in exceptional circumstances, but we are now getting to the point where it is becoming a regular feature. I am not sure that is appropriate. Perhaps we could have some discussion about a more orderly procedure by which this can be done. I will, of course—as I have already indicated—give leave because Senator Short tends to have the virtue of at least being brief about these matters when he brings them forward. I appreciate that. If these matters are to become a regular feature rather than as they were previously—something to do with exceptional circumstances—perhaps we ought to discuss the procedure and criteria which will apply to them. Those are only my generalised comments. Leave will be given to Senator Short today.
—I seek leave to respond to the statement that has just been made by Senator McMullan.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Question Time was abused today, not because of questions on Ministers' portfolios and responses to them, but because Ministers used that opportunity to debate the Opposition's package. That is why the Standing Orders prohibit debate. The Standing Orders prohibit debate because it would be a one-sided debate, which is not permitted.
—Let's have a fair debate.

—As Senator Baume says, let us have a fair debate. If Ministers are going to abuse Question Time by debating the issues instead of answering questions and, in particular, debating the Opposition package, then they should be prepared to hear the other side of the argument. If Ministers keep doing that, we will, at the end of each Question Time, get up and seek to continue the debate that they start during Question Time. That is what Senator Short is doing in this instance and it is more than reasonable that he should be able to. Therefore, he is seeking leave. If the Minister and his colleagues continue to abuse Question Time, we will continue to debate the issues at the end of Question Time.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Crowley this day relating to Australia's balance of trade payments.

SPEECH.PARA: In his response to Senator Crowley's question about the balance of payments and the external situation facing Australia, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) sought to portray recent trends in our external account as a major improvement in our economic and external account position. I would welcome such a statement because the one thing that this country desperately needs is an improvement in its external account. Sadly, the facts of the situation are totally contrary to what Senator Button attempted to portray today. He attempted to portray that we are in the process of a significant improvement in Australia's balance of payments and external account position and, therefore, this is all part of the economic recovery.

PARA.TAB: One look at the facts shows that that is just nonsense. The balance of payments results that we received today for October show a deficit of $1.3 billion. That is the highest balance of payments deficit we have had since April this year. It was exceeded only by the January figure, and that just by a whisker. Setting aside April, the balance of payments outcome for this year was the worst that we have had virtually this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —You mean this month?

—No, this year. The October monthly balance of payments figure was virtually the worst balance of payments outcome that we have had this year. Australia is in the middle of the deepest recession in 60 years as a result of the massive policy failures of this Government. One would therefore expect that there would have been a huge fall in imports over the last year.

PARA.TAB: The October imports figure for 1991 is $30m higher than it was one year ago. It may not be much different, but it is higher and we should have expected, if the Government's scorched earth policy of bludgeoning this economy to death were working, that we would have had a very significant fall in imports. That has not happened because this Government has wrecked the structure of the economy and has failed to take any substantial measures to improve our productivity and our competitive position.

Despite the hardship that is being caused to millions of Australians because of the Government's policy failure, not one thing is being put in place to provide any hope, vision or prospect for the future. There is no hope at all for those one in three kids who are unemployed as a result of Senator Button's policies. There is no hope at all for the 1 1/2 million Australians who are either under-employed or unemployed.

I have just mentioned imports. Exports fell by 7 per cent this year. The export figure for October is the lowest for six months. It is lower than any other month except April this year. Indeed, one has to go back to this time last year to find figures of similar magnitude.

The cost of debt servicing in October rose again to $1.6 billion. The cost of servicing our debt is now running in excess of $17 billion a year and is rising. The whole structure and the whole nature of our economy are such that we are, quite frankly and bluntly, unable to pay our way in the world.

For Senator Button to get up and use a question, which may or may not have been a dorothy dixer, to portray that the external situation is improving when, in fact, it is not, is not only misleading but also very dangerous. Senator Button's attempt to portray bad figures—figures that we all ought to recognise as bad; therefore, there is a need for urgent action to be taken in this country to get things right—in the misleading way that he did is disgraceful because it is very dangerous to the whole process of proper consideration of the issues facing this country. I hope that, when the remainder of the economic news comes out over the weeks ahead, Senator Button will have the decency on behalf of all Australians to look at those figures honestly and try to present an honest interpretation of them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last few minutes I have been accused of being disgraceful, dishonest and misleading—all those things. Senator Short, as Opposition spokesman for finance, is very concerned about the October figures for the current account. He had his chance at Question Time; instead he asked a silly question about whether the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) had delayed the figures for four days—a sort of gossip question, not a question which went to the issue which he now says is of fundamental importance. Senator Short knows full well that one does not judge the performance of the current account on the basis of one month's figures. He is trying to do that now.
—No, I'm not; I am telling you about trends.

—The honourable senator is not telling me about any trends; he would not know what the trend was. If he had listened to the answer which I gave—he has not been very good on figures for an Opposition finance spokesman—he would know perfectly well that the trade deficit is back down to 3.5 per cent of GDP, and that, for three consecutive quarters in a row, we have run a surplus in the balance of the goods and services account. If he was really concerned about this issue, as Opposition spokesman he might have mentioned these things—he who is not disgraceful, is always honest and never misleads anybody.

PARA.TAB: One reason why the honourable senator did not mention any of those things is that his colleagues did not want to hear the answer which I gave. There was total uproar in this place when I gave the answer, because none of those opposite wanted to hear it. All they want to hear about is unemployment figures going up because they think that will get their backsides on seats over here. I tell them that there is more in this than that. Those opposite did not want to hear that answer. That is why I rise to comment on it now. If Senator Short wants to have a debate with me about the trends, he should come in here with some honest figures next time. He should not just pluck one month's figures out of the air and try to turn them into a trend. As a former Treasury officer, he ought to know better than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make a very simple point just to back up the point made by my colleague Senator Short. The figure of $1.3 billion shows that exports are down and imports are up and that it is a poor performance. Last month those opposite chose to shout from the rooftops that they had had a good month. This month, when it is a bad month, they want to disown it. The bottom line is that it is getting worse under this Government, and the sooner we get an election and change it the better.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The point of order that Senator Macdonald made has arisen two or three times recently and I think I should make a statement on it. The Chair is not required to judge or regulate the accuracy or truthfulness of answers to questions or speeches in the Senate. Matters relating to the accuracy or truthfulness of statements made by senators should not be raised by point of order because there is no question of order involved. If a Minister in answer to a question, or any other senator in debate, makes a statement which another senator believes not to be accurate or truthful, that is a matter for correction or rebuttal through the normal procedures: for example, by way of personal explanation or statement by leave.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Under standing order 190, I wish to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented. In Question Time today, Senator Button, for his own grubby little political purposes or whatever else, made an accusation. He made it at a time when the proceedings were being broadcast and were on television, which Senator Button well knew. He was given this information no doubt by the Minister assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia (Senator Collins), who has been smarting ever since he was exposed for the waste of money that he has perpetrated in his Townsville office.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Macdonald has done nothing but attribute ill motives to this side and to debate the issue. He has not said anything so far which constitutes anything in the nature of a personal explanation. It was that for which he was given leave, not to contribute further to a debate.
—Order! Senator Macdonald, it is a personal explanation.

—The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) intimated that I opposed the consumption tax. He also intimated that I opposed it a couple of weeks or a couple of months ago. In both instances, the Leader of the Government in the Senate is quite incorrect. He referred to an article, I assume, which the Minister assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia handed to him while I happened to be having a discussion with Senator Button about the matter. The headline is not my statement and it is nothing I have ever said. I have always thought that a properly framed consumption tax, a goods and services tax, would be excellent for the people that I serve, which is particularly the north of Queensland and northern Australian people. Of course, time has proved that to be very true.

PARA.TAB: The part of the article that is correct and actually quotes what I said—not the headline, which is of course not mine, but the journalist's licence, which is not at all accurate in this particular instance—states:

A consumption tax with corresponding and substantial reductions in income tax is a fine aim but it has to be tempered with some formula to assist those on fixed incomes, on pensions, and particularly those living in northern Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: That statement was not made a couple of weeks or even a couple of months ago; it was reported on 3 July 1990 when I had been a senator for three days. What I said was as correct then as it is now. I am very pleased to say that, in all of that time, as I said in this article, I have watched the development of a consumption tax proposal very closely to make sure that people—particularly people in northern Australia—were not disadvantaged.

PARA.TAB: I am very pleased to say that what has happened, as a result of many trips which Dr Hewson and Mr Reith have made to northern Australia, including north Queensland—many more than the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) bothers to make—is that Dr Hewson and Mr Reith have taken on board the concerns that have been expressed in some quarters. As a result of that, they have abolished seven taxes which are of particular significance to northern Australia, particularly the things that I spoke about in that article.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Macdonald, you are going past a personal explanation.

—In that article I was talking about things that I wanted to watch, including a zone allowance. I was also concerned that north Queenslanders not be disadvantaged. The fuel allowance has been particularly—
—Order! Senator Macdonald, you are beginning to debate the point. It is a personal explanation.
—I wanted to say that I was concerned that things be looked at. The fuel reduction will be of specific and very detailed benefit to north Queenslanders.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Macdonald has gone manifestly beyond your ruling, Mr President. He is not saying what he said; he is saying what is happening in response to his article.
—Order! I think Senator Macdonald has finished.

—Mr President, I rise to speak to the point of order, since Senator Evans has raised it. The degree of maligning that Senator Button used against Senator Macdonald earlier today was such that Senator Macdonald was quite entitled to give a full reply.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I apologise to Senator Macdonald with respect to the date—nothing else. It was July 1990. Senator Macdonald need not worry about it, he is big enough to look after himself with the troglodytes in the Liberal Party up there. I got the date wrong—I thought it was July 1991. I apologise for that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented. Senator Patterson was kind enough to explain to me in the very early hours of last Friday morning that the members of the Opposition had thought that I had gone over-the-top and stark raving mad—which I know a lot of people had been thinking for a long time, a point which is reciprocated in some degree in some cases sometimes from my point of view.

PARA.TAB: I refer to an interjection that I made during Question Time on Thursday 28 November when Senator Tate was listing a litany of sins on the part of the demonstrators at the AIDEX site. Among other things, he said that some demonstrators were smearing themselves with faeces. That is quoted in Hansard. This is not the point that was incorrect, but I will get to that. I interjected, `That was to protect them from the sun'. That is not all that I said, Mr President. I think it is very important to clear this up.
To my shock and horror, in the Daily Telegraph Mirror on Friday, 29 November, there appeared the following paragraph:

SPEECH.PARA: Green Senator, Joe Vallentine, defended the practice, saying that demonstrators put faeces on their faces to protect them from the sun.
I said that they had used ochre, not that it was okay.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, she did. I heard her.

—I thank Senator Crowley. I should have said `mud'. Perhaps members of the Opposition would then have understood. It was the practice of a very few demonstrators at the exhibition to smear mud on their faces to protect them from the sun. It was mud. I was not saying that putting faeces on faces was okay—but it was O-C-H-R-E. I am sure that Hansard will get that correct. I think that the journalist who wrote the story, Adam Connolly, made a genuine error. I think the word that I used was not heard correctly.
—Mr President, I have a difficulty with that because my hearing and recollection was that it was just as it is in Hansard.
—Order!
—I can only say that I feel sorry for Senator Vallentine and I offer some deodorant.
—Senator Bishop, you cannot just stand up and speak without leave, and you know that.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Tobacco Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PARA.TAB: That we the undersigned call for urgent action by our Federal Parliament and all government agencies concerned with Health and Sport to impose an immediate ban on the incidental advertising of tobacco products on television and provide for alternative funding to replace tobacco sponsorship. That tobacco sponsorship of sporting events and participants openly flouts the 1976 Federal law prohibiting tobacco advertising on TV and radio. That our Parliament immediately end this association between healthy sports and the deaths of 18,300 people in Australia each year from tobacco-related diseases.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:

PARA.TAB: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PETITION.PARA: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PARA.TAB: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty The Queen of Australia our head of State and as in duty bound will every pray. God save The Queen.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Material
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PARA.TAB: That we, the undersigned, having great concern over the effect that increasing availability of pornographic material is having in hastening the spread of moral pollution in our nation, call upon the Federal Government to:

PETITION.PARA: (1)Dramatically improve the Federal Attorney-General's guidelines for classification of video tapes/discs, which restrict the importation, production, sale or hire, screening in private homes and especially mailing by Australia Post, so as to include the total prohibition of any pornographic, obscene or blasphemous video cassette, or film which exploits or degrades women as sex objects, or which obtain child pornography, bestiality, sodomy, group sex or violent sex acts with women, such as rape and pack rape, sadism and torture, etc. or which promotes homosexuality or lesbianism;
(2)Resist moves to have Federal Funds granted to subsidise the production and export of X-rated videos; and
(3)Implement the decision of all State Attorneys-General to have the distribution of X-rated videos from the Australian Capital Territory outlawed.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will protect our society, especially women and children, from moral pollution and its harmful effects.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned petitioners draw to the attention of the Senate the central role played by the arms trade in creating an environment in which armed conflict such as the Gulf War can occur.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should demand that the Australian Government:
(a)outlaw sales of armaments and arms-related technology to overseas organisations: government and private.
(b)lobby internationally, including at the United Nations, for the banning of sales of armaments and arms-related technology.
(c)cancel the AIDEX 91 arms bazaar.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smokefree International Flights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned,
(i)are alarmed at the health and safety hazards that arise from the smoking of cigarettes and other tobacco products on international airlines, a dangerous practice banned within Australia;

(ii)call for the International Civil Aviation Organisation (IACO) of which Australia is a member to set a standard for smokefree international flights; standards set by IACO must be agreed to by its 162 member nations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055 Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PARA.TAB: (1)Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

(2)The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
(3)These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully call on the Government to withdraw its endorsement from the arms bazaar, AIDEX `91, scheduled to be held in Canberra, 26-28 November, 1991, and to ensure that no government department or company takes part in the aforementioned event.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX 91
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That attention is drawn to Australia's location and involvement in the Asia/Pacific region where there exists a number of actual and potential conflicts, along with several countries which can ill afford to pay for the importation of military equipment yet feel obliged to do so.

That Australia is increasing its role in the arms trade in this region, and in particular, it is supporting and participating in AIDEX `91. The arms trade is detrimental to Australians affected by the diversion of public money away from health, education, social welfare, and is an integral factor in the oppression and poverty of people of the Asia/Pacific region.
The petitioners therefore appeal to the Australian Parliament to:
Stop all military aid and training to governments engaged in repression of their own people

Direct those Government Departments participating in AIDEX `91, i.e. Defence, Austrade, Industry, Technology and Commerce, to cancel their bookings for space at the exhibition and withdraw their support for AIDEX `91.
Redirect all monies currently being used in promoting the arms industry to socially useful research, development and production.
Explore the possibilities of setting up an Agency for the development of techniques for conflict resolution.
Increase overseas aid to counteract the reduction since 1983/4.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Teague proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The need for the Government to adopt the strategy for the excellence in education announced in the Liberal-National `Fightback' program, in order to provide Australia with education and training of international standard and restore the community confidence in our schools, training institutions and universities which has disappeared under the Hawke Labor Government.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that informal arrangements have been made to limit the debate to 80 minutes, with the speaking times as follows: Senator Teague, 15 minutes; Senator Bolkus, 15 minutes; Senator Sowada, 10 minutes; Senator Tierney, 10 minutes; Senator Aulich, 10 minutes; Senator MacGibbon, 10 minutes; and Senator Giles, 10 minutes. With the concurrence of the Senate I shall ask the Clerks to set the clock accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an urgent need for this failed Labor Government to study the education policies announced in the Liberal-National Fightback program and to implement those policies.
