What are the two tests which the Labor Government has failed in education? One is the test of international standards. Australia has slipped away and is no longer providing to Australia's schools, technical and further education institutes and universities the international standards that we need to live up to the professed phrase `the clever country'. The second test the Labor Government has failed is to keep the confidence of the Australian community. The only way to restore these two objectives is to implement the education policies announced in the Liberal and National Fightback policies.

PARA.TAB: I will summarise the policies that have been announced by referring to five particular matters. Firstly, in a general assessment, there is the increased funding that is represented in the Fightback package for education. The other four points of summary deal with the positive policies for schools, technical and further education, universities and, finally, student benefits. This Fightback package of policies provides $3 billion more for education throughout Australia until the year 2000. There are increases in every area of education provision through the policies announced by Dr Hewson.

Not only will there be additional resources—an additional $3,000m—but also there will be lower costs because it has been decided that education services will not incur the goods and services tax. All education services will be zero rated and therefore this tax will not apply to them. At the same time, the wholesale sales tax will be abolished, petrol excise will be abolished and—a saving to universities—payroll tax will be abolished. With all these taxes no longer bearing upon education in this country, there will be a decrease in education costs, and those affected will be better off in real terms.

Secondly, with regard to schools, the Liberal and National parties have announced 19 new initiatives in the package, which I will itemise in a minute or two. This will include $721m more funding for Australian schools, both government and non-government. Thirdly, with regard to technical and further education, perhaps the Cinderella of Australian education currently, new resources need to be made available. The Liberal and National parties will provide $520m additional funding for TAFE to the year 2000. Fourthly, with regard to universities, there will be $245m more provided for university research; autonomy will be restored to Australia's universities; and Dawkins's centralism will be abolished. We will make it possible for additional students to be enrolled—that is, additional to the numbers currently or envisaged to be enrolled in the triennial provisions of this Parliament.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—Senator Teague, I remind you that you should refer to politicians by their titles. It is Mr Dawkins. Thank you.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will refer to Mr Dawkins this way: Mr Dawkins's centralism will be abolished. The Liberal and National parties will restore genuine autonomy to education institutions, including universities. Fifthly, with regard to student benefits, the Liberal and National parties will retain HECS—that is, the higher education contribution scheme—but we will increase the discount for payments that are made up-front; that is, at the beginning of the year of study, we will increase the discount from 15 per cent to 25 per cent. This will mean a saving to an average full time student of $225 per annum. We will provide 200 more postgraduate awards, and the value of each postgraduate award will be increased by $2,000 per annum.

PARA.TAB: Further, all Austudy rates of benefit will be increased by 6 per cent, which is parallel to the increase in benefits, to give compensation for the goods and services tax. This 6 per cent increase in Austudy rates is greater than the expected 4.4 per cent GST induced inflation.
This week I received a letter from the headmaster of a school in my State of South Australia. He states:

I must say how positively the proposals of the Liberal and National Parties relating to Goods and Services Tax were received by the education sector. We are delighted that our concerns have been taken into account with the proposals which have been developed.

I am most encouraged that education services will be zero-rated under the Goods and Services Tax both in relation to purchases and fees, and that special consideration has been given to the rural sector to allow for country students to receive allowances for boarding.
I am most encouraged by the obvious consideration that your party has given to the requirements of education in future years, acknowledging the real needs that exist.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to incorporate the full text of the letter in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—Is leave granted?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have to look at it first.

—I stress that the exemption from goods and services tax will not only apply to all schools, universities, TAFE institutions and all their activities, but it will also apply to all preschools, Sunday schools, kindergartens, bible colleges, correspondence schools, schools of the air, non-profit business and secretarial colleges, all courses for entry into regulated professions and occupations and private boarding schools.

PARA.TAB: I now wish to list the 19 new initiatives for schools that we have set out in the package. Point 1: we will introduce a national standards program to provide systematic and continuing assessment of the quality of learning. Point 2: we will provide for freedom of movement between non-government and government schools to allow maximum parental freedom of choice. Point 3: we will see the mutual recognition of teacher qualifications from State to State. Point 4: we will give greater flexibility to schools in the hiring of teachers and in determining conditions of employment.

Point 5: we will allow the acceptance of alternative paths into teaching so that competent persons can be attracted into teaching mid-career and we will not have the stereotype of teachers who have not, in many cases, sufficient experience of the wide world of work. Of course, in breaking those stereotypes by allowing this innovation we will ensure that all alternative entrants are fully educationally qualified to teach.

Point 6: we will break down regulations and work practices which inhibit schools in making the most effective use of schools in the community and in making contacts with industry. Point 7: we will have an excellence program for languages, other than English, of $5m a year at the school level. Point 8: there will be a schools of choice program of $10m a year.

Point 9: we will have a quality of teaching program of annual awards for outstanding teachers nominated by schools and parents of $10m a year. Point 10: there will be a literacy start program of $5m a year to identify and support best practice initiatives for children with learning difficulties. Point 11: there will be a $2m program for gifted children.

Point 12: we will abolish Mr Dawkins's so-called new schools policy for non-government schools and abolish all the restrictions for new schools that this represents. Point 13: non-government schools will receive an additional $567m for capital improvement over the years 1993 to 2000. This will provide the choice that another 20 per cent of Australian families wish to have for their children whereby they will have non-government schools in which to enrol, schools on which the present Government has closed the door.

Point 14: we will increase the recurrent grants to non-government schools and simplify the present 12 levels to six levels, and every school child will benefit. Point 15: we will increase the assistance to isolated children with regard to school allowances, and the assets test on this scheme will be abolished at a cost of $6m. Point 16: an additional $10m per annum will be spent under this scheme to raise the value of the isolated children's boarding allowance. This will be particularly welcome right across the bush. This request has been made to senators and members over many years now as the assistance that has been made available for isolated children has been deteriorating.

Point 17: the assets test on Austudy will be set aside in cases of extreme economic hardship. I refer particularly to the crisis in rural areas that many families are suffering. Point 18: there will be an increase of 6 per cent in the Austudy rate of payment. Point 19: there will be an increase of 6 per cent in Abstudy payments.

By these 19 new initiatives for schools we are spending a large part of the additional $3,000m set aside for education in the Fightback package. This is the means by which we will restore Australian education to international standards and restore Australian community confidence in schools. In referring to universities in the package, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter written by Dr David Kemp that appeared in today's Australian Financial Review.
Leave granted.
SIR, I feel that readers of The Australian Financial Review have been short-changed in Michael Dwyer's reporting of the coalition's education initiatives announced as part of the GST package.

In his comment piece (AFR November 26), he refers to a "major ideological shift in the focus of Commonwealth education funding" away from public universities. It is not at all clear to me what this means, but even a cursory reading of the policy statement would show a significant increase in university funding.

The policy statement commits a coalition government to at least maintaining the real level per student funding of higher education as well as spending an additional $245 million on university research to the year 2000. A matching grants programme of $25 million a year will be provided to support basic research in institutions which are successful in obtaining industry research contracts. In addition, the coalition has promised an extra 200 post-graduate research awards plus lifting the value of the awards by $2,000. This represents a substantial net gain to all universities, public or private.

In the accompanying article on financial assistance to tertiary students Mr Dwyer said it would be "slashed by almost 10 per cent under the proposed GST package". Leaving aside the highly emotive verb chosen, Mr Dwyer chooses not to acknowledge that the bulk of the spending reduction is contained in eliminating waste, curbing fraud and reducing overpayments, priorities with which Mr Dwyer might reasonably be expected to agree.
The coalition reiterates its support for student assistance to keep in education those willing and able to continue who would otherwise be forced to withdraw for financial reasons.

In fact, in harmony with the philosophy of the "Fightback" programme to actually increase assistance to those in need, Austudy will be boosted by 6 per cent to compensate for the introduction of the GST. As this will almost certainly be over-compensation, Austudy recipients will have the value of their benefits increased in real terms; for example, the away independent rate would rise by $354.55 from its current $5,905.

Mr Dwyer also fails to acknowledge the significance of the increase in the discount rate on HECS for upfront payment which will be increased from 15 to 25 per cent. This will encourage students to pay upfront and reduce their fee by some $225.

Quite simply, the Liberal and National Party policy will create more university places to accommodate the 30,000 qualified Australians currently unable to enter tertiary institutions, create a genuine student market in which choice will be paramount and in which diversity will be encouraged, and foster the conditions for excellence.

SPEECH.PARA: Dr DAVID KEMP

TALK.START.PARA: —The letter answers a question that was put in the newspaper about university funding. I note that Dr Kemp refers to the $245m extra for university research, the extra postgraduate awards, the Austudy benefit rise of 6 per cent, the up-front discounts which will lead to a $225 per annum improvement for those who take that option and the provision of more university places. I also make the new point that payroll tax, which universities pay, will be no longer required under the package. For example, in the case of the University of Adelaide, this will mean a saving of $6.5m. I estimate that it will be a saving around Australia of about $300m.

PARA.TAB: I conclude by referring to a motion that was passed in the Senate just two weeks ago. It was a motion on higher education that I moved on behalf of the Opposition, supported by the Democrats. It is the resolution of this Senate. For easy reference, I ask that the words of this resolution be incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
In respect of the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991:
At end of motion, add ", but the Senate condemns the Government for:
(a)its determination to maintain a flawed funding mechanism for higher education;
(b)its pursuit of a policy which prevents over 30,000 qualified Australian students from gaining places;
(c)its failure to address adequately the issues of quality and diversity in higher education;
(d)its failure to address the serious inequities of current higher education funding arrangements; and
(e)its decision to deal with overcrowding mainly by excluding even more Australian students from university places".

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. With regard to TAFE, we will increase funding by $75m per annum, which will be more than half a billion dollars of additional moneys for technical and further education before the year 2000. This is the package which has given hope to Australians. This is the Fightback package that will fight us back into education standards that are at an international level and that will bring full community confidence. It is only by the Government adopting this package that we will see the kinds of education reforms that Australia needs.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Senator, Teague, I understand that prior to my coming into the chair, you sought leave to incorporate a letter. Is that the letter which you were later given leave to incorporate or is that an additional letter which has not yet been finalised?

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask whether the Senate will give leave for the incorporation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate and I thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baden Teague
6 Waterloo Street
GLENELG SA 5045
25th November, 1991
Dear Baden,

PARA.TAB: I must say how positively the proposals of the Liberal and National Parties relating to Goods and Services Tax were received by the education sector. We are delighted that our concerns have been taken into account with the proposals which have been developed.

I am most encouraged that education services will be zero-rated under the Goods and Services Tax both in relation to purchases and fees, and that special consideration has been given to the rural sector to allow for country students to receive allowances for boarding. In the latter regard I would also point out that it is iniquitous to have Fringe Benefits Tax paid for resident staff who need to provide a 24 hour coverage of care for students in the boarding houses.

The attention of the Liberal and National Parties to the increasing of per capita grants (collapsing the current 12 levels to 6) and doubling the capital grants programme for non-Government schools is acknowledged. For Level 1 schools . . . , however, there is little joy in the needs differential of 5% with schools in Levels 2 and 3. These schools have enjoyed changing rules in 1988 and 1992 which have kept many of them from being classified as Level 1, giving a competitive advantage with respect to fees especially when accumulated over the years.

All in all, however, I believe we were most encouraged by the obvious consideration that your party has given to the requirements of education in future years, acknowledging the real needs that exist.

SPEECH.PARA: Yours sincerely,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose this matter of public importance. Senator Teague spent a great amount of his time praising the so-called Fightback package. The Australian public is starting to become aware of the package and all its implications. The basic point about it is that it does not add up. It pretends to make everyone better off. To that extent, it is and will be exposed as being totally inadequate.
—You haven't started doing that yet.

—We have not started yet but already the Australian public is waking up to it. The basic thing it is waking up to is that one cannot promise to make everybody better off in the way that this coalition has done in the last week or so. It cannot promise to give so much to so many without people knowing from where the money is coming. Out there the public is saying, `If you expect us to believe in Dr Hewson, you would expect us to believe in both the Easter bunny and the tooth fairy'.

PARA.TAB: The basic thing about this package is that it is computer driven. It is driven by market research, computers and right wing ideology. Already we see in newspapers headlines such as—and I quote from the Ross Gittins article in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning—`Hewson shows how to lie with computers'. Towards the end of the article Ross Gittins says:

SPEECH.PARA: Which is just another indication of how irrelevant—and thereby misleading—the whole computer modelling exercise is.

We are dealing today with one of the add-ons. We are dealing today with one of those aspects of the package that will affect the lives of many Australians. Lots of things have been tacked onto this package to disguise its main elements. I must say to Senator Teague that there are so many potential bushfires in this package that Black Friday will look like a cold snap in six months time.

PARA.TAB: There are so many areas such as this one that will be affected by the package because the basic principle behind this package is inequity. The main element is reducing the tax which is now raised according to the ability to pay and swapping it for a tax which is levied despite an ability to pay. It is being driven by a very pathetic, outdated philosophy—one that is not new, one that has been tried overseas and one that has been found failing overseas in a whole range of areas. It is little wonder that already, as I say, this morning we get headlines like `Churches attack GST for selling out the poor'. We will get a lot more of those because out in the community people are starting to lick through the package.

What we have in this package is nothing other than a poisoned toffee apple, and the public is licking to the core of it. It is not happy about the fact that it has to pay an extra 15 per cent for the toffee either, but it is licking through and it is finding out. There is only one part of this community which has not woken up to this package yet, and I say that with some regret. It is my friends in the press gallery, the marshmallow club. They have called the game after 10 minutes; they have seen 10 minutes of play and they reckon the game is over.

They have a challenge up there. What they have to do is look at the specialist writers—those outside of the gallery upstairs, those outside of Canberra. They have to start to see what the experts are saying and analyse the substance. They are still licking the toffee. They have not got to the substance yet. But unless they do that, in six months time they will be totally irrelevant to the whole debate going on in this community.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President: the matter of public importance that I introduced in this afternoon's agenda for the Senate is about education policy. The Minister has been on his feet now for almost five minutes and he has not mentioned education. He has not mentioned anything that is relevant to the words of the matter that I brought. In my own speaking I referred only to education policies. The Minister ought to be required to address himself to the words that are in front of us in the Senate. So far he has not shown that he has anything at all to say.
—Madam Acting Deputy President—
—I might be able to save you some time, Senator Bolkus.
—I am just about to move to education. I have mentioned education once already and I am about to do that again.

—Perhaps I can respond to the point of order. I thought you wanted to speak on the point of order; that is why I was asking you to hold on there. There is no point of order. The matter of public importance that the Senate is discussing, in the first phrase before it goes into detail, draws attention to the Liberal-National Fightback program. As I understand it, that is what the Minister has been discussing in general. As the debate moves on, no doubt he will address his remarks; if he was not thinking of doing so, I am sure now he will address his remarks to the further detail in the matter of public importance before the chamber.

—As an instance of the massive con job that has been perpetrated, let me go to two points that Senator Teague made. He mentioned an extra $3 billion in funding over the next 10 years. Let us look at one area. Let us try to bring some honesty back into this debate in respect of the TAFE area. Senator Teague said that there would be a commitment for extra money from the Fightback package to TAFE. But what he does not mention is that the commitment of funds from the coalition is totally inadequate. Both the Deveson and Finn reports called for TAFE to be put on a growth path between now and the end of the decade. The Opposition has promised half of what is required to implement the Finn report.

PARA.TAB: In contrast to what the Opposition is promising, we have already announced an increase in technical and further education funding of over $100m for 1992 alone and we have put a proposal to the States for new funding arrangements for TAFE which will enable us to meet the endeavours and targets of the Finn report on post-compulsory education and training. That is one aspect of the package.

If we are talking about the benefits of this package, let us look at how it will impact on the whole raft of students in the community. Students will now have to pay a tax on books, something they have never before had to pay to the extent to which they will. There will be a 15 per cent tax on books. Those opposite should tell the students, whether in primary school or tertiary institutions, how much more they will have to pay under the package, and that they will be paying an extra 15 per cent in tax on the basic necessities for education. That is where the inequity comes into the Opposition's package. That is where the Opposition is swapping tax levied on the basis of ability to pay for tax levied despite the ability to pay.

The Opposition's education policy is based on one principle: education for the rich, ignorance for the rest. When we look at the collaboration of Drs Kemp and Hewson in their so-called policy, we see the ideologues who are prepared to sacrifice equity, equality and principle in an effort to raise so-called quality.

When it comes to education, there are two aspects to the package. In one respect the package follows some of the proposals that we have put up already in terms of a national curriculum, national assessment, and so on. In that respect, it can be accepted. The rest is a mishmash of ill-conceived ideology, with no coherence, no cohesiveness. It is interventionist and totally inadequate. It focuses on one part of the education process. It ignores enormously aspects other than those for universities.

Let us look at one of the two major legs of the package relating to education: the voucher system, which is claimed to be one of the major elements of the new Hewson-Kemp policy. It is impractical and inequitable and it will destroy our current system. Here we have a mob of terrorists attacking the education system in this country. A voucher system, as has been proposed by the Opposition, cannot take into account the fact that different courses lead to varying levels of benefit to society as a whole. If the voucher system is fixed—one of the options—the education system, as has been developed, will be disrupted enormously. If it is not fixed, the level of funding will not be able to be controlled and there will be a blow-out.

Any attempt to control the discipline mix—Senator Teague knows this—would contradict the purposes of vouchers and would be more intrusive into institutional affairs than are the current arrangements. Senator Teague understands that criticism and the people's concern that the Opposition's system will be more intrusive. Senator Teague understands that the Opposition is caught between either a blow-out to its Budget and a blow-out to institution planning or a blow-out of its policy.

Let us look at this aspect. The Opposition has spent quite a deal of time talking about removal of central control over universities. The Opposition policies will directly imply—and those opposite know this—a greater degree of control over the operation of institutions. The institutions know that. I do not have to go into detail at this stage. I do not have time to do that. The institutions know that pretty well. The Opposition's proposal for a highly intrusive centralised system of accreditation of institutions by the Higher Education Council, for instance, is unprecedented in interference with the affairs of the universities and their programs. Those opposite cannot tell me that with this voucher system they will not be forcing amalgamations, when they have criticised us so much over recent years for initiatives in that area.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is scare tactics.

—It is not a scare tactic. That will be the direct result of the Opposition's policies. Let us go to fees. Senator Teague and the Opposition preach very loudly about equity in the system and access to the system. The Opposition's proposal—it is accepted; Dr Kemp says that fees are a key element of the Opposition's proposals—is to allow universities to charge by setting course fees as students are admitted over and above the Commonwealth funded loans and to all other students. Under this major element of the Opposition's proposal, conveniently buried on page 48 of supplementary paper No. 4 of the package documents, all students could end up paying fees. They know that, and the Opposition knows that. The students will be paying enormous fees. They will be paying fees that would have one direct outcome: people who now have access to the system will not.
—This is just scare tactics.

—It is not scare tactics. Senator Teague has been programmed. That programming has led him to do two things: first, to laugh at the Government; and, second, to claim scare tactics. The Opposition might get away with that for a day or so, or a week or so. However, people in the community are a little brighter than the Opposition backbenchers. They are a little brighter than that mob upstairs. The community can already see this. I challenge Senator Teague to talk to members of the tertiary sector about what they see in the Opposition's proposal. Those are two aspects of the proposal.

PARA.TAB: Those opposite come in here with their new direction and proposals and claim that they are the answer to everything. Let us look further at the package. In respect of fees let us look at the United States experience. The Opposition claims in its document that no student will be prevented on financial grounds from proceeding. In the United States, when something like this has been tried, it has been found that many people have been denied. I know that those opposite talk about reliance on banks and loans from banks and so on, but the US Government has had to fork out huge sums of money to subsidise student loans.

The Opposition's package focuses on the tertiary sector and, to that extent, the provision of education is let down in that the figures for TAFE funding are not anywhere near what that sector should, and will, get.
The inequity of the Opposition's package is reflected in the area of schools. The package proposes to tax one level of schools and to exempt another.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not taxing any schools.

—In terms of paying consumption tax on school fees, the Opposition has exempted the private sector. I think Senator Vanstone, in her pamphlet, said, `We're not wimps; we will tax the rich as they spend'. If the Opposition wants to be consistent, it has not been consistent there.

PARA.TAB: We do have a government which over the past eight years or so has had a strong commitment to quality and equity in education in all sectors. The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Mr Baldwin, recently announced a major reform initiative designed to encourage quality assurance in higher education. They are not mere mouthings. There is a whole raft of proposals covering the National Centre for Teaching Excellence, the reserve fund and, from 1994 onwards, an extra allocation of $70m in new funds to go to institutions above normal institutional funding on the basis of performance.

Looking at the Government's list of proposals, we will also see that the percentage of public funding going to education is third highest of the OECD countries. We should also recognise that major achievements have been made over the past eight years. The Opposition talks about schools, about the opportunity for education. In the past nine years, there has been almost a doubling in the level of kids staying on in year 12. That has been a major achievement of this Government.

Let us go on. We have national curriculum development corporations. We have established 10 national goals for schooling. As importantly, we are working with the States. One important achievement in recent days has been the State and Territory agreement to remove unnecessary difficulties. Our programs are not based on and do not reflect an inept, inadequate, outdated ideology. The achievements are the result of much hard work dissecting the area. Whether a person is covered by the disadvantaged schools programs, the country areas program or the students at risk program, or is a migrant or is interested in English as a second language, our policies have been very much directed to satisfying demand and leading the way to improving the standard of education.

This Government has shown a commitment to quality and equity. We recognise that some students face obstacles to participation and achievement in education. We have tackled those barriers. The Opposition is pursuing a policy which, as I said at the start of my speech, is education for the rich, ignorance for the rest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating a matter of public importance related to quality and excellence in education brought on by the Opposition to force discussion in this place on the Fightback package. It is quite clear to the Australian Democrats that between now and the end of the year the Opposition will trot out various sections of its election platform as a means of drawing the Government and the Democrats into debate before any of us have looked at the proposals in detail.

PARA.TAB: I remind honourable senators that this package has been 18 months in the making and baking, with the assistance of accountants, economists and the like. We have had it less than two weeks and are now expected to make an instant judgment on what is clearly a very detailed, integrated and carefully constructed election manifesto.

The Australian Democrats have already stated that our detailed response to the specific policy areas will be forthcoming in the New Year. We will not be drawn into detailed comment so early in the debate, particularly on such an important area as education. We have said, however, that we will be requesting the Opposition to consider exempting the basic necessities of life from the 15 per cent goods and services tax. These would include essential foods, clothing, footwear and building materials, so that the low and middle income earners in our community would not be disadvantaged in the long term by price increases on goods they would have to purchase simply to survive from day to day.

A commitment to fairness and social justice is central to Democrats policy. Both the GST itself and all other areas of the package will be filtered through this basic premise as we sift through the details and talk to community groups which will be affected by the massive changes proposed by the coalition. Voters will need to assess the package not on the basis of short term gain but in the light of the fundamental social changes shrouded by the fine print and massive handouts contained in this document.

The Australian Democrats support access, diversity and quality at all levels of the education system. We support the key role of the Commonwealth in developing a nationally integrated education policy, focused on preparing Australians and Australia for a very different international economic climate than that of 30 years ago. In an age when we must move as a nation towards improving productivity, national output and the economic base of Australia, now is not the time for piecemeal policy-making devolved to the hands of the States.

In assessing this matter of public importance, the Democrats are in no doubt that our education system faces a severe lack of community confidence brought about by the policies of the Labor Government. But it is not just its education policies that have brought about this crisis. More and more students, despairing of finding a job—a situation caused by this Government's economic policies—are staying in education longer in the hope of putting off the inevitable hardship of not finding a job, and hoping that a qualification will increase their already dim chances of employment.

Without commenting directly on the Opposition's education package as outlined in its election manifesto it is, however, timely to assess the Hawke Labor Government's contribution to this sector as the Opposition has suggested in this matter of public importance. As the 1991 academic year closes, it is worth recalling that some 30,000 students missed out on a university place this year. Many universities were plagued by a severe overcrowding crisis, resulting in students being locked out of lectures on some campuses and being issued with lecture tickets on others. While student numbers have increased from 394,000 in 1987 to 535,000 in 1991, universities have not had the resources to cope with these numbers and, as a result, the quality of higher education has suffered badly. In a recent survey, 70 per cent of academics reported that teaching facilities were inadequate for their needs.

Indeed, despite the rhetoric and the apparent injection of funds into the tertiary sector, the reality is that at many universities massive budget cuts are the norm, choices for students are reduced and lectures and tutorials are being cut. Just ask the Chief Librarian at the University of Sydney, who must shave $1m from his budget this year.

Austudy was introduced in 1987, replacing the tertiary education assistance scheme and some other less prominent student funding schemes. Despite amalgamating several diverse funding schemes under one umbrella, the effect of Austudy on students has often been one of great confusion and frustration due to a complex welter of regulations. Often these regulations seem to be created on an ad hoc basis to address particular problems, without any serious attempt at overall coordination.

The result has been that applicants are required to be aware not only of their own and their parents' assets and income but also of such obscure matters as the difference between their institution's definition of `full time workload' and that of the Department of Employment, Education and Training. This is just a small part of the information required just to apply for Austudy, so it is little wonder that many students have problems.Once over the threshold, students must deal with a complex maze of bureaucratic restrictions and conditions imposed on the allowance which, moreover, may be changed inconsistently from year to year. Consequently, some students find themselves eligible for Austudy one year but not the next, even though their own situation has not varied.

The vast majority of Austudy recipients get far less than the theoretical recipient of full Austudy. They have to be satisfied with between $5 and $30 per week due to the stringencies of the parental income test. Clearly, this amount cannot support anyone, so these students have no choice but to seek work while studying. If they earn more than $4,000 a year, each dollar earned reduces their Austudy entitlement by 50c. All these students are forced to look for work, which will not only cut their study time but also reduce the number of jobs available for non-student members of the work force.

Austudy is clearly a mess and needs another overhaul. The paltry amount received by students is, in many cases—especially for these students living and studying in Sydney—completely insufficient for their needs. Austudy is still well below the amount received by those on unemployment benefit. Young people who may wish to further their education after school do better, financially, on the dole than in the education system. This inequitable and ludicrous situation must be rectified to ensure that students receive every possible encouragement to continue their studies beyond their school years.

We are witnessing enormous strains being placed on the TAFE sector as it is required to cope with increasing student numbers and the task of retraining and reskilling the work force. Funding burdens will not lighten over the next decade, especially given the Government's commitment—as stated in the Finn review—to bring the funding of TAFE fully under the auspices of the Commonwealth budgetary process. The Government has not successfully resolved this dilemma but, as I have said before in this place, estimates in the vicinity of $5 billion have been suggested by the Commonwealth-State working party on TAFE to meet the expansion needs of the TAFE sector as flagged in the Finn review. Clearly, the Opposition's allocation of $520m to fund expansion of the TAFE sector over the next decade will go nowhere near meeting the funding needs of this sector if the Commonwealth-State working party recommendations are to be believed.

However, in returning to this matter of public importance moved by the Opposition, we need to be mindful of the inherent dangers posed by the wording of it. The word `excellence' raises its head. While I do not think that any member in this place would complain about the need for excellence in education, we need to be mindful as to what this might mean in the minds of members of the Opposition. I will quote briefly from an article in the Bulletin this week by David O'Reilly, which discussed the education philosophy propounded by the coalition's shadow education Minister, Dr David Kemp:

SPEECH.PARA: Kemps Education policy, for example, seems to make a virtue of elitism—allowing school principals to break out of centralised bureaucratic and union control, set up their schools as independent businesses and hire the best teachers. Kemp would provide more scholarships so education was free for the most talented. But he would allow those who did not make the grade under the government-funded tertiary education selection process to buy extra places in universities by paying fees. This kind of elitism, Kemp and Hewson argue, will produce excellence.

So here we have it—excellence is produced by exclusion and limiting access to all but an elite group of students. Where is the equity of access which has been a feature of higher education since the mid-1970s? We need to look no further than New South Wales to obtain some idea of where this policy might lead us.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, the Australian Democrats have already placed on the public record their opposition to any extension of fees to students. We will continue to support an education system which is equitable and open to all. Fightback! requires careful debate to look beyond the rhetoric; and from that point of view we will give the Opposition's education package most careful consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we bring to the attention of the Senate a subject of great importance. Education is a responsibility that has long been acknowledged as the backbone of any successful progressive society. It is through education of its people that a country can grow, adapt and seize opportunities. Government has certain responsibilities to create an environment where education can flourish through all levels of society and through every stage of a person's life. Without a strong commitment to education we stagnate as a country and as a people. Education needs a commitment from government, whether it be in schooling, TAFE, other vocational training, higher education or—the neglected fourth sector of the education structure—adult and community education.

PARA.TAB: We bring this matter to the attention of the Senate in order to urge the Hawke Labor Government to abandon its policies of centralism and mismanagement. The coalition has the policies that will restore dynamic growth to this vital sector of our economy and society. The Fightback program addresses all levels of our education system and seeks to correct the destructive policies of the Hawke Government.

As are all aspects of education in Australia under the Hawke Government, the university sector is restricted and hampered by rigid centralist policies that prevent constructive growth and leave the universities incapable of meeting the demands that are placed upon them. This has resulted in the standards of our universities deteriorating compared with the world standard.

The Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, has created a system of higher education which is directed by political and bureaucratic discretion. A direct result of this has been the erosion of university autonomy in Australia, leaving the institutions financially vulnerable.

Research allocation is highly centralised and institutions are heavily restricted as to their course content and student enrolment. In the current system, the central allocation of resources, including those for research, educational profiles as a prerequisite for funding, student quotas, prohibition on admitting Australian undergraduates for fees and the centralised industrial relations framework have all contributed to the decline in our higher education sector. The results of this system have been disastrous for the quality of teaching and research, and the efficient use of resources. This has become more evident every day.

Presently there are almost 30,000 qualified Australians who are excluded from higher education by Government imposed quotas. Incentives arising from Government regulation has resulted in the overenrolment of 14,000 which has put a serious strain on our universities with their massive overcrowding problems. Disruption and demoralisation resulting from centrally forced amalgamation are rife right across the country. A looming academic staff shortage has been estimated to reach 20,000 by the end of the decade. There is increasing frustration arising from the prohibition on institutions accessing otherwise available private funds for higher education. It is easily observed that all of these problems stem from the Governments application of inappropriate centralist policies.

The Fightback program will put our education sector back on track. It particularly addresses the problems that our universities now face. The basic philosophy underlying the coalition's strategy for education is that individuals and institutions should have the freedom to choose their own futures within very broad limitations. With freedom comes responsibility, including financial responsibility. Given that responsibility, institutions should be largely independent of government control or interference. Success or failure should depend on merit, not upon winning bureaucratic favour.

The primary objective of the Fightback program's education policy for higher education is a university system of world class standard, providing the diversity of opportunities required to meet the diversity of student need. The key role of universities as Australia's powerhouses of research needs to be strengthened while allowing it to develop the responsiveness necessary to meet the need of international competitiveness. This has not been achieved during the term of the Hawke Government.

Government regulation and imposed uniformity can stifle initiative and diversity, and leads to mediocrity. A competitive framework will allow this to occur. Freedom for institutions, academics and students requires a decisive move away from a centrally administered system to one based on a greatly strengthened student market in which students can choose their university based on their own judgments and institutions have the flexibility to respond to those choices.

These important issues are addressed in the coalition's Fightback program. The implementation of the policy will have very positive effects for Australian universities. The funding arrangements will provide continuing, and indeed strengthened, incentives to institutional strategic planning to define each institution's mission and its place in the market for students. Diversity of institutions will be encouraged as the diversity of student demand is met.

The pressures towards centralisation on campus imposed by the demand of the Labor Government's national unified system for information and observance of central regulations will be greatly eased. University administrators will have greater control over institutional budgets through fee structures, the funding arrangements for undergraduate and postgraduate students will be unified and the objectionable distinction between full fee paying overseas students and other students will be eliminated. These funding arrangements outlined in the Fightback program will provide a less politicised, more rational allocation of resources. Financial and human resources will have much greater freedom to move within the system in response to the demand of institutions setting their own priorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sort of like a new Jerusalem.

—As Senator Aulich rightly points out, a new Jerusalem for higher education. The Fightback program acknowledges that Australia's universities play a vital role in providing access to, and contributing to, both the international and national research effort. The coalition rejects the attempt to make the content of the nation's basic research effort subject to politically determined national priorities. The funding of this effort should secure a higher level of independence and decision-making arrangements should encourage responsiveness to the needs of industry.

PARA.TAB: This morning, when opening the symposium on the Quality of Teaching in Higher Education Institutions, the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Mr Baldwin, demonstrated that he quite obviously did not have a rational grasp of the issues and problems in higher education today and does not understand what the Fightback program will achieve. Like the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Treasurer (Mr Kerin) before him, who are so desperately trying to find a hole in the Fightback program but who resort to taking liberties with the truth instead, Mr Baldwin totally misrepresented the implications for higher education of our education policy. I found this rather ironical, as he was addressing a gathering of scholars who are seekers of truth.

Let us take a moment to discover the truth of the issues that the Minister raised. He claimed that the introduction of the national awards system means that institutions will lose control of the discipline mix. This is just an indication of his socialist, centralist thinking. What we are really proposing is a market driven system where students take their national awards or vouchers and then vote with their feet. Therefore, the outcome in terms of a discipline mix will be what the students and what the industries want, not what central planners think they should have.

Mr Baldwin also claims that the policy would create mega-institutions. I thought that is what we have just completed under the Dawkins national unified system. What this policy will do is assist universities to develop their areas of strength. What will happen under the coalition policies is that certain faculties within universities will blossom as they display excellence and others will wither as their performance is shown to be below standard. This market driven competition will raise the overall standards of our institutions.

The Minister also claims that our policies will affect the socioeconomic mix in universities. He is well aware that many studies have shown that when one compares times in which there have been no fees with periods when fees have been levied, one finds that there has been no change in the socio-economic mix.

The Minister also criticised the variable fee structure, conveniently forgetting that overseas students who are prepared to pay full fees will gain a place in our universities but Australian students who are prepared to pay cannot gain a place. It is only by moving towards a user pays principle that we will generate the funds to create the places needed. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise for the full 10 minutes that we have been allocated to debate this issue in depth. But, to be crude, this paper of the Liberals called Fightback! really requires only about 10 minutes debate. The paper itself should have been called `Rightback'; that is, right back into the 1980s.
—Your understanding of it would only take one minute, wouldn't it?

—What really stands out about this Fightback! or `Rightback' paper, which Senator Macdonald seeks to defend, is that it seems to be something out of antiquity. In other words, it looks like something straight out of the 1980s. It is the Thatcher plan and it is the Reagan plan for the 1980s.

PARA.TAB: Maybe someone should have told the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, that somehow or other there is a new era beginning and that maybe the Gordon Gekko approach to education and society is out of place—that the 1980s are over, and that greed in fact is not good and there are other things that motivate people. One might be community service, another altruism, and another the question of whether or not individuals are the be-all and end-all of our society or whether one is educated by the community to contribute to the community as well as to develop oneself. I guess that is the difference between the attitudes we have on this side of the House as a government and the attitudes that prevail elsewhere. I am not sure that this `Rightback' or Fightback! paper is the view of—

TALK.START.PARA: —`Frightpack'.

—Or `Frightpack', is the view of the whole Opposition. When the Fightback! documents were delivered it was the most entertaining spectacle on television. Even my wife, who can tolerate those opposite from time to time—more than I can—sat back in shock and amazement when she saw the performance in the party room of those opposite. This document of 600 pages was brought in and dumped in front of the back bench. Someone must have said, `Let's move for it'. Then those opposite chatted for a little while about it. Within less than 24 hours, suddenly those opposite were all standing up like an Australian Rules crowd at three-quarter time, or a rugby crowd, chanting and holding hands—that in itself was a wonderful sight to see—trying to gee themselves up to give themselves some psychological advantage over the Government and for the cameras.

PARA.TAB: One of the cameramen going into the party room heard one of those opposite say, `Come on, fellas. We have to make it look good'. That is exactly what the Fightback package is all about—making it look good. What those Opposite are selling is something akin to the Chevrolet with fins. It is 1980s stuff, 1970s stuff. It goes back to the period when everyone thought that, somehow or other, governments ought to stay out of it, that it should be left up to individuals wanting to make a buck to drive society. Has Mr Skase told those opposite about that, or Mr Bond and other people—

TALK.START.PARA: —What? One of your rich mates.

—They are not my mates and they never have been; I can assure those opposite of that. This comes from the `greed is good' era. I want to look at some of the areas where this Government has created a changed situation in education. I think I am, of all the people in this chamber, entitled to call myself reasonably objective about matters relating to education. Everyone knows that I have stood up my own Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) from time to time on major issues. I have been called all things under the sun by him and he has disagreed with me on a number of significant issues. That is what this place is about. It is supposed to involve individuals coming to terms with their own conscience, their own intellectual and political positions, and standing up and being counted—which is what I did, even against my Minister.

PARA.TAB: One thing I must say about Joe Dawkins as a Minister is that he has made a number of very significant changes—changes that were long overdue—in the political and educational system of this country. I will go through some of them if those opposite wish. When we came to government, less than 12 per cent of school leavers went on to university. Australia was near the bottom of OECD countries for participation in higher education. The level is now about 30 per cent. That in itself is a major improvement which would never have occurred under those opposite. It is something that would not have occurred unless Minister Dawkins had sat down and worked out ways in which the terribly low participation rate in higher education could be lifted. He brought that improvement about. Sure, I do not agree with all his methods, but at least he put himself out the front and argued that case in Cabinet.

Secondly, he has also changed the social mix in our universities—though not as much as I would like; it is still of concern that the middle class send their middle class kids to universities to learn middle class things and then get into middle class jobs. It does seem, for example, that people living in the western suburbs of Sydney tend to miss out compared with children who come from the eastern suburbs or Wahroonga. It is interesting to look at the figures for the days when the conservatives were running education. In 1939, 76 per cent of all university graduates came from private schools, yet roughly 75 per cent of school children went to public schools and 25 per cent went to private schools. So the figures were totally reversed. It was even worse in the prestigious subjects such as medicine. At Sydney University, 90 per cent of those who graduated in medicine came from private schools.

TALK.START.PARA: —So what?
—The professor opposite says, `So what?'. Does he believe that people going to university should come from only one socioeconomic group—from the privileged people in the community?
—No, I don't.

—Let me put it another way: does Senator MacGibbon believe that doctors and lawyers should come from only one social class? Is that his view about the way society plucks out talent? In other words, we wipe out two-thirds of our society and say, `We are not interested in the skills that you have to give to society or in you improving yourself. We are interested in taking only the elite socioeconomic groups, plucking them out and putting them through university and giving them all the benefits that university education provides'. If that is the sort of thing that Senator MacGibbon wants—he ought to go back to 1939, further back than the 1980s where this Fightback! document is, where his people were basically running the show—then he should say so here and now.

PARA.TAB: Have a look at the Opposition's voucher system. It is all about making sure that the elite groups get the benefits. I do not care whether the elite groups get the benefits, but what I do care about is that it is a poor, ineffective and unfair society which simply says that two-thirds of society is not going to get any benefit from higher education, that it can miss out and cannot contribute to society as a whole in the way it should.It is very interesting that that is the way those opposite are putting it when we look at the voucher system. In other words, in medicine—

TALK.START.PARA: —We have too many medicos.

—That is interesting. Senator MacGibbon has agreed that if those opposite ever get into government, and copy this particular document, they will loosen all controls over who goes into what disciplines. They will leave it up to the marketplace—`greed is good' et cetera—to decide into what disciplines students go. The net result of the mechanics that we have in this proposal will be that the faculties of law, veterinary science and medicine will be very much in demand—even more so than now—and the universities will charge enormous fees for those, because they will be free, under the proposal of those opposite, to do so. Those fees will be the real income earners for the universities. So more places will be created by the universities, funded by people seeking to be doctors, lawyers and veterinary scientists.

PARA.TAB: They are the key faculties as far as demand is concerned: parents think their children are going to make money if they are educated in those areas. Is that what those opposite want—universities simply dropping off important subjects such as science because nobody wants them? The big money is in medicine and law, so that is what the universities will cater for. Do those opposite want the `greed is good' syndrome to run the higher education institutions in this country? That is what the `Rightback'—or `Frightpack' —document is all about: `Greed is good', and that is how higher education is going to run. What about the noble virtues of learning for learning's sake, of civilising our society, of ensuring that people are given an opportunity to use their intelligence? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Ten minutes is not much time to deal with the antiquarian approach to education that we have just heard about, but I would just put some points on the record for starters. First, the modern education system in Australia was developed by the Liberal Government under Bob Menzies. The expansion of the universities in the late 1940s, 1950s and 1960s was a product of a Liberal government which sought to bring equality of opportunity to all Australians who were able, intellectually, to take advantage of it. There were no restraints on people getting into university because a very lavish Commonwealth scholarship system was available to all who were able to get in.
—It was not open to all.

—I am a little older than Senator Aulich and I was one of those people. Since the golden age of education in Australia, we have had the reduction to the lowest common denominator under Mr Dawkins. We have had nothing but amalgamations of CAEs and a fall in academic standards across the board in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Senator Aulich raised the point that a certain socioeconomic group gets into universities. That is perfectly true. I do not deny that; I do not support it. I look beyond the statement to the reason. There is not a massive conspiracy in society saying that only members of the middle class go to universities. The reason why a certain strata in Australian society takes advantage of education is that within individual families there is a premium placed on scholarships. Our children grew up in a family where they were respected for doing their homework in primary school and secondary school. That environment within the family meant that children followed on to a successful university career. I do not propose to go on that path much longer. My time is short and I have wasted time talking on an irrelevancy.

There is a need to restore excellence in Australian education from the wasteland it is in. It is vital that we do that if we are to recover as a nation; it is vital if we are to fulfil our destiny. I want to go to the heart of excellence in education; that is, quite simply, the teaching of mathematics. Most people are quite oblivious to the crucial importance of mathematics in education. It is a subject that most people shy away from—they are uncomfortable with it. Mathematics is the very core, the fundamental building block of a civilised, industrialised society. Its progeny are the sciences—pure and applied science, health sciences, technology and engineering. I do not want to get into a sterile, semantic debate about science versus technology, but the place of mathematics, and how well it is taught, is absolutely crucial to our development as a nation. The mastery of this subject and its application will give us the sort of society which we want—increased living standards, being able to do something for the poor and the needy, developing industry, looking after the environment and the 1,001 things that are essential and pressing upon us. Without a mastery of mathematics we will go deeper and deeper into Third World status.

In developing this theme, I wish to look at a couple of points: the teaching of mathematics, firstly, in schools and, secondly, in tertiary institutions. On an Australia-wide basis, there is an imbalance in schools—the curriculum is loaded too heavily towards the humanities at the expense of the maths and science groups. I am not denying at all the humanitarian values in an education; in fact, I have been in more art galleries and spent more time at symphony concerts than anyone in this chamber. There has to be a balance; we have to prioritise our education.

When we ask children coming out of schools these days some humanitarian or civic knowledge questions they are unable to answer. If we took 1,000 year 12 students and asked them what they know about the Senate—for example, how many senators are from their State—90 per cent of them could not tell us that there were 12. If we told them that there were 12 senators and asked them to name three or four, they could not do it. They could not tell us what the functions of the Senate are; they could not even tell us what the Australian Constitution provides—something that every American high school graduate can do about the US Constitution. I do not think that we are getting value out of the effort we put into the humanities.

I refer again to the need for schools to be able to produce people who are mathematically literate. To be functionally mathematically illiterate is to be as economically and socially constrained as being unable to read or write. How can people below the poverty line, trying to budget the expenses of the family, do that if they do not have basic mathematical skills? A level of competence in mathematics is absolutely essential in society.

Let us look at tertiary education. I believe that the standards for maths and the sciences should be raised as a prerequisite for entry into university. If a person does not have knowledge of those two subject groups, how can he speak the lingua franca of the age? How can he know what is going on around him? How can a legislator see the possibilities of the future if he is denied some insight into the modern environment?

I will return to the schools for a moment. If schools are going to teach mathematics, the first requirement is good teachers. I find it absurd that there is an egalitarian principle in schools where schoolteachers, irrespective of subject, are paid the same. Mathematics is the hardest of subjects and maths teachers ought to have a loading; they also ought to have some special training. They have to be competent in the subject, otherwise students detect that and have no confidence in them.

Some decent examination systems need to be introduced for mathematics in this country. Children love adventure; they love challenge; they love being tested. The education system ought to harness that creative enthusiasm. Children need to be tested on their ability to accumulate knowledge and get on top of subjects. Abandoning examinations because they create stress in the students is absolute nonsense. Learning must take place in an air of peace and tranquillity. We cannot have people, such as the empty heads on the other side of the chamber, stirring children up about nuclear ship visits, protesting about social issues and then trying to teach them difficult subjects. There has to be peace and tranquillity in the classroom. At the end of the day, we have to have examinations to find out how good they are.

TALK.START.PARA: —No debate? No shifting of values or social justice?

—I do not want to deal with people in my life who cannot handle stress. I certainly do not want to fly home from here at the end of the week with a pilot who panics because he loses a critical engine on take-off; I do not want to go to a medical practitioner who panics when a serious situation arises.

PARA.TAB: I will move on to the tertiary sector. The need for an improvement in mathematics and science is crucial to improving the level of excellence within the Australian academic environment. Senator Aulich said that not many students are enrolling in the science faculties. We find that many science faculties at the universities now have the lowest entry scores—some of them lower than human movement studies. Part of that is as a result of the policy of this Government of paying for bodies enrolled on courses. It is a body snatching exercise. The science faculties have lowered their standards to attract students.

If we look at campuses, we see that mathematics is weakly represented—those departments are not as strong as they are in many universities overseas. We find that research in pure mathematics is poorly funded. That is one of the great ironies that the socialists sitting opposite ought to ponder. The countries which treat education as an extension of the welfare system, such as the United Kingdom and Australia, are the countries which fund most weakly pure science and pure mathematics research. Yet in the United States, where the capitalist system applies and given the benefits of pure science and pure mathematics research are not so visible instantly, we find that there is no shortage of benefactors to support those activities, both at the corporate and private levels.

Finally, in developing excellence in education we have to provide career paths for people who are prepared to follow difficult subjects, such as mathematics and science. We need an affirmative action program which provides doctoral scholarships, post-doctoral appointments and research appointments. After all, research in pure mathematics is the cheapest of all—one needs an office, a decent computer and a decent travel grant to go to conferences overseas. All research today requires extensive computing.

The problems before us are enormous. At the end of the day, they stem from a poor education system. We have to work our way out of the problems that we are in. We will not work our way out through the strength of our muscles; we can do it only through the strength of our intellects. We need a decent training system, which this Government is not giving us and is quite incapable of giving us, with its reduction to the lowest common denominator, to meet the challenges of staying alive nationally.

TALK.START.PARA: —I could not agree more with the penultimate sentence uttered by Senator MacGibbon about the need for a decent training system. But if we were to rely upon this extraordinary package of the coalition for some blueprint of a decent training system, the poverty of the whole exercise would be exposed for exactly what it is: a market and computer driven approach to social issues—social issues which Senator MacGibbon has just managed to put, if not completely out of the curriculum, certainly onto the back burner. The reliance on tricks, half truths, subterfuge and sheer wrong-headedness is almost breathtaking.

PARA.TAB: Australians, particularly women, as we have been told in surveys that have been undertaken, are beginning to see through this deceit. This is not at all surprising when we remember that very many Australian women previously lived in the United Kingdom. Many of them have relatives or friends who are experiencing VAT in New Zealand. I remind honourable senators that even in the United Kingdom the Government was not blatant, harsh and cruel enough to put VAT on basic foodstuffs, children's clothes, public transport fares, electricity and gas bills.

Presumably, the matter of public importance before us today does acknowledge the existence of young people. But, looking at the actual documents which have been produced for our edification, dare I say, one would think that the coalition's main concern is with the institutional and instrumental aspects of education. There are simply no measures for young people in the Fightback package. In a document of nearly 700 pages, the only attempt to address the needs of at-risk young people, those who are most in need of consideration in any education policy, is a statement that an Opposition government would work with the States to ensure that young people have appropriate assistance—no detail, no funding, no real analysis.

There are specific policies in the document which undermine the coalition's stated aim and would severely disadvantage at-risk youth. It advocates the abolition of the CES, which would mean the abolition of youth access centres as well as a whole range of other essential services and means of helping disadvantaged youth to gain access to education and training. The coalition intends to abolish the youth group bureau while simultaneously claiming that the Fightback program represents a massive investment in our youth. It seems absolutely extraordinary to me that there is this degree of self-delusion amongst the authors of this document. Homeless and unemployed youth, like everybody else, will have to pay 15 per cent more for everything they buy—clothing, basic foodstuffs, transport and electricity.

In contrast, this Government has a real commitment to youth and is carrying out that commitment. In purely educational terms, as honourable senators have just been reminded, there has been an enormous increase in participation to year 12, a doubling in seven or eight years, a remarkable increase in female participation in upper schooling and post-secondary schooling, and expansion from 12 per cent to 30 per cent, and a 250 per cent increase, in tertiary participation within a very short period of time.

I became aware of these sorts of things at the time my own children were in secondary schooling. At that stage, 20 years ago—after 20 years of conservative government—only 17 per cent of children in public schooling were going on to complete their secondary education. There has been an extraordinary revolution in education in this country over the last few years and, of all the achievements of the Hawke Government, this is the achievement of which I am most proud—the one which will make the greatest difference in the long term to the quality of life chances and the employment of Australians generally and, most importantly, of young Australians.

After all the effort which has gone into establishing a relatively acceptable system of Federal funding for private schools, this package offers a fast track back to the acrimony and divisiveness of the 1960s. That is one of the issues in which I was very much involved at the time and worked very hard to overcome, which work eventuated in the development of the Schools Commission. Of all those people who came together in the Schools Commission, who would have thought that a reform program would have elements such as the ones with which we have been faced in this extraordinary document? This is a major ideological shift in the focus of Commonwealth education funding away from the public sector and towards non-government schools and private universities.

As if this were not bad enough, we are told that accountability requirements for non-government schools will be abolished. This Government has a new schools policy: it will ensure that new non-government schools are established in areas where there is a demand for education facilities. The abolition of our new schools policy as advocated by the coalition would mean that any private school anywhere in Australia would receive Federal Government funding—tiny schools with handfuls of students, huge expansionist schools and struggling medium-sized schools, all battling for the education dollar. No school would be able to plan for the future. Billions of dollars in school facilities would be wasted. Doubling in the capital grants programs, as the Liberals propose, would have a minimal impact on the shocking wastage of school facilities.

In all of this there would be no accountability. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts will be very interested if this ever comes to pass. The coalition would reduce the existing 12 funding categories down to six with funding linked to government schools' costs. What will this mean? It will mean that, under the Hewson plan, there will be massive funding increases to schools in categories one and two and very small increases in grants to poorer schools.

I seek to have incorporated in Hansard an extract from the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette which shows clearly which schools will have their funding massively increased and which schools, mostly Aboriginal schools and schools for the disabled, will benefit very little, if at all, from this extraordinary new—or should I say, very old—extremely reactionary and regressive approach to schooling.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you seeking leave to incorporate those lists in Hansard?
—Yes. I seek leave to incorporate these lists from the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette.
—I would like to see them.

—I would be happy for Senator Teague to peruse them. Senator Teague's boasts about extra TAFE funding are as hollow as everything else in this package relating to education. The training levy guarantee is being cut out. Our $400m guarantee for training is to be chopped out in the same way as New Zealand and its national Government has rejected totally any interest in training.

PARA.TAB: The coalition has pledged to TAFE $520m over the next eight years. This amount will not be anything like enough. The one-off increase of about $45m in the first year and then static funding for seven years is less than half of what is required to implement the Finn report. TAFE is no longer the cinderella of the Labor Government. Both Deveson and Finn have called for TAFE to be put on a growth path between now and the end of the decade, and that is exactly what we intend to do. The Opposition proposal in this as in every other respect negates the Finn and Deveson targets for access and equity and for social justice in our education system which have been, and will continue to be, characteristics of the Hawke Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to tidy that up, Senator Teague, have you seen those documents? Are you prepared to grant leave?
—I have looked at the documents. There are about six full pages of lists, and I am not at all clear that they are in fact in a suitable form to be incorporated in the Hansard record.
—Senator Giles, can I just ask you to make clear what it is you are seeking leave to incorporate?

—Yes. It is an extract from the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette which lists schools in their funding categories. I do not see why there would be any difficulty, in a technical sense, with their incorporation. Perhaps we could consult Hansard on that.

—We do not wish in any way to refuse a reasonable request for leave but, as Senator Giles has said, this information is available in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. Six pages of detailed lists would take about six pages of Hansard. I do not believe that it is of a form that would normally be incorporated in Hansard. The information is fully available in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. I ask Senator Giles whether she really wishes to press for inclusion.

—Yes, I would be pressing to have this document incorporated. I am quite sure that Hansard can find a form in which to include the information. It is not unusual, if I might remind you, Madam Acting Deputy President, to incorporate in Hansard information which is available, and fairly readily available, elsewhere. The Commonwealth of Australia Gazette is available to those of us in Parliament and to some other people but not to the public generally.
—Leave is granted but on the basis that all of the contents of those five or six pages be included so that the whole list is available for anyone who is interested.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I wish to say something on this matter. Having been in this place for four years, I am now not a new girl. But some time ago, I made a similar request to have quite a detailed document incorporated in Hansard. Hansard officers requested that, if I anticipated incorporating a document of that sort in the future, I provide them with the material early on so that they could start to type it up and not delay the production of Hansard. Hansard now has to prepare all of this material. Senator Giles has been here for much longer than I have. I wonder whether Senator Giles approached Hansard before she asked for this document to be incorporated. Incorporating a document at this stage of the day does place an undue load on Hansard.
—With respect, Senator Patterson, this is a very elegant little discussion but it really has nothing to do with whether the Senate is prepared to grant leave.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, in fact it does. I was about to oppose leave being given to incorporate this document because, bearing in mind the problems faced by Hansard, I felt that this matter should have been addressed beforehand. If honourable senators are going to table documents of this length—and I made an error of this sort a couple of weeks ago—it should be brought to their attention, perhaps even by the Clerk of the Senate or the President, that they ought to consider Hansard and provide the material so that it can be prepared in disk form.

—by leave—It behoves all of us in this chamber to exercise a degree of tolerance about giving leave to incorporate material in Hansard. I say that for the reason that all of us at one time or another have wished to incorporate documentation which illustrates the remarks we have made. Given the time limits on debate, sometimes it is neither possible nor appropriate to cover that type of material in any detail. This is one of those issues that affects both sides of the chamber equally—but I dare say that more Opposition senators than Government senators sometimes seek to incorporate material in order to make detailed explanations. So, on the first point, it is very desirable that there be a degree of tolerance.
