PARA.TAB: The second point is that it is true that one ought to try to accommodate the concerns of Hansard and there is an obligation on all of us to do that appropriately and properly. But it should be remembered that the Senate exists to enable representatives to express views in a wholly unedited way within the Standing Orders. Therefore, any implication that those views ought to be modified, tailored or unduly restricted to suit the needs of Hansard is to be rejected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Six pages!
—Tolerance and freedom to express and illustrate are important questions here for all of us.

PARA.TAB: The other matter that I wish to refer to is a possible implication in some of the remarks made by Senator Teague. I took him to mean that he would agree to giving leave, depending upon whether all of the tables, and not some of the tables, were included.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's what was asked.

—Senator Teague confirms that that is what was asked. I want to make it clear that it really is for the senator concerned to be specific about what is to be included. In some cases, all of the material may not need to be incorporated. Indeed, the point was made earlier about too much detail being given. But I do not think it is reasonable—and this is the point I am trying to make—for senators on the other side of the chamber to tell a senator that he or she can incorporate material on the basis of what they think is appropriate. That is a matter for the senator to decide. As the duty Minister, I simply make these remarks to make the Government's position clear. We exercise tolerance to enable everyone to put his or her point of view. It is a virtue of the Senate that that can be done and it is one that all of us should uphold.
—I seek leave to respond because the Minister, Senator Cook, referred to me in his remarks.
—Senator Teague, first of all I would like to clear up whether leave is to be granted. Senator Giles has sought leave and you have acknowledged that leave is granted for her to—
—No, it is a point which is preliminary to that. I think it would be helpful—
—I take it as not necessarily preliminary at all, unless what you are going to say about Senator Cook's remarks qualifies your decision that leave be granted.
—Well, there are pages missing from the documents that are in front of us.
—With respect, Senator Giles asked for leave to incorporate in the Hansard those pages which she passed over.
—I ask again, while that is being sorted out, that I be given leave to make a brief statement.
—Very well, Senator Teague, as we do have an interruption, leave is granted.

—by leave—Pages are missing from the document. We had to act cautiously because only selected pages from the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette were presented to us within a minute of the end of Senator Giles's speech. Even then, my generosity led me to say that if Senator Giles insisted on seeking leave, it would be granted. Frankly, one of the reasons I conceded is that every single school on these five pages of lists, whether they are complete or incomplete, will get more money under the Fightback program of the Liberal and National parties. In fact, the level 12 schools will be given a greater increase in dollars per capita grant than will the level 1 schools. It is a greater increase for those in greater need than those in the lowest category of need.
—Senator Teague—
—So, it is for this reason—
—Order, Senator Teague!
—that these matters—
—Senator Teague!
—have been referred to in the Senate.
—With respect, sir, just one moment, please.
—`Senator'. I am not a sir.

—When I ask you to come to order, that is what this Chair means. I was going to draw your attention to the fact that your remarks are straying a fair way from the relevance of the matter raised by Senator Cook, on which you asked for leave to speak.
—I was making a brief statement.
—I am not going to argue with you. Could you wait until the Chair has finished speaking, thank you, Senator.

—Well, I had waited until you had finished, Madam Acting Deputy President. I sought leave of the Senate to make a brief statement on the matter that is before this chamber and I made a brief statement. I will not be compromised by any remarks that are made when the Senate has given me leave to make a brief statement. On full consideration of this matter, I believe that a different course of action would have been taken by a Labor senator had all of these facts been known to that senator. I now leave it entirely to Senator Giles to decide whether she wishes to continue with her original request for all of the pages to be incorporated in Hansard, or take the better path of tabling the pages so that they are available in the way that she wishes.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Board of Employment, Education and Training--Employment and Skills Formation Council

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The report of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training and its Employment and Skills Formation Council touches upon a matter which honourable senators on this side of the chamber have been concerned about for a long time. The present Government has set up a National Board of Employment, Education and Training for which it has not given sufficient authority, sufficient independence or sufficient resources. It is no wonder that when we get a document such as this tabled in the Parliament we are inadequately informed, because the National Board of Employment, Education and Training has been placed in the pocket of this centralist Labor Government.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition wishes to move towards the abolition of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training and bring back a genuinely independent Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission which will be able, with proper resources and with proper access to the whole education community in Australia, to bring independent advice to us when we are in government and not have this farce whereby the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, and his assistant, the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Mr Baldwin, have denied this country an independent coordinating voice of advice about education matters.

The National Board has four councils. The four councils are concerned with higher education, technical and further education and skills formation, schools, and research. These four councils have very important functions. We have a compromise of those very important functions because the Board to which they report and through which they gain their secretarial and other support has not been given the resources and independence that it deserves from the Labor Government. The way ahead will come about only with a change of government.

The Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, who represents Minister Dawkins, is in the chamber. I was very disappointed with the ill-prepared speech that he gave in the Senate on the matter of public importance this afternoon on education matters. Having heard Senator Bolkus, representing Minister Dawkins, I have got to the point where I am totally dispirited about any possible education reform from this Labor Government. With or without any advice from the National Board of Employment, Education and Training, the only way ahead is to see a change of government and to see the full education policies of the Fightback policy package of the Liberal and National parties implemented so that we might get the kind of reforms which will bring back international standards in education for Australia and public confidence in the education provisions of this country.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1990-91 report of the Bureau of Meteorology is the first self-contained annual report of the Bureau since 1973. Between 1974 and 1990 brief reports on Bureau activities were included in the annual reports of the departments of Science and Consumer Affairs, Science and Environment, Science and Technology, Administrative Services, et cetera. It is good to see that such an important area has a report of its own.

PARA.TAB: In the letter of transmittal in the report the Director of Meteorology, Mr Zillman, said:

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, the relocation of the Bureau to the ASETT Portfolio has established the foundation for close and effective interaction with the policy development process in respect of a range of meteorology-related environmental issues such as ozone depletion, the greenhouse effect and global environmental change.
He went on to talk about the achievements of its staff, saying:

The Bureau of Meteorology is notable for the high percentage of its staff who have spent most of their careers in the geographically dispersed, round-the-clock meteorological operations that underpin the provision of the nation's weather and climate services.

As a person who has been a farmer all his life, I believe that weather forecasting is very important to the people on the land. Flood forecasting is very important as well. The warnings that the Bureau gives at different times have been very helpful to all of us in the farming sectors, as well as to the shire councils and those who live in country areas—and not to forget the people who live in city areas. Although people who live in the city are more worried about whether the weekend will be fine and nice so that they can go to the beach or play their sport, the farmers in the country areas are sometimes hoping that it will rain like heck to help them with some of their crop.

PARA.TAB: In its goals, the Bureau says that it works towards the reduction of the social and economic impact of natural disasters. We have a natural disaster at the moment in Australia with the drought that is pervading some 60 per cent of New South Wales and causing untold heartbreak and hardship. It is quite interesting that the weather conditions from July 1990 to June 1991 have changed dramatically. We have had floods and droughts in different areas, we have had floods again and we have had more drought.

It is interesting that the Bureau makes note of the El Nino effect. I believe that if it is scientifically factual that the El Nino does have a big effect on our weather, there should be much more research done into it. The Bureau should be applying itself to getting early forewarning of the changes that it brings about. It should be noted that the Drought Policy Review Task Force, which was looking for a national drought policy, made mention in its report that priority should be given to research and the application of remote sensing and geographic information systems. It also said that the Bureau of Meteorology should refine its drought watch service as much as possible to specific geographic locations and that State agricultural extension and advisory services should publicise more widely the existence of this service and the number of private services available.

I notice that in its report the Bureau noted that it had put out descriptive articles about the broad scale controls of the Australian climate, including the El Nino southern oscillation phenomenon. These articles were prepared for rural newspapers and farmer-oriented magazines. I congratulate the Bureau on the work it is doing, but it has a lot more work to do to make sure that people in farming areas and people in different enterprises in Australia have earlier warning. That will require more research and more money for research in this very vital area. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The annual report of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal before us today was not able to be tabled until about an hour ago. I would like to bring one matter of importance in this document to the attention of the Senate. In her overview of the 1990-91 financial year, the national convener of the SSAT, Ms Anne Coghlan, was moved to state:

Unfortunately, the salary dollars allocated to the Tribunal were not sufficient to enable us to function satisfactorily and $53,000 had to be transferred from the administrative allocation. This arrangement might have solved the problem in the short term but in the long run is not a satisfactory way to operate. The Tribunal should be given an allocation to allow it to function effectively and properly.

This appears to me to be a situation which should not be allowed to continue. If administrative money is being shifted to salaries, then the issue ought to be addressed as to whether the Tribunal has sufficient money for salaries or whether other measures ought to be taken to redress this situation.

PARA.TAB: As at 30 June 1991, the Social Security Appeals Tribunal employed 61 full time personnel, including 39 support staff. Twenty-six of these staff were paid at the ASO6 level or above, with an actual average salary of $32,822—considerably higher than the allocated average salary of $30,852. As is stated in the annual report, this shortfall meant that the SSAT was unable to utilise its average staffing level of 59.

Despite the fact that the number of applications for review lodged at the SSAT increased by 10 per cent—or 685—over the previous financial year to a total of 7,334, the Tribunal received no increase in staff resources over that allocated for the previous year. The staffing situation at the SSAT had become so tight that it is claimed on page 14 of the annual report that without the $53,000 transfer—to which I referred earlier—from the administrative allocation to salaries and without the use of private agency word processing operators in a number of offices, the Tribunal would not have been able to prepare its decisions in a timely manner.

The objectives of the SSAT should not be forgotten. Its first objective is to provide a mechanism of review that is fair, just, economical, informal and quick. The SSAT needs to be congratulated for the fact that, despite its staffing allocation problems, it has been able to reduce the average processing time from lodgment to completion from 14.6 weeks in 1989-90 to 10.5 weeks in 1990-91. Similarly, the average length of time for giving written reasons for SSAT decisions dropped from 18.7 days to 10.4 days during the 1990-91 financial year. Finally, the statutory 14 days time limit for the notification of decisions was met in 77.1 per cent of cases, an increase from 57 per cent in 1989-90. We can see that there have been some efficiency improvements, even without increased staff resources.

The staffing allocation shortfall is particularly concerning when one recognises the major reforms which are being undertaken in the social security system this financial year. I will outline those briefly. For the first time, the Social Security Appeals Tribunal will be reviewing decisions made by the Commonwealth Employment Service. The new plain English social security legislation came into operation on 1 July 1991 and the Tribunal will be the first external body to look closely at, and apply, this new legislation. On 12 November 1991, the disability reform package commenced operation. Invalid pensions and sickness benefits—now the disability support pension and the sickness allowance—have always represented a large proportion of the appeals heard by the Tribunal. Again, the inception of new and radically different legislation will present quite a challenge to the SSAT in the 1991-92 financial year.

Given the concerns that have been expressed in the report and given these additional legislative changes and their implications, I call on the Government to address those concerns. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to speak briefly on the annual report of the Australia-Indonesia Institute. It is very important that we note the good work that has been done by the Australia-Indonesia Institute in its last year of operations. As very close neighbours and good friends of the Indonesian people, it is necessary that we do all in our power to extend the close relationships that exist between the Indonesian people and the Australian people. The unfortunate happenings in East Timor of recent weeks should not be allowed to interfere with the generally very good relationships we have with the Indonesian people and the Indonesian institutions.

PARA.TAB: The Institute was established by the Australian Government to foster people-to-people contacts, visits and exchanges between the two countries; to promote all forms of contact in the media, performing and visual arts, the professions, science and technology, business and trade, sport and youth; to promote the Indonesian language and cultural studies in Australia; and to promote the Australian culture and English language studies in Indonesia. Part of the work of the Institute is to create those contacts in all fields, including the media.

The Australian media have had an unhappy relationship with Indonesia over a period of time and it is good that an attempt is being made to make contact between the Australian media and the Indonesian media much closer. I was fortunate to be on a parliamentary delegation to Indonesia earlier this year. Coincidentally, at the same time a young reporter from the Cairns Post was also going to Indonesia to investigate the Indonesian society and way of life. I was a bit disappointed that the leader of the delegation, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, would not permit that young reporter from the Cairns Post to make contact with the delegation whilst we were in Indonesia. I thought it was a rather mean decision by the delegation not to permit that.

Nevertheless, the delegation went ahead. We made very close contacts with the Indonesians generally and that reporter also extended his knowledge of Indonesian affairs as a result of the visit. I am not sure from the report—which we have only just received, and it is very difficult to go through it in the limited time available—whether that reporter was given assistance by the Australia-Indonesia Institute. I thought he was, but certainly if he was not there under that program, he was there under some other program. In the long term, it can only help to extend the relationships between the two countries.

Part of the Institute's function is to extend cultural ties. I was privileged only a week ago last Friday to be part of a magnificent display of Indonesian culture hosted by Garuda International at a dinner in Cairns celebrating the inaugural visit to Cairns by the airline. I was rather disappointed to find that not one person from the Cairns City Council could make the effort to be at that function. Apparently, the acting deputy chairman of the Council was supposed to be at the meeting, but at the last minute had trouble with planes. No-one representing the Cairns community, as such, was there to receive the warmth of the Indonesians at the opening of that airline. It was a very good function and it certainly helped to foster understanding and cement relations between the ordinary people of Australia and the ordinary people of Indonesia.

The cultural magnificence which we were treated to at that function is just one of the things which this Institute promotes. I think the Institute will go a long way towards helping the relationships between Australia and Indonesia—something we must make an extra effort to do in these difficult times. That is an important role for the Institute to play.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in speaking to the Australia-Indonesia Institute's annual report because I think it is a very important activity for Australia to be involved in. As Senator Macdonald said, the Institute was established in 1989 to foster people-to-people contacts and visits and exchanges between the two countries in a variety of fields, such as the media, the performing and visual arts, the professions, science and technology, business, trades, sport and youth. It is those people-to-people contacts that are fundamental to building a better understanding between Australia and Indonesia.

PARA.TAB: Sadly, in this country—and I believe the reciprocal situation applies in Indonesia—there is a very poor level of understanding of what the other country is about. It is true that there are many differences. I am tempted to say that there are more differences between Indonesia and Australia than between any other two countries in the world that live alongside each other. There is a distance of about 500 miles from Australia to the nearest Indonesian territory—less than that if we consider West Irian.

The differences between Australia and Indonesia are enormous: for example, the great ethnic difference. The number of different ethnic groups within Indonesia runs into many hundreds or even thousands. There are enormous cultural differences with a range of Asian cultures, and many different religions. The Moslem religion is the predominant religion, but there is a large Christian community as well as all sorts of animists, Buddhists and other Asian religions.

One of the biggest differences that become apparent to the Australian people is with respect to administration. As a consequence of the revolution, when the Indonesian people displaced the Dutch colonial administration, Indonesia has relied very strongly on a military administration of the country, with the armed services, principally the Army, fulfilling the role that in Australia is fulfilled by a civilian Public Service. That leads to difficulties. I am sure that the difficulties in East Timor at present are partly because there is not a regular police force and a civilian public service administering the region. There are these difficulties in our paths, but we are committed and destined to live as neighbours and it is important that we break down the barriers between us. One of the best ways of breaking down those barriers is to invite Indonesians to visit Australia and for Australians to go to Indonesia to see the differences in each country in order to build understanding.

It is very important for Indonesians to visit Australia to build understanding, particularly in the education field. Australia can offer to Indonesians higher degree training at the tertiary level. I think we ought to be making as much effort as we can to make those courses attractive to Indonesians, because people who go to school or university in another country nearly always retain not only a degree of understanding of that country but also a degree of sympathy for it and its values. Given the problems we have had in the international arena, there is a very real case for improving that understanding between the two countries. I have much pleasure in supporting the annual report of the Australia-Indonesia Institute.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

Classifying films, videos and literature must be a very difficult task for the people involved, because what might be one person's cup of tea or fantasy may be another person's dislike. The report, in its preamble, sets out these general principles applying to the guidelines:

Adults should be free to see what they wish provided there is sufficient protection for young people. . . The classification should reflect what a reasonable adult person would consider within the acceptable limits of community standards for that age group. . . The closest attention is paid to the portrayal of violence and, in particular, sexual violence. . . Certain classes of activity, such as child sexual abuse. . .

I note that Senator Harradine will be speaking to this report. Being a member of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material, which dealt with videos and explicit material, he has had a lot more experience in this area than I have.

PARA.TAB: The report shows that, of the videos for sale or hire that were studied, 17 per cent were X-rated and, of those, 68 were refused. I think that shows that the literature Board is doing its job reasonably well. Whilst the Film and Literature Classification Board of Review may be doing a great job as watchdog for what is peddled in our community, I am very concerned that the Federal Government, through the Australian Film Finance Corporation and the ABC, saw fit to spend $270,000 of taxpayers' money on partly making an R-rated sex film called Sacred Sex, which has received a fair amount of publicity around the community. I am not here to say whether that should have had an R classification or an X classification, or that it should not be shown in Australia, but I do question that $270,000 of taxpayers' money has been put into this production.

The film includes graphic pornographic scenes, sex workshops and orgies and studies none other than the infamous—now famous—sex star from America, Annie Sprinkle. A review of this film which appeared in the Weekend Australian of 23 to 24 November—I do not intend to go into all the lurid details of the review—said in its final paragraph:

SPEECH.PARA: What our own ABC and the excellent Film Finance Corporation thought they were doing when they aided this production—none of which, apparently, was filmed in this country—is beyond me.

It is certainly beyond me. I am disgusted, as are many people around Australia. In fact, I presented a petition here the other day on behalf of Southern Cross Homes in New South Wales, which obviously is aware of the situation. It was signed by some 170 people who are concerned that the Government, through the ABC and the Film Finance Corporation, saw fit to do what it did. I have written to both the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) and the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley). I did receive from the Film and Finance Corporation a press release, which in part said:
It's the FFC's standard practice. We have no input into the content of the program.

It is saying that it is giving a blank cheque to anyone it sees fit to promote or produce films that—in my opinion and probably the opinion of many honourable senators in this chamber on both sides of the House—are very offensive and an absolute waste of taxpayers' money. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present the report of the Committee on the Australian Defence Force Reserves, together with the minutes of proceedings and transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present the Report of the Committee entitled The Australian Defence Force Reserves.

On 17 March 1989 the Minister for Defence referred for inquiry the issue of the structure and capabilities of ADF Reserves. The inquiry attracted a great deal of interest from ADF personnel, defence academics and the general public. By the dissolution of the 35th Parliament in February 1990 more than 120 submissions had been received and four public hearings held.

The Terms of Reference were re-referred to the Committee on 13 June 1990 following its re-appointment in the 36th Parliament. The Auditor-General's Report on the Army Reserve was added later through referral by the House of Representatives.

During this present Parliament the Committee received a further 130 submissions, totalling some 2,500 pages, and conducted nine public hearings, amassing over 1500 pages of oral evidence. We also travelled extensively to Service establishments around Australia to inspect facilities and discuss issues of concern with both Reserve and Regular members of the ADF.

Several major events affected this inquiry—for example, the pilots' strike during the second half of 1989 and the Federal election early in 1990. A further factor was the Force Structure Review undertaken in 1990 and early 1991. The Committee decided to delay the finalisation of its proceedings to take account of the Review's outcome.

Following the tabling of the Force Structure Review by the Minister for Defence on 30 May 1991, the Committee sought further submissions and held a final public hearing at Canberra on 26 July 1991 to allow for comment on the impact of the Force Structure Review on ADF Reserves.

This has been a protracted and complex inquiry. Indeed, Mr President, this inquiry has been a mammoth task, involving hundreds of hours of work by the Members of the Committee and the Secretariat. At this point, I would like to acknowledge formally the efforts of my fellow Committee Members and Committee staff.

Turning to the Committee's assessment of the effectiveness and efficiency of ADF Reserve forces—Naval Reserves contribute only indirectly to readiness. However, the Committee found that Naval Reserves were performing their current roles effectively and that the estimated annual cost of some $17 million was being applied efficiently.

Notwithstanding the more than 20 years and $100 million spent in its development, an operational ADF mine countermeasures capability is still at least many years off. That is bad enough. The Force Structure Review, however, reversed a longstanding policy of employing auxiliary minesweepers manned largely by Reserves to complement the minehunting capability.

Army Reserves make a major and direct contribution to ADF readiness. The operational roles concerned relate mainly to surveillance, protection and logistics. The Committee found that Army Reserves provide marginally effective surveillance, ineffective vital asset protection, and an ineffective level of logistic support.

The broad costs of the ARes include equipment worth some $268m with planned near-term acquisitions of about $100m; facilities worth at least $130m; and recurrent funding of half a billion dollars a year.
The Committee has no doubt that the military capability being generated currently by the Army Reserve is grossly inefficient.

Ready Reserves will be introduced at the expense of one of Army's only three Regular brigades—and essentially without any rigorous consideration of 26,000 General Reservists. The Force Structure Review has reduced the Reservists to `third XI status'.

Of a total of 35,000 personnel in Army's combat forces, some 6,000 Regular and 11,500 General Reserves are allocated to other than priority roles established by Defence policy. In force structure terms, this equates to seven infantry battalions, or about 30 per cent of all such units in the total Army. Of these, some 40 per cent require 90 days or longer to become operationally ready and some 13 per cent require in the order of a year to do so.

The lack of Army Reserve operational readiness is the weak link in the concept of defence-in-depth. ADF ground forces are manifestly unable to secure the bases required for deployed maritime forces. I stress, this is not a reflection on the energy or dedication of Reservists themselves but reflects major deficiencies in Reserve policy development, equipment and training.
Air Force Reservists contribute only indirectly to the performance of many operational roles at an estimated annual cost of some $12m. This is cost effective.

The RAAF's most serious operational weaknesses are its low aircraft-to-aircrew ratio and the relatively few technical and other personnel to support operations at forward deployment airfields. The Air Force plan to introduce Reserves as Airfield Defence Guards is sound and will now be enabled by the Ready Reserve Program.

However, no serious attempt has been made to extend RAAF operational effectiveness by widening the application of integrated Regular/Reserve force elements. We believe that Air Force should introduce an integrated structure in at least five or six operational squadrons employing a mixture of Reserve and Permanent air and ground personnel.

The Committee came to the firm conclusion that a corporate planning approach is the only way that Reserve force development will be achieved comprehensively and effectively, and recommends that the Department of Defence develop a Corporate Plan for the Development of ADF Reserve Forces.

That plan should address, among other things: the introduction of an MCM operational minesweeping capability into the Naval Reserve at an equipment cost in the order of $20m, to be offset against the planned replacement of five Reserve patrol boats by Fleet Support Vessels; the restructure of Army's Manoeuvre and Follow On Forces so that the available Regular and Reserve force structure can be applied to priority capability requirements; and the introduction into Air Force of integrated operational squadrons.

The Committee recommends that additional resources be programmed as follows: an estimated $100m for each of the seven General Reserve infantry brigades to equip them fully; in the order of $2m in the short term rising to $50m a year after 10 years for Army General Reserve operating costs; and an estimated total $50m over ten years to acquire unit equipment for the three Reserve Airfield Defence Guard squadrons.

The Committee concluded that the Auditor General's Report on the Army Reserve is a very valuable document both in its own right and for the impetus and guidance provided to the processes of calculating and attributing the costs of ADF activities.
The past record of policy development and implementation for Reserves has been anything but satisfactory. Transparency and regular review should be features of the long-term implementation process.

The Committee recommends, therefore, that the Department of Defence publish a Reserves Corporate Plan by the end of 1992, and thereafter report annually to the Parliament on the extent to which key milestones have been met.

In conclusion, the way ahead for Reserves must accommodate uncertain strategic circumstances, severe financial constraints and even increased attention to the structural concerns of productivity, effectiveness and efficiency. However, the Committee considers that the planning environment over the next ten years or so does not present the major problem facing ADF Reserve forces. As this Report so clearly shows, the central challenge is to redress the failure of the force development process to adjust the military capability of Reserves in response to evolving Australian strategic thinking and the Government's defence policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The origins of the Australian defence forces are firmly based in a reserve structure. The great efforts of two world wars were principally mounted by citizen soldiers in all three Services. But with the passing of time there have been changes in global politics which have led to changes within the Australian Defence Force structure. There also has been a move within Australia across a range of governments towards more self-reliance in the Australian defence forces.

PARA.TAB: Self-reliance is the goal we are all working for. In reality, it can never be obtained in absolute terms. But, again, it has affected the way the defence forces are put together. These factors over a period of time have led to the development of a professional, full time Defence Force for Australia, supported by reserve forces. Admittedly, the professional numbers are small and for the future we will have to maintain our principal defence capability in the hands of permanent, professional, full time forces. We also need to supplement those forces in whatever ways we can with part time reserve forces. In one sense the historical role has been reversed. We now have the principal role being played by professionals, whereas up to the end of the Second World War the principal role in Australia's defence was provided by civilian forces.

The report presented today has been very long in preparation. I have been advised that it has been the longest time ever taken to present a report from a committee. I do not know whether that is literally true, but it certainly took far longer than anyone on the Committee wanted to take. We had some circumstances operating that were beyond our control. In the very first instance, we had the great airline strike at the end of 1989 which interfered for a period of about four months in the activities of the Committee because we could not hold public hearings, we could not get witnesses to us and we could not get out to see witnesses.

Shortly after that, in the early part of 1990, we had a general election in this country and the Parliament did not re-form until after June. It was quite a while before the Committee could get re-established and work on the report. Then we had a report from the Department of Defence, the Force Structure Review Committee, which in one sense pre-empted the findings of this Committee by bringing down a force structure review in March of this year. The Committee decided it was timely to look at the proposals of the Department of Defence because they were entirely within the ambit of the Committee. All of those things led to a very long period of gestation for this report.

I should like to thank the Chairman, Mr Lindsay from the other place, for his chairing of the Committee. There were the difficulties that I have outlined, and his chairing was excellent. He persistently maintained the direction of the Committee to prosecute its inquiry.

I should like to thank my fellow members of the Committee, the senators and members who formed the Defence Subcommittee, and note for the record that it was a unanimous report. Most reports of the Defence Subcommittee over the years have been unanimous. We have never had any substantial dissent in a report.

I can think back to 1983, to one report which one or two members put a qualifying sentence in, but basically we try to put party positions behind us and be led by the evidence that is given to an inquiry. That has led to a series of what I believe have been excellent reports over the years from the Committee. We have been able to reach common ground on what we present to the Parliament. That inevitably involves a little bit of personal compromise in that we cannot follow our own individual hobbyhorses, but the essential points, as we see them, are met.

The report proposes a series of constructive and even radical proposals. It is a very coherent document. It is tightly reasoned intellectually right through. We do not pretend for one moment that it is the final answer to the needs of the Defence Force reserves because that is a continuum; it is moving the whole time. As circumstances change, so the defence forces will evolve. But we do believe that our recommendations will correct some of the great deficiencies in capability in the Defence Force. We would welcome the Government implementing those recommendations because we believe that the nation would benefit from them.

It is always difficult in looking at defence to look at one section of it. We were restricted to looking at the reserves in all three services. But to look at the reserves and to change the way they are organised inevitably has some influence on the regular forces. We would have liked to make some changes in the regular forces, but that was denied us by reasons of our remit.

The report is written to The Defence of Australia 1987, which is the policy document governing the structure and capabilities of the Australian Defence Force. It was modified in 1990 by ASP90, Australia's Strategic Planning in the 1990s. Our requirement was to write to those documents. I happen to think DOA87 and ASP90 are now very dated documents of limited or no relevance at all to Australia's defence needs, but the important point is that they were our riding instructions for this report.

I do not think that that was a disability for us for the reason that the recommendations we made will lead to improvements in the capabilities of the Australian Defence Force, and those improvements in capabilities will be useful—indeed, probably vital—in a whole range of different circumstances. The restriction, at the end of the day, of writing to DOA87 was not a real restraint upon us. I will quote from the terms of inquiry in the opening part of the report. We were required to report on:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Reserves' structure and capabilities (including manning and equipment) with respect to the priority tasks set out in DOA87. . .
That was our principal brief.

PARA.TAB: I would like to look at the findings of the Committee as to the current conditions and capabilities in the reserve forces. I will do this very briefly because I do not intend to take much of the time of the Senate tonight. The Committee looked at the Reserve for the Royal Australian Navy. It is a relatively small component of the Navy. The Navy has about 14,000 personnel in the way of permanent members and the RAN Reserve numbers about 1,500. We thought the RAN Reserve was reasonably efficiently organised and doing a worthwhile job. Similarly, the Air Force has around 20,000 to 21,000 personnel, again with a small Reserve component of about 1,500 personnel. We thought the Air Force Reserve was quite efficiently organised and we had no complaint with that.

Most of our time was spent on a consideration of the ARes, the Army Reserve. The Army Reserve is a big force. It has 25,000 personnel. Of that 25,000 personnel, 5,000 are involved in training command and about 1,500 in logistics. The Army Reserve provides something like 60 per cent of the combat forces of the Australian Army. It provides a considerable part of logistic support for the Regular Army, as well as providing logistic support for its own operations.

The Committee found that the capability of the Army Reserve was not what it might have been. I regret that some press reports at the weekend have been a little extravagant, a little flamboyant, and they could well lead people in the reserves to think that we were unjust in our criticism. We were pointing out that the military capability, that is, the ability to use the Reserve in the short term and in accordance with the guidelines for readiness set by the Government, is very low. We are not critical at all of the quality of the people in the Reserve.

As an ex-reservist myself, and as someone who has relatives and countless friends in the reserves, I have an unbounded admiration for the dedication that reservists give to the Army; for the huge amount of time, particularly as they go up the ladder, that they put into it; and for the sacrifices they make in their family lives and, often, in their careers because, if they are serious about the Reserve, it is very hard to develop a civilian career as the Reserve makes such inroads into their time and resources.

At the end of the day the reserves are not as efficient as they might be, simply because the Government has failed to come up with a corporate plan. It has failed to provide the resources so that the Army Reserve can operate at the level that the Government requires of it. That leads me to the heart of our report.

We are saying in this report that in DOA87 and in ASP90—the two policy documents which define the duties and the responsibilities of the Australian Defence Force—the Government says, `Look, we want the defence forces to be able to do this, this and this, and we want them to do it at certain times'. That is fine. We accept that. But the Government has not given the various branches of the Services—particularly the reserves—the resources they need to carry it out. The reserves are short of money and desperately short of equipment. Reserves cannot train if they do not have equipment and, what is more, they cannot fulfil their roles. There are readiness times of 28 days, 90 days, 180 days and up to 360 days for some of the units. Equipment cannot be got to them in that time so they simply cannot fulfil the obligations put upon them by the Government in its policy directives.

Nor has the Government—and in one sense this is an even bigger sin—altered the force structure and arranged the disposition of personnel within the reserves to fulfil the role, particularly in the case of the Army, that the Government wants them to perform. Our recommendations certainly involve a recommendation that the Government spend money, principally to rectify the equipment defects from which the reserves are suffering.

We have made a realistic estimate in the light of good information as to what we think will be needed to bring the reserves to an adequate level. We make the point that something like half a billion dollars a year, over $500m, is invested in the reserves at the present time and we are getting very little from it. The point to be made is that we only need to go a little bit further to reap a very much greater capability from the reserves. We have been forced to request that as additional funding in our report. We were required, in one of the latter parts of our instructions, to comment on the financial implications of what we were proposing but we were not allowed to go into restructuring the whole of the ADF.

We would have liked to go into the whole of the defence forces and, particularly, to have cleaned out the huge administrative overheads, particularly in Canberra where, by my estimate, we have something like 132 generals—that is, one-star, two-star, three-star and four-star generals—in all three services. It is a structure of comic opera proportions. Every one of those generals has a huge staff. If we could clean that out we could save billions of dollars in the operation of defence and put that money into more effective roles. That was denied us. We were not allowed to go that way.

In the early part of my speech I mentioned that one of the reasons for delay was the fact that the Government brought on a Force Structure Review Committee to look at the very things this Committee was looking at. That Committee reported in March this year. It pre-empted the findings of this Committee. It would have been correct for the Government to have held off appointing that Committee until it had received this report. Had that happened, the Government would have got this report six months earlier.

The report of the Force Structure Review Committee, with the passing of time, stands increasingly exposed as being very shallow, very superficial and lacking any intellectual content at all. When attending functions in Canberra, it is very interesting to talk with uniformed and civilian members of the Department of Defence and to observe the derision that now is heaped upon the Force Structure Review by people in defence. It simply has no status at all. Without being unkind to the Force Structure Review Committee, it brought an attitude of mind to it that, since all the members were Army members and had worn uniforms all their lives, they knew all about the reserves and did not need to look at what they were proposing in the way of force structure review.

I will give the Senate briefly two examples of that. One of the most important Reserve exercises in Australia in the Army has been the integration exercise in 6 Brigade in Queensland where Reserve units have been integrated with Regular units. This was recommended by the Millar inquiry in the 1970s. It took Defence, with its lightning speed, over 10 years to implement it. Initially, when it was trialled in 6 Brigade, there were certainly problems, but those problems have been worked through and overcome. I have no hesitation in saying that 6 Brigade today is a brilliant example of integration. Having built up to that point, the Force Structure Review Committee recommended that it be disbanded and thrown out.

The Review Committee was entitled to that point of view, but it was not entitled to come to that decision without having the courtesy even to go and talk to the officers and the men and women of 6 Brigade to find out how it was working. There are two regular battalions in 6 Brigade—6 Battalion RAR and 8/9 Battalion RAR—linked with a third battalion in the brigade, that being 49 RQR, a reserve infantry battalion. So there is integration at that level.

In a different sense there is integration within units. The regular artillery unit has a reserve battery. One of the cavalry units, 2/14 QMI, is a reserve unit integrated into the mainly regular cavalry unit. The brigade has been integrated in two ways. This has worked out brilliantly, with the reservists learning a great deal and reaching a much higher standard of military competence through mixing with the regulars, and the regulars learning something from the enthusiasm and the different attitudes of the reservists. But, no, the members of the Force Structure Review Committee knew it all. They did not even go and have a look to see what they were destroying before they destroyed it.

I will give another example of how the Review Committee knew everything. I was talking to what I regard as one of the brightest and best infantry officers in the Reserve in Queensland—a lieutenant who, at the time, had been in the Reserve for seven years. I was talking to this chap and asked, `How long is it since you have been involved in any live firing exercises with mortars?'. He said, `I have never seen or heard a mortar fired'. Mortars are a standard infantry weapon, a standard tool of trade that is as basic as a rifle, yet here was an infantry officer who had never seen a mortar fired.

When I brought this up in a committee hearing as an example of a lack of resources for the Reserve, the senior officer on the Force Structure Review Committee told me—and it is all in Hansard—that really that Reserve officer must have been far less than conscientious and must have been quite incapable and inadequate in his Reserve duties to have never had that experience. A fact of life is that people do not pick their own actions or chart and develop their own careers in the Services; that is done for them by a higher authority. The point I am making in this case is that resources have been so constrained and restricted for the reserves that many of them have never even had the basics of military life. More importantly, the Force Structure Review Committee never knew that. It never knew the reality of life in the reserves.

The Force Structure Review Committee recommended that we move to something called the Ready Reserve. That gets a whole chapter in the report, and I do not propose to go through it. However, we did comment that we thought too high a price was paid in the abolition of two regular battalions and in the loss of a fine brigade in 6 Brigade. We commented that it makes the Army Reserve of even lower priority than the abysmally low priority it has enjoyed up to the present and that it makes it even more a third eleven.

One point that the Committee briefly referred to was the way that the changes cut out the university regiments. The Force Structure Review Committee recommended that the university regiments be reduced to officer training units. That might seem fine to the unthinking and the uninformed mind; but, while some of the university regiments in Australia have not operated very efficiently, they have a very important role in putting the Australian defence forces before the tertiary student body of this country.

Many students join the university regiments not with any intention of being generals, officers or anything like that; they just want the adventure and experience of military training. They are quite happy to be privates—sappers—and bombardiers, to serve in a unit for the years they are at university. They get a favourable impression of the defence forces and it is marvellous PR for the defence community. Reducing the university regiments to OCTUs means that they will shrink to about a fifth of their present size and that they will a have very little discernible place on the campus.

Before I touch briefly on the recommendations of the Committee, let me say that one of the generalisations of our recommendations can be encapsulated in a belief in the need for a lot more flexibility in the terms of Reserve service. In the Army, for example, service is restricted to 100 days in any 12 months. We see no reason for that. We propose a range of duty periods for Reserve service and we see no reason why someone cannot serve as a reservist for up to 200 days a year. The importance of that 200-day figure lies in the fact that it is recognised that the effective time of service for a permanent service man or woman is about 220 days a year. We think that there is no reason why reservists cannot become `career reservists' provided they are prepared to take the reduction in income that comes from that and serve for up to 200 days a year. That will give the country great benefits in all three services.

The Committee also recommended that there be improvements in the conditions of service. We found that one of the faults of the Ready Reserve scheme was that the Government was very lavish with the terms and conditions it offered to buy recruits. For example, we do not see why there should not be some sort of superannuation scheme for the existing reservists.
I would now like to move briefly through the recommendations of the Committee. The very first paragraph of the final chapter states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee received an abundance of evidence to show that, over the past 20 years or so, there have been many sound ideas about how the performance and conditions of ADF Reserves could be improved. No attempt has been made by Defence to implement those initiatives in a sustained and cohesive way. Fragmented policies, inadequate priority for the resources available and lack of commitment have been the hallmarks of Reserve development. The Committee is thoroughly convinced that a corporate planning approach must be adopted if ADF Reserve forces are to become an effective and efficient total force component. This is the overriding conclusion of this inquiry.

We recommended that the Navy should develop a minesweeping capability for its reservists, which was always part of the Navy plan but was axed in the recent past without any justification. We believe that mine countermeasures are very inadequately dealt with by this country and that the minesweeping function, with simple minesweepers, is a role that is well within the capabilities of reserves. We recommend that there be eight coastal minesweepers in port divisions around Australia.

PARA.TAB: With respect to the Army, we recommend that if 6 Brigade does not meet the standards that are required through the Ready Reserve program, it be disbanded and reformed as a Regular brigade. One of the objectives for the Ready Reserve program that the Force Structure Review Committee proposed was that it would improve the readiness and capability of the Australian defence forces. Of course, the scheme that was put in place does not do anything like that. The level of readiness is still precisely the same; it is still 90 days as presently exists for 6 Brigade. So we have no increase in readiness. Capability is decreased because we are going to Reserve soldiers instead of regulars.

While discussing the changes to the reservists, let me say that one of our central aims is to reduce readiness times to realistic levels. We do not believe that it is realistic to have Reserve units on 360-day readiness. We can take people straight off the street and train them up as we did for Vietnam and commit them to high intensity land warfare within a 12-month training period. So there is no point in running a Reserve program if a number of units—as the Army presently has—are ready at one year's notice. We want to get readiness times down to about 28 days or maybe 90 days at the very most. Our proposals are based on that. If the units are equipped and trained to that degree of readiness, they can reach a higher level of training in the field when they are deployed at short notice.

The Committee came up with quite a radical proposal for the Royal Australian Air Force, recommending that it introduce reserve flying air crew. For some reason that I have never been able to understand, the RAAF has never accepted the place of reservists as air crew in any effective way. There has been a tradition that pilots who leave the Air Force will never return to again fly as pilots in command of any high performance aircraft. They can get jobs as operations officers in a Reserve squadron on the ground, but they cannot fly.

We have come up with a way that is quite unashamedly based on the American reserve system of running six or eight reserve squadrons across the spectrum. We think that it could be applied to cover the transport field—the C130s and Caribous—and certainly the F18s, and possibly the F111s if we had enough F111 aircrew. We could build squadrons with a cadre of permanent Royal Australian Air Force commanding officers, one or two flight commanders, and the rest could be made up of reservists on two levels of service—the 200-day per year pilots and the 40-day per year pilots.

While we accept a slight diminution in readiness of those squadrons from an operational point of view, we believe that they could be brought up to speed, to an operational readiness standard, within a matter of weeks. We estimate the savings from that will run into many of hundreds of millions of dollars each year. There are great savings in that. The reason for doing that is not so much to save money but because the Air Force does not have enough pilots. The great difficulty the RAAF has suffered in recent years has been in having more aircraft than experienced pilots.

The rule of thumb is that about 2 1/2 to three pilots or crew are needed for aircraft such as the F111s, F18s and the P3s on maritime patrols. In the case of the P3s, for example, where there are 10 aircraft in a squadron, there have never been more than seven trained air crew at any one time in a squadron. To meet any surge and to be able to sustain that surge in a defence emergency is quite beyond us. The real importance of what we are proposing with the RAAF restructuring is that it gets the surge capacity from the reservists.

In conclusion, if I could be so bold as to forecast the Government's response, my anticipation is that the Government will meet this report with absolute silence. I do not think that it will even damn it with faint praise. But, like a good wine, it will live on and get better year by year and more and more intelligent people will read it and put pressure on the Government to lift the capabilities of the Australian defence forces to the level that the Australian public deserve and, given the money that we put into it, we really should have. I commend the report to the Senate and to the public.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the twentieth anniversary of the Committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Acting Deputy President, I take this opportunity of thanking the various honourable senators who have served on this Committee over the years. I note that there are some very famous names amongst them. There have been some very dedicated, brilliant secretaries. The ones with whom I had most to do were Dr Gibb, who has gone to private practice; Bronwyn McNaughton, whom I think you, Madam Acting Deputy President, would agree served this Committee with great distinction and great praise; and our present secretary, Mr Frank Tallarita. I also thank the present members of the Committee: Senator Kemp, Senator Giles, Senator O'Chee, Senator Schacht, Senator Spindler and Senator Walsh. Madam Acting Deputy President, I conclude my remarks by thanking you most sincerely for the way in which you have so ably joined with me in making this what I consider to be a very good Committee. I seek leave to incorporate the text of the tabling statement in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: TABLING STATEMENT

On the evening of 11 June 1970 the Australian Senate passed an historic resolution to establish seven Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committees and five Estimates Committees. That decision has been described as having `revolutionised the Parliament as a whole' and has had far reaching effects on the Australian system of parliamentary government changing the nature of much parliamentary activity and affecting the way in which executive government carries out its business.

The Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee (renamed the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee), one of the seven Committees originally proposed by Senator Lionel Murphy, was formally established on 6 October 1971. In those 20 years, focusing as it does on questions of a legal and constitutional nature, the Committee's work has ranged widely over many areas.

To a large extent, the Committee's concerns have reflected concerns in the wider community. Important instances of this include the Committee's inquiry into family law and the Family Law Bill, its work on the legal status of children conceived through in vitro fertilisation (IVF), and more recently its inquiry into the cost of legal services and litigation. This inquiry has become known as the `cost of justice inquiry'. The Committee has spent a great deal of its time canvassing issues at public hearings, and sifting through more than 250 written submissions and has released several discussion papers.

Despite the tendency to conduct more wide ranging inquiries in recent times, the Committee has also been required to examine legislative proposals such as the Privacy Bill 1986, and the feasibility of a national ID scheme.

Perhaps the major example of a long and detailed examination of legislation by the Committee has been its involvement with the freedom of information proposals and subsequently, legislation. The Committee canvassed the development of the awareness of FOI, examined the philosophical foundation of the concept of FOI and considered the implications of FOI legislation for a Westminster style of government.

It seems that Committee members are busier than perhaps ever before. There are today more ministers in the Senate than at any other time, leaving fewer backbenchers for appointment to committees. At the same time, the number of committees continues to increase.

One trend which has emerged in recent times and which is bound to affect the future work of the Committee is the referral of bills to committees. In the 1990s the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee has taken on this extra workload with no accompanying diminution in its general workload of longer term inquiries, but rather the opposite. A major reason for the Committee's success has been the support and dedication it has received from past and present secretaries and secretariat staff.

The Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee has responded to the concerns of the time. In doing so it has demonstrated its versatility and flexibility. Simultaneously it has brought to bear an expertise, narrowly based in the law, yet broadly based in terms of other experience on matters of the day.
The Committee is arguably the Senate's most active standing committee and enjoys the enthusiastic support of its members and looks forward to continuing the work done so ably by its past members.
I commend the report to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

Omit paragraph (3), substitute:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Tuesday, 3 and 10 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: (i)Petitions

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of the amendments is to delete from the Government's motion the desire of the Government to meet for the fourth week and to provide for the Senate to sit on the two Tuesday mornings in weeks 2 and 3.

PARA.TAB: The reason we take this action at this time is that we have been working—with the Government, I think I can say, and the Australian Democrats—on a program that has been monitored on a weekly basis to enable the Senate to dispose of the essential workload of the Government by 13 December. We have sat long hours to achieve that aim. On many nights we have sat until the early hours of the following morning. We have basically been able to maintain that program. Occasionally we might have fallen behind a Bill or two, but in no way have we fallen behind to the extent that it cannot be reasonably easily made up.

It therefore seems to us that at the moment there is no reason to justify a further week's sitting. The time will simply be filled up with work which is unnecessary at this time of the year. The Senate has set a program which will enable honourable senators to return to their electorates, to have a clear week in their electorates before Christmas, which seems to be commonsense. We would achieve something that the Senate has not been able to achieve in recent years. For the Government to undermine that program, and the long hours that honourable senators have sat to achieve that program, would be counterproductive.

What I have said is that we are happy to extend the sitting hours for the next two weeks to help maintain the schedule which has been set. Therefore, we agree to the two Tuesday mornings being added to the program as previously agreed, but we do not see any basis at this moment for agreeing to a further sitting of one week. We say to the Government, `Let us stick to the program for the next week or two'. I can assure Senator McMullan that we will keep to the undertakings we have previously given but, if the Government falls behind or for some other reason there is a problem, we will address the issue then without unnecessarily locking the Parliament into longer sitting times at this moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the Government is moving this motion to put an element of flexibility into the system. While I agree with Senator Hill that it is highly desirable to finish at the end of next week, and I certainly hope we can do that by suitably negating the adjournment on those occasions when the business is tending to drag, I understand from Senator McMullan that it is necessary to pass this provision at this time bearing in mind that if we do complete the business this motion could be amended later on. The House of Representatives will need to come back—
—They are coming before the 13th.
—The House of Representatives will need to come back when our legislation is completed.
—Why?

—The assumption is that if the House of Representatives does not come back none of the amendments we pass will be dealt with by the House, so there is not much point in our continuing in any case. If there is legislation which the Government is seeking to have completed this year it is necessary—if we are to have the right to amend that legislation—that the House of Representatives come back and deal with those amendments. I understand from private discussions with Senator McMullan that this is simply a way of setting a date, but that date could be brought back if we find that we do not need the time. I would certainly hope that we can rely on what Senator Hill, on behalf of the Opposition, has said and that every effort will be made to complete the sitting by the end of next week.

—I think the Government needs to give a much better explanation to the Senate as to why it is pursuing this particular course of action. We gave clear undertakings about the work we would complete by 13 December when we said that we would complete that legislation which is essential. It seems to me that some of the Bills before us that we have agreed to complete are not essential because, in any event, they do not need to come into effect before next February. Certainly the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill is one of those that need not.

PARA.TAB: We have sat four weeks out of five. If we conclude with the next two, as the Government is now insisting upon, the Senate will have sat for six weeks out of seven with the sort of hours that involves honourable senators getting up at 6 o'clock in the morning and leaving here very late. We did not rise until 1.50 last Friday morning and many then had to catch planes at 6.40 a.m. This sort of behaviour is not sensible any way one looks at it and it is certainly not in the best interests of honourable senators' health. One cannot help but wonder who will be the first person to collapse under this regime that the Government is insisting upon without in any way justifying it. We are not against sitting, but think of the number of days earlier in the year, both in this session and the autumn session, when the Senate virtually had nothing to do and was filling up time so as not to adjourn early.

We are now faced with a program such as this which is totally unjustified. We have sat late. We were told this morning at the Whips' meeting that the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991 would start at 8 p.m.—it is already 8.10 p.m. and it has not started—and that we would sit until it was finished. Clearly, looking at the list and the number of amendments, we would be here until dawn tomorrow or later, and tomorrow's session would follow straight on from it. Any government that puts that sort of proposal before the Senate and expects to be taken seriously really needs to go and have another think. It is not responsible management or a reasonable way to expect people to behave. From today we will be sitting a further three weeks, yet the Government wants to sit virtually all night. I support the amendment moved by Senator Hill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with most of the things Senator Hill said. But he left out a vital fact that has led inexorably to this motion. He and Senator Reid would know, because I told them quite explicitly, arising from the discussion at a meeting between Senator Hill, Senator Reid, the Leader and Whip of the Australian Democrats, Senator Jones and me, that that fact would necessarily lead to this motion. We have had a cooperative approach this session. I have appreciated that and I have indicated that in this chamber on previous occasions. It was the shared objective of those six people in a series of meetings that we should seek to finish a week earlier than the Government's original intention. Many will remember that I indicated that the sitting schedule would go to 19 December. At the request of the Opposition, supported by the Democrats, the original motion dropped that week off to set us all a more stringent target.

PARA.TAB: We were on target and had received indications that that would be achieved. But last week, at that equivalent meeting when I sought an assurance that the essential passage of legislation for the Government—including the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991—would be passed by 12 or 13 December, or by that week, I was told that there was no assurance that that part of the program would be passed by that date. I therefore indicated at that meeting, as everybody must have known that I would have no choice but to do, that to enable the legislative program to be completed I would immediately give notice of motion for a further sitting week.

Nothing would please me more than to be able to have an agreement that would enable all that legislation to be passed by 12 December. That would be a shared objective of every honourable senator. Not all honourable senators might agree on the outcome of all the Bills, but I am sure they would agree that that would be a desirable objective. But I could not receive from Senator Hill and Senator Reid—I am sure for very good reasons—an assurance that the program would be finished by the 12 December. I would have been absolutely negligent had I not accordingly given notice of the extra week to enable the legislative program to be completed. That is self-evident following that statement. That is the missing fact.

It is not the case that in this Budget session we have had days on which we have been padding out the program to avoid running out of business. There has not been a day this session when that has happened. At the end of last session we agreed—and the House of Representatives, under pressure from us, arranged—for legislation to be either introduced or dealt with early in the session by the Senate, and we have had an adequate and comprehensive legislative program every day. I do not want this motion to lead to a breakdown of the cooperative arrangement which we have had. However, the Government has no alternative but to set a sitting timetable which is capable of passing the legislative program. That is our obligation. This is the only timetable that will meet that proper and inevitable objective. It is quite obvious that that is the reason why the motion had to be moved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Talk about occupational health and safety, Senator!

—Nobody would disagree with the objective of finishing a week earlier and minimising the hours and days of sitting. I do not want to be diverted to the question of how we should have dealt with the political advertising legislation at 8 o'clock tonight. As I understand it, we changed that timetable at the request of the Opposition. I am prepared to do that.
—Because your amendments came in late this afternoon, so don't blame us for that.

—Senator Reid should not get excited about it; I was not blaming anybody. She was trying to make a point about the fact that we were not dealing with it and there is a very sound and sensible reason why we are not, which is shared by everybody here. It is quite simple and straightforward. The timetable must meet one fundamental requirement, that is, it must be capable of passing the legislative program. The one we have before us is not and, therefore, this further motion is required.
—Mr Deputy President—
—Senator Lewis, I understand that the debate has been closed.
—By whom, Mr Deputy President?
—By Senator McMullan.
—With all due respect, Mr Deputy President, Senator Hill moved an amendment. I presume that Senator Hill will close the debate on his amendment.

—No, a debate is never closed on an amendment; a debate is closed on a motion. Senator McMullan moved a motion, there was an amendment to it. When Senator McMullan spoke just now, he was closing the debate on his motion.
—I seek leave to speak to Senator Hill's amendment.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know it is some time since former Senator Chipp was in the Senate, but I remind the Senate how concerned we all were when he suffered a heart attack. Thereafter, the Senate managed to adjourn early regularly. I remember former Senator Grimes had similar difficulties. In fact, I think he had open heart surgery and everyone was concerned. I remember when Senator Durack had heart difficulties and was away from this chamber for a considerable number of months and when former Senator Gerry Jones was also away from this chamber.

PARA.TAB: Every time that happens everyone in the Senate gets concerned and starts talking about the workload. We all say, `Next time we must be much more cautious'. The numbers in the Senate then change, people forget and the next thing we know is that the Senate is sitting until 2 o'clock, 3 o'clock or 4 o'clock in the morning. As I understand it, the way we are going tonight we will probably sit until dawn.

The Government says that it has to set a timetable to achieve a particular result. We offered the Government a timetable very early in these sittings to achieve a particular result. It is the introduction of the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill and these amendments at this stage which has created the problem. The program was going perfectly all right until this Bill was forced into the Senate. It is not forced into the Senate in our last week, or on the last day; it is forced into the Senate when we still have two weeks of sitting to go.

This is a Bill which relates to the next election. The chances of the Government wanting to have an election in February or March of 1992 are so remote that I think even the Government senators would say that is not on.

TALK.START.PARA: —If only they would.

—As Senator Macdonald says, if only the Government would, we would be delighted. Of course, it will not have an election, and the probabilities are that it will not have an election until March of 1993. Yet the Senate is being required to sit for these ridiculous hours. How senators in the Labor Party, who claim to be interested in the concerns and welfare of ordinary working people, can force their own staff, the Senate staff and the Hansard staff to work, let alone the senators, and it would not matter if it were just the 76 of us sitting in here—
—I've been sitting these hours for 15 years. That is just part of life in any parliament I know of.

—Senator Collins makes these comments, and no-one denies that from time to time the Senate has to sit long hours. I am lucky; I have been away. But I understand that last week the Senate sat until the very early hours of the morning to try—
—Ten to two and a quarter past one.

—Senator Reid says 10 to two and a quarter past one—in order to pass the Government's legislation and give senators an opportunity to express their views about that legislation. I ask the Government: are you being reasonable? I say to the Democrats: please think about what the Government is proposing. It is no good Senator McMullan saying, `Oh, well, this just sets the time'. Once this motion passed, it is on the record and nothing can then be done about it except with another resolution of the Senate, which means we will have to apply our minds to some subsequent debate on the subject. I say to the Government: you are being totally unreasonable to push this through at this particular stage.

That the amendments (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Amendments negatived.
Original question put:
That the motion (Senator McMullan's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
