TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately for Australian veterans, the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 continues this Government's tradition of making Budget driven decisions which have a detrimental impact on veterans' benefits. Some of these decisions have been directly related to ensuring that the definitions under which service men and women can claim veterans entitlement are kept as narrow as possible. Others reflect a tightening up in the social security budget that the Government has then seen fit to automatically carry across to veterans' entitlements. This Bill certainly continues that trend.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats have consistently opposed further inroads being made into veterans' benefits. My predecessor in this area, former Senator Paul McLean, spoke out repeatedly against what he saw as continual undermining of veterans' entitlements. He also often referred to the suspicion that exists between a substantial portion of the veterans community and the Federal Government on this issue. This legislation will do nothing to allay that suspicion.

However, I do acknowledge that there are a number of positive measures in this Bill—they were outlined in the second reading speech of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys)—which do not require legislation, but which are being introduced by delegated legislation or administrative methods. In particular, I welcome the extension of repatriation benefits to Australian merchant mariners of World War I and World War II. It certainly is high time that this occurred. It has been Australian Democrats policy for quite some time to give full veteran status to those who served in the merchant navy during times of war. Principally through the efforts of former Senator Paul McLean, we have pursued this issue very strongly over the years.

Australian merchant mariners have always had a legitimate claim to repatriation benefits. It is a national disgrace that it has taken until now—in fact, it will take until 1992—to recognise the enormous service given by merchant seamen in the First World War and Second World War. Even so, there is still a need for further extension of entitlements. I trust that the Government, having taken the plunge, will move quickly to extend these entitlements. After all, there is not much point in finally granting benefits to these merchant mariners when there are none left to make use of them.

As far as the Bill is concerned, its most significant measure is that it gives effect to the introduction of a charge for pharmaceuticals under the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The actual charge will be implemented by an instrument under section 91 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act, but that is dependent upon this Bill, which establishes the mechanism for paying pharmaceutical allowance as an offset against that charge.

Until now, the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme has provided pharmaceuticals free of charge to holders of personal treatment entitlement cards and specific treatment entitlement cards. With this Bill, the Government proposes to charge those cardholders $2.60 per scrip item with a compensatory pharmaceutical allowance of $2.60 per week and the same advance payments and safety net provisions which now exist for pensioners. This measure will take effect from 1 January. Essentially, these changes mirror the charge which was introduced for pensioners last year under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

I am pleased to note that the conditions under which an advance payment can be paid have been relaxed and that the liquid assets test has now been removed. When the prescription fee was introduced for pensioners last year, the Democrats stated that we felt the eligibility criteria for advance payments were far too narrow and I moved amendments in the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs to relax them. Those amendments were defeated, so I am now somewhat gratified to see the liquid assets test dumped altogether.

However, the income test will still apply to service pensioners. This remains a great cause for concern because it is a most ungenerous income test: only $10 per week for singles and $20 per week for couples. It operates to ensure that only the poorest of the poor pensioners and veterans have access to advance payments of the allowance. The Australian Democrats oppose this charge for pensioners and we oppose its introduction for veterans for much the same reasons—with the added argument that we have long held the view that veterans of conflicts in which Australia has been involved are entitled to receive special treatment in recognition of their service in times of war.

I also indicate in the strongest terms our continuing opposition to the current obsession with applying the user pays concept to the area of health when quite clearly it does not hold up. Anyone who says it does is either ignoring all the available evidence or is choosing to view the issue with his ideological blinkers well and truly on. This charge is yet another example of where cost saving and cost shifting are occurring with little regard for, or knowledge of, the possible consequences or the existing evidence.

The savings to government from the co-payment are estimated at $35m over the next four years. But what will the cost be to veterans and, indeed, to their long term health care? Yes, the cost up front for the veterans is offset; but, as with the charge for pensioners, there are other problems with the charge beyond the issue of offsetting. Despite the claims of some Government members during the second reading debate in the House of Representatives, the evidence about the effect of the charge on pensioners a year down the track is still not in. We do not know the full impact of the charge and it is quite ridiculous to argue that there has been no substantial impact on pensioners simply because they have not been queuing up to make complaints to their members of parliament.

Dr Ken Harvey from La Trobe University, in a paper written in June of this year entitled Forces acting upon the Australian Pharmaceutical Market, states that 60 to 70 per cent of pensioners are now paying additional premiums for commonly prescribed drugs which are not covered by the pension increase—through the pharmaceutical allowance—or the safety net provisions. Dr Harvey also notes that while the overall CPI fell by 0.2 per cent between the December 1990 quarter and the March 1991 quarter, the cost of pharmaceuticals in that period rose by 14 per cent. This sort of figure is scarcely reassuring and suggests that, as a consequence of the co-payment and the PBS minimum pricing authority, pensioners may be paying more for their pharmaceuticals.

We simply do not have the evidence to say with authority that there has been any positive effect on pensioners' consumption patterns or doctors' prescribing habits. It is quite misleading to argue that the prescription charge for pensioners has had no detrimental effect at all and, therefore, it is okay now to pass it on to veterans and slug them too with the same fee.

There is also the concern that this sort of measure now seems to be the Government's primary strategy for containing costs. Higher patient contributions, co-payments, the minimum pricing policy and the Government PBS education package all tell consumers that it is their responsibility alone. Once again, there is little commitment to look closely at the supply side of the equation and seriously tackle the advertising practices of the pharmaceutical manufacturers or the prescribing patterns of doctors, although I acknowledge the efforts of the Repatriation Pharmaceutical Reference Committee in this area.

As I said earlier, there is more to this matter than the issue of offsetting the charge through the allowance and the safety net provisions. Many of the main concerns remain the same as when the charge was introduced for pensioners last year. I remind the Senate that the original proposal last year did not contain provision for a pharmaceutical allowance or advances; that only came after concerted lobbying from a number of organisations and the referral of the legislation to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. I guess it is at least something that the veterans now do not have to fight for the concessions as pensioners did before them.

Even with the quarantining of the charge and the relaxing of eligibility requirements for advance payments, veterans still have much to be concerned about. Firstly, this Bill furthers the danger of creating a two-tier pension—and now a veterans' entitlements system—with a higher rate of income support for those who are fit and well and a lower rate for those who are ill and infirm. Such an approach must reduce the equitableness of the RPBS. Put simply, under this proposal, veterans who are ill will be financially disadvantaged compared with those who enjoy good health, because the latter will not need to spend their additional allowance on pharmaceuticals.

Secondly, this Bill is based upon the mistaken assumption that veterans will be in a position to actively protect their own interests and ensure that they are not financially or medically disadvantaged. For example, in order to receive an advance, a person—or an advocate on that person's behalf—must make a claim in writing and lodge it with the Department. In many instances, this will rely upon veterans themselves recognising that they are eligible—in other words, they have kept all the figures up to date—for that additional advance and that they know how to go through the process of making arrangements to secure the advance. This will be difficult, if not impossible, for those veterans who are frail, confused or isolated in their own home or who do not have access to family or professional support or advice. As was the case with pensioners, the measure relies upon veterans comprehending the nature of the advance and being able to exercise a choice about setting money aside for potential medical needs.

Thirdly, this Bill fails to address the problem of multiple scrips being required by veterans at any one time. Fourthly, evidence shows that there may be a reduction in the filling of scrips. While some of this may relate to non-essential medication, some of it undoubtedly will not.

Fifthly, what about those veterans with psychiatric problems? We certainly do not have evidence yet about the effects of the charge on pensioners with psychiatric disabilities and, therefore, we cannot say that this is not a problem. Indeed, anecdotal evidence from some community groups suggests that it is a real cause for concern. At the time of the Committee hearings last year, several groups which appeared were worried about people with psychiatric disabilities choosing not to take medication if they had to pay up front for it.

So it is difficult to see the rationale behind extending the charge to veterans. I can only assume it is part of the pattern I mentioned at the start of my speech, that it is a kind of automatic extension following on from the decision to introduce it for pensioners. Beyond the notion of, `We did it for pensioners; now let us do it for the veterans', I cannot see that very much thought has gone into it.

There is no hint in the Minister's speech about the Government's specific motives in making this extension. The evidence is clear that price signals are not a decisive factor in the supply and consumption of pharmaceuticals. The demand for drugs is essentially beyond the control of market price mechanisms, and it is certainly beyond the control of consumers—particularly, I might add, when those consumers are frail, elderly, chronically ill, non-ambulant or living in isolated circumstances.

In short, the Australian Democrats do not support the extension of the charge to veterans because we are not convinced that the charge is needed; we are not interested in the market orientated theory that underpins it as it is flying, as it usually does, in the face of the evidence; we do not believe the effects of last year's charge on pensioners have been fully evaluated; and we do not believe that there is adequate protection for the most disadvantaged veterans.

Veterans have every right to be angry about this charge, as indeed pensioners were last year, because it is based not upon genuine concerns for their health and well-being but upon saving the Government money in the short term with little regard for the consequences, particularly the longer term consequences, of the exercise.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those honourable senators who have contributed to the debate on the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991. I believe it is an important Bill which, through legislation and complemented by administrative measures and various other regulations, achieves what the Government set out to do in the Budget when it brought various of these matters together for action.

PARA.TAB: I recall for the benefit of the Senate the fact that some important changes, such as the provision from 2 January of emergency short term home relief for veterans and war widows, the choice of in-home respite care and veteran support networks, the expansion of the financial information service for pensioners and the extension from 1 December 1991 of repatriation treatment benefits to Australian merchant mariners of World War I and World War II on the same basis as applies to Australian war veterans, can be implemented through administrative arrangements or delegated legislation.

I can say that Senator Lees was quite right and, Madam Acting Deputy President, you will have known from representations made to you in your electorate, as would Senator Reid, that the merchant mariners had a good case to put. I am very pleased that the Government has been able to meet their request by making available to them repatriation treatment benefits.

Of course, legislation is also required to give effect to certain measures. One would effect changes in the arrangements for payments of advances for pharmaceutical allowance, indexation of pharmaceutical allowance and changes to the operational areas in schedule 2 to the Veterans' Entitlements Act to include the area of Iraq and Kuwait and to specify the periods during which certain areas are to be regarded as being operational.

I understand that during the second reading debate Senator Newman asked whether the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) could give a similar undertaking in relation to operational service in Malaya as that given by him to the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer), in another place, in relation to operational service in Iraq or Kuwait. I am able to inform the Senate that, if Senator Newman or anyone else can produce details to prove that but for the date specified in this amendment Bill in relation to Malayan service in the areas described in items 5 and 7 of schedule 2 a veteran would have qualified for benefits under the Veterans' Entitlements Act—that is, if he or she satisfied the other eligibility criteria required under the Act—the Minister has indicated that he would be prepared to consider the amendment of the dates for operational service in consultation with the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray). As I say, I bring that undertaking to the chamber.

In particular, this Bill gives effect to the decision to extend the co-payment arrangements for pharmaceutical benefits under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme to the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme from 1 January 1992. Some aspects of this decision do not require amendment of veterans' affairs legislation. The introduction of a patient contribution of $2.60 per prescription item requires an amendment to the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme which was established in accordance with section 91 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act. I understand that the Minister has already signed and arranged for the tabling of the instrument to effect this change to the scheme.

However, legislative amendment is required for the payment of a fortnightly pharmaceutical allowance to offset the patient contribution. I do not know whether Senator Lees, in her contribution to tonight's debate, really gave enough weight to the payment of that allowance, which offsets the patient contribution, because that is what the Bill provides for.

I believe that these changes are very important. I believe that, despite Senator Lees's misgivings or concern for the lack of really hard evidence, this change can address some of the problems associated with overprescribing and the oversupply of medication and encourage sensible drug use throughout the community. In this case we are addressing the question of the use of drugs by veterans.

I also indicate that the Government will be moving certain amendments in the Senate to correct certain provisions relating to eligibility for an advance pharmaceutical allowance under the entitlements Act. I can deal with those in the course of the committee stage. Basically, the amendments are to ensure that the Bill operates correctly in respect of that important matter as far as veterans are concerned. I thank the honourable senators who spoke in support of the Bill and commend it to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to move an amendment to clause 16 which has been circulated on behalf of the Government. However, before I do so, I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the amendment to be moved by me on behalf of the Government to this Bill. I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 16, page 9, proposed section 118F (including the Notes), lines 7 to 19, omit the section, substitute the following section:
"`118F.(1) Subject to subsection (2), a person to whom section 118A applies is eligible for an advance pharmaceutical allowance.
"(2) A person is not eligible for an advance pharmaceutical allowance if:
(a) the person is receiving a service pension; and
(b) the only reason why section 118A applies to the person is that the person is receiving that pension; and
(c) the Commission is satisfied that the person's ordinary income exceeds $20.00 per fortnight.

SPEECH.PARA: Note: for `ordinary income' see subsection 5H(1).

PARA.TAB: "(3) If the person is a member of a couple, the amount of the person's ordinary income for the purposes of this section is worked out by adding the couple's ordinary incomes (on a fortnightly basis) and dividing by 2.

SPEECH.PARA: Note: for `member of a couple' see subsections 5E(1), (2), (3) and (4).".

As I foreshadowed, this amendment is required to correct the provisions relating to eligibility for an advance pharmaceutical allowance under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. As drafted, the new section 118F included in clause 16 of the Bill does not operate correctly in respect of the income test applicable to the advance pharmaceutical allowance. This amendment would replace section 118F with a revised version, as it were—I have heard that term before—to correct the two drafting errors which have been identified. The problems relate to two issues: who the income level applies to, and the income level applicable to a person who is a member of a couple.

PARA.TAB: The first problem stems from the fact that a person may satisfy more than one of the eligibility criteria for pharmaceutical allowance. For example, a service pensioner may also be in receipt of a war widow's pension. The intention is, and has always been, that such a person should not be subject to the income test. The income test on the advance pharmaceutical allowance will apply only where the sole reason that person is eligible for the pharmaceutical allowance is that that person is a service pensioner.

The second issue relates to the income levels specified in the income test for the advance pharmaceutical allowance. An individual may have ordinary income of $20 per fortnight. The provision as drafted would allow a person who was a member of a couple to have an ordinary income of $40 per fortnight. This should be a total of $40 between the members of the couple, not $40 each. This intention is reflected in the original explanatory memorandum to the Bill and continues the rules applying under the existing income test for the advance pharmaceutical allowance introduced last year. I ask that the Committee consider favourably that amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise two matters. One is to indicate that the Opposition does not oppose the amendment. As the Minister has said, it fixes up drafting arrangements. The other relates to the undertaking which the Minister just gave. The officers will have the transcript of Senator Newman's speech where she said, as recorded on page 3524:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . should any cases emerge which clearly show the operational dates to be inappropriate, then the Government will move to ensure that such veterans are properly recognised.
I take it that the Minister's undertaking met that request.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can tell Senator Reid that the undertaking is precisely directed to meeting that request.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 12 and 14 November, on motions by Senator McMullan and Senator Collins:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of Bills that the Senate is now debating, comprising the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1991, the Fringe Benefits Tax Amendment Bill 1991, the Income Tax (Deferred Interest Securities) (Tax File Number Withholding Tax) Bill 1991, the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 and the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991, is an important package. The Bills deal with a range of different issues. There is a significant list of honourable senators on the speakers list for this second reading debate. I am sure that the different speakers will be addressing various aspects of the Bills.

PARA.TAB: So far as the technical aspects of the taxation Bills are concerned, the Opposition will be led in this debate by my colleague Senator Watson. He will be talking particularly about some of the technical aspects which concern us and various sections of industry. The Medicare Levy Amendment Bill will be addressed by Senator Herron and others. We will be moving some amendments in relation to some of these Bills.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) is an important Bill because it gives effect to the announcements in the March industry statement that the tax concessions for research and development be retained as a permanent feature and that provision be made for deductibility of environmental impact study expenditure. There are various other aspects covered by the Bill, including an amendment to give effect to the announcement of the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) on 13 June to provide relief for small business by deferring the initial payment of company tax in respect of the 1990-91 tax year. The Bill will also give effect to the announcement on 2 August that living away from home allowance paid to offshore oil and gas rig workers will be treated as fringe benefits. There are additional aspects of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) which Senator Watson will elaborate on.

The Fringe Benefits Tax Amendment Bill is designed to increase the fringe benefits tax rate from 47 per cent to 48.25 per cent, and the Income Tax (Deferred Interest Securities) (Tax File Number Withholding Tax) Bill 1991 is to impose a withholding tax jointly and severally on investment bodies and investors where a tax file number is not quoted for certain deferred interest investments made on or after 1 February 1992. The fourth tax Bill, the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill (No. 2), provides legislative authority for the entry into force of comprehensive double taxation agreements between Australia and India and Australia and Poland.

I do not wish to comment further on these Bills other than to note that in respect of the last one the Opposition welcomes the conclusion of the agreement with Poland, in particular, and also with India. The agreement with Poland is an indication of Australia's support for that country's moves towards democratic structures and economic reforms. That is a very important move and we wish Poland well in the difficult task ahead in restructuring its economy along the lines of a modern democratic market society. It is very difficult to make the changes that are required in countries like Poland. The task will not be easy and we wish Poland well.

I wish to address some of the broader aspects of taxation and economic policy. In particular, the proposals put forward by the Opposition in the last couple of weeks to reward and rebuild Australia by the introduction of the most comprehensive and far-reaching package for reform ever produced by any political party in Australia, either in government or in opposition. I will deal with that and some of the comments that have been made, and look specifically at some of the issues that have been raised in relation to it.

The first question that needs to be asked and is being asked is: why did the coalition produce such fundamental proposals for change? Believe me, they are very fundamental proposals indeed. We have introduced such fundamental proposals for change because tinkering at the edges, playing around with incremental change, has done Australia no good—indeed, it has done Australia a great deal of harm. Governments have been doing that for 15 years now and, in the last eight or nine years in particular, the Hawke Government has turned incremental change and tinkering at the margins into an art form.

The result is the worst recession for 60 years; unemployment approaching one million people; under-employment at least another half a million people; one in every three young persons jobless; savings at record low levels; disastrous collapses in investment and business confidence; a rapidly deteriorating budget position following two years of massive deterioration when we saw a turnaround in the Commonwealth's fiscal position of no less than $13 billion; and our Achilles heel, the balance of payments, showing no signs of sustained improvement—what improvement there has been is due to the bludgeoning blow of the recession, but even then the improvement has been very limited.

As we have seen from the balance of payments figures for October released today, despite the deepest recession that we have had for 60 years, the import figure for October 1991 was higher than the figure one year ago. That is occurring at the same time as we are seeing a very worrying fall in export earnings, coupled with a significant increase in the debt servicing burden which, in the month of October alone, was $1.6 billion. That was the amount required last month to service our foreign liabilities. That debt servicing cost is now running at $17 billion a year and rising, and there is no sign of sustainable recovery.

We remain uncompetitive on the world front. We are not paying our way in the world. We must lift our productivity and our competitiveness, otherwise we will continue to slip down the ladder of comparative international living standards in the way that we have done in the last few years. The net result of that is a lower standard of living than we have come to expect—a lower standard of living for a country like ours with great resources, skills, talents and all the things that we have going for us which we should be utilising to provide a better way of life and, in particular, more jobs and opportunities for our people.

The coalition's Fightback proposals point the way to a better future for Australians and provide a vision for the future. They provide hope not only for us but also for our children and our grandchildren. It is pleasing that very widely throughout the community, including in the media, it has been noted that it is refreshing for a political party in opposition to have had the courage and the ability to bring forward such important and far-reaching proposals. This is an honest attempt on our part to put forward a coherent, integrated, far-sighted set of proposals for Australians to consider. That is why it has been so well received. That is why I would formally move the second reading amendment which has been circulated in the name of the coalition to Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991. Whilst not, of course, declining to give the Bill a second reading, I move:

At end of motion, add ", but the Senate condemns the Government for its economic policy failures which have resulted in one and a half million Australians being unemployed or underemployed in the worst recession for 60 years, and urges the Government to adopt the Opposition's Fightback! package of proposals to provide hope, and a vision for the future, for all Australians, including in particular:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)the largest personal income tax cuts in Australia's history, amounting to $13 billion;
(b)the abolition of the wholesale sales tax, payroll tax, the petroleum products excise, superannuation lump sum tax, customs levy, training guarantee levy and the coal export duty;
(c)significant, and beneficial, restructuring of the capital gains tax and fringe benefits tax;
(d)the creation of two million jobs;
(e)a halving of the current devastating level of unemployment and underemployment involving more than 1.5 million Australians; and
(f)the introduction of a 15 per cent goods and services tax that will:

PARA.TAB: (i)reform and simplify Australia's grossly inefficient taxation system;
(ii)boost our national productivity and savings;
(iii)enable greater international competitiveness by slashing taxes on business inputs;
(iv)assist in reducing marginal tax rates and thus increase incentives to work, save and invest;
(v)make the tax system fairer by reducing avoidance and evasion; and
(vi)adequately compensate Australians for the net one-off price effect of the goods and services tax".

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has been threatening for months that it would destroy the coalition's goods and services tax and related proposals. Time and again the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that he could not wait for the details so that he could demolish the Opposition. We have been waiting for the great attack to be launched. Indeed, during the last weekend the Prime Minister suggested that the attack would be launched this week.

PARA.TAB: Today was actually day one. Boy, what a day it has proved to be; it has been a triple whammy. The first was the fact that the Prime Minister, who was so concerned about how he and his Government were going in relation to attacking the package, pleaded for the help of the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland, Mr Keating. That was a pretty good start to the day. That came out in today's media as a result of what the Prime Minister said at the weekend. But then the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Howe, launched his full-blooded attack on the Opposition's proposals to have a very beneficial and major reform of the health system, for which this country has been crying out for years. Deputy Prime Minister Howe did not like this too much so he held a press conference and AAP reported it. On the wires at 4.09 p.m. today came this blast from Deputy Prime Minister Howe that health costs were going to blow out by $2 billion under the coalition's health policy released this week.

Less than 1 1/2 hours later, AAP reported something slightly different. It reported that, at a news conference called by Mr Howe to give his first major response to the policy, there was a major embarrassment when he was forced to admit a mistake in the news releases his staff had just issued an hour or so earlier. Those releases had said that, under the coalition, people without private health insurance would have to pay a tax surcharge of $800 a family. He omitted to mention the coalition's policy which said that that applies only to families with an income of $50,000 or single people with an income over $40,000. He also omitted totally to list any of the other major benefits involved in the coalition's health policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was his excuse?

—My friend Senator Walters asks: what was his excuse? It was not his fault. He said that he was working on departmental advice, and if there had been an error it was not deliberate. He then went on to say that he was not too sure whether the error affected his claim that the coalition policy would add $2 billion to the cost of health care. I can give the Deputy Prime Minister the answer to that: the answer is that he has made an almighty blunder and that the coalition's policy does not add $2 billion to the cost of health care. Indeed, the net effect of the coalition's policy is that the overall cost of health care will fall.

PARA.TAB: Later, the Deputy Prime Minister issued a statement saying that the original releases about the tax surcharge would have been `more complete if they had referred to "some" uninsured people'. What a ripper. My friend and colleague the shadow Minister for health, Dr Bob Woods, put out a press release headed `Howe wrong can you get?'. I do not know the answer to that, just ask Minister Howe how wrong you can get. I am sure my friend Senator Herron will say more about that a little later.

The second barrel of the great attack today came from no less than the, until recently—indeed, he still is essentially—invisible Treasurer, John Kerin. He called a press conference to talk about a few things today. He was going to shoot us down on this package as well. I thought the most significant thing he said was when he was asked what the Government might have to do to come up with a substantial alternative to win back voters. He said, `In government there is always room to repackage what we are doing'. When asked what that meant he said, `Watch this space'. He did not have a clue as to what the Government would do to attack this package. He then went on to say, `The main attack at the end of the day will be political'. That repeats a similar claim he made the other night on the 7.30 Report when he said that he did not think the Government would be able to attack the package on the arithmetic; it would have to attack it on the policies and on the ideology.

If that is the case, I ask the Prime Minister and the Treasurer why it is that almost two weeks after the launch of the most comprehensive package of reform proposals in Australia's history the Government has not been able to come up with one meaningful attack on it. There is an easy answer for that. We will continue to wait, wait and wait if the Government wants us to, but I can tell the Senate why the Government has not attacked this package: to attack a visionary document, a document of hope, a document of opportunity, one has to have vision, to have hope and to provide opportunity. The Government has none of those things. It has no vision; it has no hope; it has no ideas. It is old, tired and tatty. It is dispirited, divided and consumed with personal bitterness. It is infested with distrust and disloyalty.

There is no doubt that it is now time for a change of government in this country. What does the Prime Minister have in mind for change? As I said earlier, he has in mind enlisting his arch enemy—the pretender to the throne, the architect who helped him create the deepest, most cruel, most unnecessary recession in 60 years—to assist the Government in attacking the coalition's Fightback proposals. That is novel and refreshing; that is visionary, I must say!

I refer to some of the criticisms that have been made of some aspects of the coalition's Fightback proposals. In the past couple of days, the Treasurer has claimed that a Treasury analysis has shown that wholesale sales tax has a minimal effect on business. He claims, according to press reports, that the wholesale sales tax adds less than 2 per cent to business costs in virtually all sectors. It is also claimed, I think by the Treasurer, that the Treasury analysis says that the wholesale sales tax cost to exporters is only $810m. He is reported as asking why, in these circumstances, a goods and services tax is necessary.

Some very obvious responses need to be made to these claims. First, the Government should release all of the details of the Treasury analysis for us to be in a position to make any considered assessment of the Treasurer's claims. If the Treasurer is not prepared to release those details, one can only be highly suspicious of his assertions.

Secondly, the figures quoted by the Treasurer are very much less than those estimated by the Business Council of Australia, other industry associations and Access Economics, using its very sophisticated AEM, developed by Chris Murphy, who was instrumental in the development of the original Treasury model. It would seem likely that the Treasury has not taken full account of the cascading effect on business costs of the wholesale sales tax. This is the underlying reason for the very significant passing on of the cost burden of the wholesale sales tax into other businesses.

Thirdly, Mr Kerin himself has acknowledged the reasons why the wholesale sales tax is an inequitable and inefficient tax. I refer to his letter of 26 November, just last week, to the chairman of the Caucus economic and industrial relations Committee. I tabled that letter in the Senate last week. Among other things, Mr Kerin states:

SPEECH.PARA: The services sector is not charged wholesale sales tax on its output, so continuing its input taxation is desirable to ensure some equity with the output taxation of the goods-producing sectors.

The only conclusion that one can draw from that statement is that the Treasurer is fully aware of the inequity of applying the wholesale sales tax only to goods and not to services; otherwise there would be no reason for him to make the statement that he did in his letter to the Chairman of the Caucus committee last week.

PARA.TAB: The fourth point is that both the Prime Minister and the former Treasurer, Mr Keating, were ardent advocates of a broad-based consumption tax in 1985, their reasons including that it removed the tax discrimination that exists under a wholesale sales tax between the tax on goods and the lack of tax on services. In that respect, I can do no better than to quote former Treasurer Keating at a luncheon in Adelaide on 13 June 1985. In the speech at that luncheon, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . At present, the tax system contains three major indirect taxes—customs duty, the excises, and the sales tax levied on manufactured goods at the wholesale level. This structure of indirect taxes is highly discriminatory.

. . . there is no logical justification for a tax which discriminates against manufactured goods compared with services, particularly in a society which has seen services replace goods as the dominate field of economic activity.
There, almost, rests the argument as far as wholesale sales tax versus goods and services tax is concerned.

PARA.TAB: I have no doubt that over the next few months the Government will come out with a major so-called expansion and simplification of the wholesale sales tax and that it will go for a very uniform rate. If it does that, it will still miss a fundamental problem with the wholesale sales tax—that is, that it does not apply to services. If we want to get our country and our manufactured goods more internationally competitive on the export market and against imports, then we have to remove that discrimination between the taxing of goods and the taxing of services. If we do not, we are just going to load the tax on goods in a much higher way than is equitable or efficient.

They are some of the reasons why I believe the statements Mr Kerin has been making on wholesale sales tax are very wrong. Even if his Treasury model figures turned out to be correct—and that is a very dubious assumption—it still would not remove the fundamental reason for having a goods and services tax rather than a wholesale sales tax.

In the time still available to me, I would like to mention just a couple of other matters. One relates to a very important, and I think valuable, interview this morning on the AM program. The interviewee was the Anglican Archbishop of Brisbane, the Most Reverend Peter Hollingworth. I am very pleased to note that in that interview this morning Archbishop Hollingworth said:

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of faults and anomalies in the tax system. Those things do need to be addressed and I think we can appreciate the effort that the Coalition's gone to providing a comprehensive package and to have done so many months before the likelihood of an election. I think that's good.
He was then asked:
Well, should there be a GST?
He replied:
Well, I don't think you can answer that simply. There's no reason why you shouldn't tax at the point of consumption. . .

He said that we have to face the fact that there are various aspects of the package, particularly in the area of compensation, where there has to be a lot more debate. I would agree completely with Archbishop Hollingworth on that.

PARA.TAB: In particular, in the debate over the days, weeks and months ahead I hope that we will be able to make people more aware than they are at the moment that a goods and services tax of 15 per cent does not increase prices across the board by 15 per cent, because the package of proposals that has been put forward by the coalition includes the abolition of a very wide range of taxes, including payroll tax, petrol excise, wholesale sales tax, the training levy, superannuation lump sum tax and the like, all of which at the moment are direct costs on business. All of those will be removed and the net impact of the goods and services tax, when taken into account with all those other things on the basis of the most sophisticated economic modelling which presently exists in Australia, is that the net consumer price index effect is 4.4 per cent.

Even that figure is an overstatement of the real underlying impact. It is accepted by a very wide range of people, including the Treasurer and certainly the former Treasurer, Mr Keating, that the real underlying measure of an inflationary impact—the best measure—is the non-farm gross domestic product deflator. Using that measure, the net price impact of the package being proposed by the coalition is not 4.4 per cent but 2.2 per cent. Compensation is being provided to every member of the community either in the form of direct compensation for pensioners, with increases of 8 per cent, or very significant tax reductions for income earners. The overall compensation, in whatever form it comes, far exceeds any likely price impact that will emerge from the imposition of the GST accompanied by the other measures.

I welcome the opportunity to continue this debate over a lengthy period of time. I am sure that at the end of that debate there will be no doubt that the great majority of the Australian population will confirm what they have already said by way of response, that is, that they are very impressed with this package, and that they will see the great benefits to them in a non-inflationary sense and in a way that will provide jobs, growth, hope and opportunity for all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1991, the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, the Income Tax (Deferred Interest Securities) (Tax File Number Withholding Tax) Bill 1991 and the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991. My colleague Senator Short from Victoria has just set the economic scene and compared this package with the coalition's tax reform Fightback program so ably led by Dr Hewson. I take this opportunity to commend Senator Short for the important role that he played in devising this Fightback package.

PARA.TAB: Debate on the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1991 will be led by our colleague from Queensland, a former eminent surgeon, Senator Herron, who will bring to this debate an acknowledged expertise in medicine. I will be concentrating on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991 and the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991. While the Government will increase the rate of tax in the Fringe Benefits Tax Amendment Bill to 48.25 per cent, the coalition will significantly reduce tax on fringe benefits as part of its Fightback reform package.

I also draw the Senate's attention to an undertaking given to the Australian people at the last ALP conference that no new taxes would be introduced and no taxes would be increased. Here is a demonstration in this Bill before us today of another break with that commitment. We recall that some time ago there was to be no capital gains tax. So much for the Government's undertakings.

Apart from the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill, there are no matters of substantive disagreement on this side of the Parliament. I remind the Senate that the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) were subject to detailed scrutiny and comment from the Australian Taxation Office and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) during the referral of these Bills on 15 November to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. I refer listeners to this debate to the Hansard of that Committee's proceedings for a full exposition of the fine details of that debate.

I take this opportunity of thanking the Taxation Office personnel and the Parliamentary Secretary for their considered responses. The referral of Bills, particularly taxation Bills, is a useful device in the evaluation of tax legislation. I would also like to take the opportunity of thanking Senator McMullan for his undertakings to bring to the Senate 15 particular issues which were raised at those deliberations and which were not responded to fully on that occasion. We look forward to his speech this evening when I believe all of those matters will be addressed.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) is, like so many tax Bills that have come before us, an omnibus technical Bill which contains a number of reforms that were announced by the Government either in the March 1991 industry statement or the 1991-92 Budget. On first appearance, the Bill presents itself as a tidying up Bill covering a vast range of over 29 different topics. Several of these require little or no comment. However, much to my dismay, on investigating the fringe benefits provisions of the living away from home allowance amendments that have been introduced in this Bill, all my comments about the need for simplification of the tax Act—the need for certainty and the need for a clear understanding of what is required by the taxpayer in a system of self-assessment—were once again reinforced and I repeat them now. There is a crying need in this country for a set of tax laws that are simple, easy and very explicit. I commend the Government on the simplification of the explanatory memorandum that accompanies this Bill. But this needs to be extended to all taxation legislation and into the body of the taxation Act itself.

Firstly, the living away from home allowances paid to off-shore oil and gas rig workers are now to be treated as fringe benefits. The Opposition has many reservations about this amendment as it may well spread across the industrial award system with the consequence that the employer, increasingly, will be responsible for meeting the top tax obligation via a fringe benefits tax regime rather than a PAYE regime. This is contrary to assurances from the Government.

The amendment has arisen as a result of a court decision known as Attwood Oceanic v. the Australian Taxation Commissioner. That corporation will no longer have to pay fringe benefits tax on living away from home allowances in respect of operations on oil rigs in Bass Strait. In this case, the payments under the award were, in part, for recognition of, amongst other things, not taking days off. Consequently, the ATO felt that the living away from home allowance should be taxed. Attwood took this decision to the court and was successful. Regrettably, the legislation before us now seeks to overturn that court decision.

During the Committee hearings I sought assurances that this amendment could be quarantined to the oil and gas workers specifically on the oil rigs in Bass Strait. I was also concerned about the indirect effect of this amendment and the present general outworkings and understanding by the public of fringe benefits. Since then I have been overwhelmed by instances of the fringe benefits tax applying to similar situations. In fact, the Australian Taxation Office auditors are enforcing such and applying penalties to corporations and to instrumentalities even in the government sector.

During the Committee proceedings I incorporated a copy of a letter from a council clerk in Queensland concerned about the fringe benefits tax that was payable on camp allowances. Since that hearing, the ATO has responded and claimed that such tax allowances were not subject to fringe benefits.

However, I venture to suggest that the Commissioner's response was only partly correct. It was correct in terms of the short term personnel who go out there, but not in terms of the norm: those who tend to stay in camps that are established for 21 days or more. Camp allowances are paid to council workers, particularly road workers who need to camp on the job sites. Employees generally spend three or four nights in the camp and then return to their homes for the remaining nights. For this inconvenience, they are paid an award of $10 per day to cover the cost of the extra food they need to bring to feed themselves on the days that they are away from home. The shire council normally provides the workers with a small caravan on site.

The problem that has arisen is that the council has received conflicting accounts as to whether it should pay fringe benefits tax on the amount minus the reasonable compensation for increased expenditure necessary since the worker is not at home; whether the payment should be taxed as part of the PAYE tax of the worker; whether it should be regarded as a travelling allowance and be exempt from tax completely; or whether it will be subject to the fringe benefits tax regime. The problem is further complicated by the fact that the ATO does not seem to be able to make up its own mind about the entire matter. Consequently, I would like to table a number of documents outlining this situation. I have sought the leave of the Parliamentary Secretary to table those documents and also to incorporate three other letters in Hansard relating to the fringe benefits tax, and I now seek the leave of the Senate.
Leave granted.

Fringe Benefits Tax on Camp Allowance
It is understood that the payment by Local Authorities of fringe benefits tax on camp allowance has been raised with you on behalf of the Quilpie Shire Council.

For some time now, this Association has been attempting to remove, or at least minimise, the fringe benefits tax liability on camp allowance. Accompanying this letter are copies of letters that have passed between the Association and the Australian Taxation Office on the issue.

Originally, the Association objected to any FBT being paid by Local Authorities on camp allowance. The Tax Office stated that it was payable when the camp allowance was considered as a living away from home allowance. An amount of $2.50 was, however, exempted from FBT on the basis that it represented increased food costs.

The Association then submitted to the Tax Office that the amount of $2.50 was incorrectly calculated as the camp allowance did not attempt to compensate employees for their normal food costs. On that basis, the Association felt that any part of the camp allowance relating to food costs should be exempt from FBT. To date, no reply has been received.

The other component of the camp allowance relates to the disability of having to live in a camp environment. Although the Association has no details of the case, it is possible that Attwood Oceanics vs Federal Government of Taxation may have some relevance as it dealt with a living away from home allowance based on disabilities and inconvenience.
It is hoped that the above information may be of assistance to you in this matter.

PARA.TAB: 24 September 1991

SPEECH.PARA: The Town/Shire Clerk,
ALL MEMBER COUNCILS
Dear Sir/Madam,
Fringe Benefits Tax on Camp Allowance

As was indicated in the circular dated 2nd September, 1991, the Association has sought the advice of Taxation Consultants, Deloitte Ross and Tohmatsu in relation to the treatment of camp allowance for taxation purposes.

There appears to be little doubt that, in the case of allowances to be paid for a period in excess of 21 days, the allowance constitutes a living away from home allowance and thus would be subject to fringe benefits taxation.

The difficulty arises when individuals are required to remain in camp for a period less than 21 days. It is understood that when an employee is required to remain in camp for a period of time up to 21 days, the allowance is generally treated as a travelling allowance for taxation purposes.

However, the 21 day rule refers to the period of time the employees are required to remain in a particular location, not the periods from week to week in which they reside in camps. For example, a Council may be engaged on a road construction project for a period of four months and require its employees to live in camp for this period. If Council is working a nine day fortnight, the employees may only remain in camp from Monday to Thursday in the first week returning home on Friday, and spend three days in camp in the second week. In this situation, the period for the purposes of the 21 day rule would be the period the employees are required to remain at the particular camp location, not the periods from week to week in which they reside in camp.

The F.E.D.F.A.'s circular cannot be interpreted as stating that camp allowance should be treated automatically as a living away from home allowance and subject to fringe benefits taxation. Any short term postings of employees to camps would result in the allowance being treated as a travelling allowance and thus not subject to FBT.

If a Council has not correctly disclosed a living away from home allowance, it is possible to make a voluntary disclosure to the Taxation Office and, in this way, the Council would minimise its exposure to penalties. Failure to make such a voluntary disclosure would expose Councils to substantial penalties. The Commissioner of Taxation has the power to amend fringe benefits tax assessments for a period of up to six years from when the tax became due and payable in order to increase a taxpayer's tax liability.
In recent times, the Commissioner has issued amended assessments to Queensland Government and Statutory Authorities to include camp allowance as a living away from home allowance.

Any reduction in the taxation value of a living away from home allowance on account of accommodation and excess food costs is only available if the employee gives to the employer a declaration in an approved form which sets out the particulars of:-
(i)the employee's usual place of residence during the allowance period; and
(ii) the place at which the employee resided during the allowance period.
the declaration must be handed to the employer before the fringe benefits tax return is to be lodged, usually 28th April of each year.

If the declaration is not obtained from every employee, then the Council is liable to full fringe benefits tax on the total cash allowance paid to each employee who fails to supply the declaration and, in addition, the taxable value of any accommodation supplied to the employee will also be liable to fringe benefits tax.
Should you require any further information in connection with this matter, please contact the Association's Industrial Relations Section.

PARA.TAB: Yours faithfully,
(G.T. Hoffman)

Dear Sir
FRINGE BENEFIT TAX:
Reference is made to your letter dated 18 October 1991 in which you requested a ruling in regards to the council's liability for payment of Fringe Benefits Tax on Camp Allowance.

As you would be aware any expression of opinion as to the likely application of the fringe benefit tax law is not binding on the commissioner. When the time comes to assess liability to tax, the law as then enacted and as interpreted by decisions of tribunals, courts and taxation rulings, must be applied to the facts as then established. The following comments on the questions raised in your letter are offered subject to this necessary reservation.

You are advised, that a camp allowance is taxed at source under the pay as you earn system and included in the assessable income of the employee. While a living away from home allowance is subject to fringe benefits tax, and paid by the employer, and not included in the employees assessable income.
(Quoting from the award).

A camp allowance is paid under an award to an employee where in the performance of his work it is necessary for that employee to live in a camp provided by the employer either because there are no reasonable transport facilities to enable such an employee to travel to and from his home each day or because such employee is directed by the employer to live in such a camp. Such employee shall be paid a camping allowance of $10.00 for each day (including Saturday and Sunday) he lives in camp.

While a living away from home allowance is defined in paragraph 27 of taxation ruling MT 2030 "It is in the nature of an allowance that it will not ordinarily be a precise measure of artificial expense of the recipient. Rather.. a living away from home allowance is an allowance in the nature of compensation for additional expenses incurred and other disadvantages suffered, by an employee through having to live away from his or her usual place of residence. Broadly, it emphasises that the central considerations are whether an employee has changed his employment location and taken up temporary residence away from his usual place of residence.
If an employee is simply travelling in the course of performing his employment duties then a travelling/camp allowance will deemed to exist.

Therefore, an allowance paid to an employee will be classed as a living away from home allowance where the employee is one of the class of employees that come within the guide-lines set out in MT 2030. If the employee does not satisfy the tests in MT 2030 then the employee is not receiving a living away from home allowance and is assessable on the allowance received.
It is trusted that this is the information you seek.
Yours faithfully
W.D. Mulherin
Deputy Commissioner of Taxation

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The documents include a letter from the Local Government Association of Queensland and letters from the Australian Taxation Office. The letter from the ATO deals only with the short term stays rather than the norm where the camp is established for more than 21 days and when the full impact of the FBT appears to apply. All I can say is that, if taxpayers receive such information under a Taxation Office letterhead, is it any wonder that there is confusion and uncertainty under this system of self-assessment? I look forward to hearing Senator McMullan's comments on this entire issue.

PARA.TAB: I would now like to refer back to the original Attwood-Oceanic decision. Following the decision, a number of problems arose as a consequence of the gap between the Attwood court hearing decision and the press release No. 68 from the Tax Office, which reaffirmed that living away from home allowances were subject to fringe benefits. During this time a number of companies did not continue to pay fringe benefits tax on the living away from home allowance. This raised a number of problems for both the individual employees and the companies involved. The issue was able to be dealt with during the Bill's referral to the Senate Standing Committee. Senator McMullan was able to assure the coalition that the Taxation Office had no intention of pursuing the individual employees caught unintentionally in this situation. I commend the Taxation Office for its human face in this situation.

The issue of what constitutes a living away from home allowance compared with a travelling allowance is far from clear and is proving to be extremely fertile ground for fringe benefits tax auditors from the Australian Taxation Office. The Taxation Office has targeted a number of State government instrumentalities on this point and has no hesitation in imposing significant penalties on any adjustments. Even the Taxation Office itself would have to complete a fringe benefits tax return and the return would disclose separately the number of living away from home allowance benefits provided by the Taxation Office and the total FBT paid in respect of such allowances.

I submit to the Senate that it would be interesting to note how much the ATO itself pays in fringe benefits tax. Perhaps the tabling of the amount and the working papers could give all taxpayers some assurance that the ATO itself is complying with the law. An interesting question I submit further is: who audits the FBT of the ATO? In the case of construction workers, people appear to have forgotten ruling MT2030FBT, which suggests that in most circumstances allowances received will be regarded as a living away from home allowance provided that the employee can establish that he or she does in fact have a home other than the construction site.

A further sleeper in the fringe benefits tax area with ammunition here involves the position of taxi fares for employees who are required to work back after normal office hours. The Taxation Office has also focused on this during its FBT audits. The approach of the Taxation Office, I am given to understand, is that, if a taxi fare is provided to an employee for after hours work in excess of one night per week, then all such fares will be subject to fringe benefits tax. This is the case irrespective of the fact that the employer may be providing taxis to employees only in the interests of the employees' safety. I understand that one of the major banks is currently disputing through the courts the FBT status of taxi fares paid on behalf of shift workers. But a whole raft of shift workers get caught up in this scenario.

I do not believe that, generally, employers would regard such taxi fares as a benefit, hence, I am sure that very few companies would be paying fringe benefits tax on such amounts. One wonders whether the Taxation Office itself is paying fringe benefits on fares provided to its employees working overtime. Perhaps the Parliamentary Secretary will oblige us with an assurance in that area. The Liberal-National Party coalition wishes to condemn in the strongest terms attempts by both the Government and the Tax Office to extend to cash payments, under an award, in the nature of a living away from home allowance, the fringe benefits tax regime rather than apply the PAYE system.

There are a number of other amendments to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) with which the coalition has some concerns. The Opposition will be moving two amendments at the committee stage, one relating to the deductibility of environmental expenditure and the other relating to lottery prizes and winnings and the discrimination that applies to banks. I note that the other amendment that we were to move has now been dealt with, because the Government picked it up—although it added another 60 days. I thank the Government for its consideration and the benefit that that will give to taxpayers. Naturally, we will not be moving that amendment.

We also look forward to assurances from the Parliamentary Secretary—despite the fact that we will move our amendment—that those prizes will not be part of the regime for the purposes of this amendment. However, we will be moving that amendment because we do not believe, despite those assurances, that our principal concern has been fully acknowledged.

I regret that the Democrats will not be supporting our amendments. Unfortunately, they have certain hang-ups, despite the injustice of the system and the discrimination against the banks. When a party espouses environmental issues as strongly as the Australian Democrats have done, I think its credibility suffers when it cannot recognise and support a justifiable amendment allowing a proper deductibility regime for costs of environmental impact studies that are necessarily incurred under statutes of Commonwealth, State or local governments. Tomorrow may see a change of heart.

The taxation treatment offered by the Australian income tax system can either encourage taxpayers to, or discourage them from, undertaking expenditure on programs to protect the environment. At present, the income tax system unintentionally discourages taxpayers from undertaking certain environmental expenditure. Under the existing law, the costs of studies undertaken to determine the impact a project may have on the environment do not qualify for a deduction. The legislation before us seeks to provide some basis for this, but a very inadequate one.

In most cases, under government provision the cost can be deducted over 10 years. An examination of what is done in our neighbouring OECD countries clearly shows that in the majority of those countries expenditure on environmental matters is recognised as an ordinary business expense. The cost of environmental impact studies is written off in far fewer than 10 years. Therefore, the coalition amendment will provide that the environmental impact studies expenses can be deductible in the following circumstances: where the project proceeds, the expenditure is to be written off over three years; where the project does not proceed, expenditure is to be deductible outright.

I believe that if this Government is serious about its commitment to environmental issues it should accept the amendment that we are proposing. In most projects nowadays the law—either Federal, State or local—requires an environmental impact study to be undertaken for new projects and the expenditure can, therefore, be regarded as a necessary expense. Comments from industry on the Government's planned 10-year write-off note indicate that this is out of line with the relevant accounting standards which would require full write-off in the year of expenditure. If the Government were to adopt the coalition's amendment of the write-off of expenditure over three years, it would acknowledge the sensitivity of business to environmental expenditures.

Before I leave this topic I would like to commend Senator McMullan for the review of section 82BF which has been described as an anti-avoidance provision. The Opposition is of the view that this could be adequately dealt with under part IVA of the Act or under sections 82KH to 82KLK. I look forward to hearing the Government's comments—especially those, revealed for the first time during the committee stages of this Bill, on its intention to remove similar specific anti-avoidance measures which appear unnecessary in view of the part IVA general anti-avoidance network as part of the Government's simplification package.

The second amendment that we raised during the referral stage of the Bill was concerned with the direct lodgment of appeals and the application of review. Under existing law, if a taxpayer is dissatisfied with the Commissioner's decision on an objection, a taxpayer may lodge with the Commissioner a request to refer the decision either to the AAT or to the Federal Court of Australia, and this right of review or appeal is provided for in various taxation laws. Each of these taxation laws sets out the mechanism and the conditions for the lodgment of objections, requests for review and appeals and the Commission's responsibilities and duties relating to them.

This Bill will amend the taxation laws in two ways. Firstly, the application for review and appeals will no longer need to be lodged with the Tax Commissioner for him to refer them to the AAT or to the Federal Court. Taxpayers will now lodge applications for review and appeals directly with the AAT or the Federal Court. I think almost the whole of part V has been wiped out, but there was not much by way of quid pro quo for the taxpayer, or taxpayers' rights; hence our amendment, which the Government, fortunately, has picked up, which will tend to bring this balance back, not unreasonably.

Secondly, there will be one set of generic provisions for objections, reviews and appeals included in the Taxation Administration Act 1953, which is the principal Act. The coalition was concerned about taxpayers' rights in the proposed new legislation, particularly section 14ZY, as this does not place a time limit on the Commissioner within which to make a decision allowing or disallowing an objection. The old legislation, by the way, did not allow this either. However, under the current section 189A, if a taxpayer, having received an objection decision from the Tax Commissioner, advises the Commissioner to refer it to either the Tribunal or the Court, and 60 days have elapsed, and the Commissioner has not complied with the request, then the taxpayer may give notice in writing to the Commissioner requiring the Commissioner to see that the referral is made and the Commissioner shall, within 60 days after receiving the notice, comply with the request.

Our amendment was not unreasonable, and I thank the Government for adopting it. Now we have virtually a 60-day lapse. Under the present proposed Government system, without this amendment, the Commissioner can take as long as he likes to make a decision on an objection with no time limits. However, we feel it is desirable to have this safeguard in terms of the old time limit set under the old section 189A, and I am pleased to see that the Government has taken our amendment on board and is using the coalition's principle. But, as I say, it will be adding a further 60 days, which is not unreasonable under the circumstances, for consideration.

We had hoped that the Government would also consider a legislative amendment to include the wording that under such circumstances no further time penalties would be applied to the taxpayer during the ATO's consideration of an objection and that the tax collection would be placed on hold during the same period. However, I believe that these circumstances are covered by what is known as an Australian Taxation Office public practice manual. The Parliamentary Secretary may see fit to table such guidelines. I believe that the tabling of those guidelines would be very reassuring to taxpayers since the Government was not prepared to put that in legislative form.

The third area of concern to the coalition is investment related lottery winnings. The banks and other financial institutions felt that they were being discriminated against and that prizes offered as incentives will now be subject to tax. The coalition has no problems with the concept that prizes given instead of interest should be taxed, but this Bill does bring prizes given as an incentive into the taxation network. However, during the referral of the Bill to the committee the Government did argue that, irrespective of whether a prize is given as an incentive or a promotion, it is still the outcome of the investment with the financial institution. The coalition has acceded only partly to this viewpoint, but we are still concerned about this proposal and that is why we are pressing our amendment.

We are also concerned about a related matter—lottery prizes that could involve UK premium bonds or other bonds issued from New Zealand which are currently held by Australian residents. I believe that these types of investments, obtained prior to the date of royal assent, should continue to be exempt because the coalition—the Liberal and National parties—has never agreed with the concept of retrospectivity.

During the second reading debate in the lower House a number of further amendments were introduced. One of the amendments agreed to the principle in my earlier private member's Bill on the realisation of a capital loss for valueless shares which I introduced and had passed in the Senate last month. Under corporations law, shareholders in companies that go into liquidation are unable to dispose of their shares unless there is approval from a court or, in some circumstances, the liquidator. In effect, these obstacles delay the realisation of any capital loss on investment until dissolution of the company. As dissolution may not occur for many years, shareholders with capital gains in the intervening period may pay more capital gains tax than in fairness they should. This inequity is aggravated because our taxation system does not permit the carry-back of losses. My private member's Bill sought to rectify that problem.

The Government has agreed to the amendments before us but has decided to tackle the problem in a slightly different way, although agreeing with the general architecture and the principles of the Bill. The Government's amendment permits the shareholder in a company in liquidation to elect to treat the share as having been disposed of and immediately required for nil consideration; that was part of my architecture. However, its requirement is that the liquidator must first make a written declaration that the liquidator has reasonable grounds to believe that there is no likelihood of the shareholder receiving any distribution in the course of the winding-up.

Unfortunately, the requirement that the liquidator make such declaration may cause such problems. Firstly, Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) does not impose a duty on liquidators to make declarations on request by shareholders. Secondly,let us consider a shareholder with a capital gain at December 1991 who holds some worthless shares in a company in liquidation at 30 June 1992. Unless the declaration from the liquidator is made by 30 June 1992, this shareholder will pay tax on the capital gain, being unable to offset the loss on those shares in the company in liquidation.

Thirdly, the shareholder's deemed disposal and resultant capital loss must be taken in the year of income in which the liquidator's declaration has been made. This may mean that shareholders will have to make the election in the year in which the declaration is made. Otherwise, if they delay in making the election until a later year, they may find that time has run out for amending the tax return for that year in which the liquidator's declaration was made.

Having to request an amendment to an earlier year's tax return is not a mechanism that promotes simplification of the tax system. Therefore, I would encourage the Government to re-examine my Bill and maybe swallow its pride and redraft the section to incorporate the original principles.

One of the problems with my Bill and the Government's Bill is that they do not provide relief to unit holders in a unit trust. Of course that is something of a problem. Further amendments are also introduced dealing with the timing of franking credits for non-mutual life companies. Industry generally supports the amendment to the dividend imputation arrangements to ensure that a franking credit is generated only by the payment of company tax and not by the issue of assessment, and the coalition agrees.

The change should provide some protection for the revenue while reducing compliance costs for most companies in respect of the operation of franking accounts. Unfortunately, the change will not reduce compliance costs for life companies despite the fact that such costs are greater for them than for other corporate taxpayers because of the operation of the special imputation rules, particularly the 80 : 20 formula. In fact, the complexities associated with the franking arrangements for life companies is no doubt the reason for the so-called technical deficiencies in the current Bill which the Government is now seeking to remove.

As was noted in the Government's supplementary explanatory memorandum, albeit in a somewhat convoluted manner, it is necessary for reducing franking credits to be recalculated on the basis of the current year's income at the time the assessment is made. In this context, reducing franking debits is a special category of debit designed to reduce the franking credits in accordance with the 80 : 20 formula.

The coalition has no concerns in relation to another part of the Bill which provides exemptions for the pay and allowances of members of the defence forces serving in Iraq and Kuwait. However, we do note concerns of some of the servicemen, particularly those resident in Western Australia, that some of the Gulf pay entitlements may not have been fully met. The extension of the research and development activities concession is also welcome.

In conclusion—time seems to have beaten us somewhat—I thank Senator McMullan for his undertaking given to the Committee hearings on this Bill in relation to the acquisition date for capital ownership costs which are included in the cost base of non-income producing assets that are acquired after 20 August 1991. These costs will not be taken into account. However, in working out a capital loss they will be eligible for indexation. That undertaking from Senator McMullan is along the lines that, if this acquisition date does cause major problems or injustices, the provisions might be amended so that they apply to all post-CGT assets whenever applied. I feel confident that Senator McMullan will uphold this undertaking. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I graduated in medicine 35 years ago from the University of Queensland. For the first half of my professional career I was proud to be a member of a profession which worked without stint for the betterment of the people of Australia. For the second half of that professional career, I have seen increasing government control and deterioration of health standards in this country. I went to the books to see why this has occurred. I am indebted to Mr Race Mathews, a member of the Australian Fabian Society, for a pamphlet he produced in 1989. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: This pamphlet updates the health care debate and democratic socialist health care delivery policies of the Whitlam years, in the light of the "Strategies for Renewal" thinking currently being developed by the Australian Fabian Society, in association with Socialist Forum and Pluto Press Australia.

PARA.TAB: The first of the pamphlet's two parts provides a broad historic overview of the events which culminated in the passage of the Medibank Bills at the 1974 Joint Sitting of the House of Representatives and the Senate, and identifies links with more recent medico-political happenings.
