The Lyons, Curtin, Chifley and Menzies experiences are reviewed, and conclusions drawn from the successful use of delaying tactics by the medical unions. The way in which Whitlam developed the Alternative National Health Programme, which later became Medibank and, later again, Medicare, is examined, with special reference to the use of questions on notice and expert advice. Acknowledgment is made of the role of inquiries into voluntary health insurance by the Senate and Mr Justice Nimmo, in legitimising Whitlam's critique and conclusions. The politicisation of the open health insurance funds is noted, as is the part played by the health care controversy in the overthrow of Gorton as Prime Minister and the downfall of the McMahon Government.

SPEECH.PARA: We are witnessing today what will occur to this Government because of the failure of the Medicare program instituted by Whitlam 18 years ago. In fact, he spoke in the 1961 Curtin Memorial lecture and said:

While the constitutional position precludes the socialisation of doctors, it permits the socialisation of hospitals—the best way to achieve a proper national health service is to establish a national hospital system.

In other words, socialist principles of collective ownership and equality underlie where we are today. Herein lay the fatal flaw of the Medicare system, based as it was on collectivism. It negated the importance of the individual and believed that the Government was stronger than the market. It ignored reality.

PARA.TAB: In 1973 the proportion of money spent on health care in this country was less than 6 per cent of gross domestic product. In 1976, with the introduction of the Medicare program, the proportion jumped to 7.5 per cent and it has been fairly static since that time. But what has happened to the individual—to you and I, the patients—in that last 18 years? The quality of health care has been deteriorating under that regime. Queues have come about. At any one time it is estimated that between 70,000 and 80,000 people are waiting for elective surgery. In my own State there is a four-year wait at some hospitals for hip replacement surgery. The capital investment in public hospitals has deteriorated to less than 3 per cent of recurrent cost.

I did a tour of the Royal Brisbane Hospital the other day and I was ashamed. I could not believe it. I was a resident there in 1957 and the only thing that had changed in some of the wards was the curtains. Instead of being on the floor on wheels, they were hung from the ceiling. I recognised the paint on the walls in some wards.

I would be ashamed to have a relative of mine—far less myself—in such surroundings, which are progressively deteriorating because during that period less and less capital expenditure has gone to the States. Has this Government got an answer? Its answer is to decrease the amount of money going to the States.

The private health sector is barely viable. The private insurance funds are unable to keep pace and many of them have dropped out of the private insurance cover field. The number is down to 46 per cent from the 70-odd per cent when this Government came into power. So, increasingly, there is a shift into the public hospital sector. What does the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) want? He wants more of the same. As he said on the 7.30 Report tonight, he wants to shift more people across.

The Minister has developed a two-tiered system of health care. The very thing that he has accused us of has developed in the last 18 years—that is, private health care is available to those who can afford it, and queues are available to those who cannot.

The Medicare levy as a proportion of Commonwealth health expenditure has progressively dropped. It is down to 18 per cent of government expenditure. Yet the poor, simple patients out there believe that by paying their Medicare levy they are entitled to health care. Tell the truth. They do not have a clue; they do not understand it. I am sure the young people in the gallery have no idea that only 18 per cent of health expenditure comes from the Medicare levy. They represent the people who are not in health insurance today because they cannot afford it. The majority of those who have health insurance are taking more out than is being contributed.

The Government's answer is rationing. But before doing so, it says, `Let's set up an inquiry'. Already $1.5m has been spent on that inquiry, and what has come out of it? First of all, the Government appointed as chairman of the inquiry a former consultant to the Health Department of Victoria. That person gave a lecture to the Mar Memorial conference. Honourable senators should not think that there was any bias. This former member—she probably still is a member—of the Australian Labor Party was appointed as a consultant to Mr Howe's Department on $80,000-odd a year, plus a car, plus superannuation. There was no bias intended—this is an inquiry to find out the facts.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were not seeking a special answer—oh, no!

—I inform Senator Walters that what the Government did next was allow consultancies in. Who did it get in as a consultant? The former Undersecretary of the Department, for a measly little sum of $528,000, was to produce a report on the hospital system.
—How much?

—An initial $528,000. But that was not enough: $80,000 was granted for a little extra consultancy which was not put out to tender. In total, $600,000-odd was spent to get an unbiased report. Where is the Government today? It is in total confusion. The answer is to reduce the amount of money going into Medicare. We have only to look at what happened in Caucus when the Government tried to do that. I am sorry Senator Crowley and Senator Walsh are not here because they led the vanguard against this and got done.

PARA.TAB: In the first year $169m was to be taken out of Medicare and $690m was to be spent over four years for the mad cities program; that is, money taken off the sick and given to the cities so that we can have better bikeways, better trees, better paths and so on. This is at a time when the population is increasing at 1.2 per cent per annum; at a time when we have a rapidly ageing population; and at a time when technology is dramatically increasing. There have been more advances in health care in my lifetime than occurred in history prior to that, and in the next 20 years there will be more advances than in my lifetime. We are facing this at a time when the Government is decreasing the amount of money to health care.

One gets conflicting statements from the Minister about the numbers of doctors. On 18 October on radio, ABC television and Channel 10 the Minister said that he wanted to remove 5,000 general practitioners from the system over a five-year period, whereas evidence given in the Estimates Committee hearing was that there are only 12,000 in Australia. The Minister will remove 5,000. The way to give better health care to people is to take 5,000 out of the system. There are only 36,000 doctors altogether in Australia and he is going to knock 5,000 out.

However, a few days before that, the Minister said he believed that that would cut overservicing; in other words, if one does not like the message—as Senator O'Chee said the other night—shoot the messenger. Then on 5 September the headline in the Australian Financial Review was `Howe threatens AMA with flood of foreign doctors'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was very original.

—The Minister at the table should listen because Mr Howe said, `We will flood the place with foreign doctors'. This is a few days before he said that we were to cut the numbers by 5,000. So we can understand his confusion on the 7.30 Report tonight; he has been confused for the last three months. Mr Howe actually threatened to lift all restrictions on the numbers of foreign doctors working in Australia.
—He is one of the looney Left.

—The looney Left still has not found out what the Minister has done to them because he has not disclosed it. He also did not declare to the Caucus committee that GP consultations in 1990-91 fell by 900,000. Dr Deeble tried to get that figure out, but he was prevented from attending the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. He was seen in Senator Zakharov's office but did not come to our Committee. It was said that he was supposed to be in Tasmania, but when we checked on that he did not have to be there at all. He had the weights put on him. That truth never came out.

PARA.TAB: The culmination has been today when the Minister attacked the coalition's health policy. My colleague in another place said that he shot himself in the foot. The Minister shot himself in the mouth tonight when he said that every family would have to pay $800 extra. He was completely wrong; he was only wrong by $2 billion! I think that from now on Mr Howe is the `$2 billion man'. Every time he gets up, the Opposition will remind him of the $2 billion inaccuracy; the $2 billion hole in his argument; the great hole that he was going to shoot.

TALK.START.PARA: —It wasn't his fault; it was the Department's.

—The coward's defence is to blame the Department and say, `It wasn't me'. In fact, Mr Howe said tonight, `Well, Bob, we are going to have to revise our figures. We are only $2 billion out'. They are the departmental figures. The coward's defence. But it goes beyond that. For example, Mr Howe said that every patient, except pensioners and health care cardholders, would be likely to pay $31 up front for every visit to a GP. Under our system, the difference in the rebate will be $4.65. Honourable senators will recall that, under the Medicare changes, there were two consultation items, six possible rebates for a GP consultation, with the introduction of the $3.50 and then the $2.50—notwithstanding whether the GP was vocationally registered—and Mr Howe says our system is confusing.

PARA.TAB: Under his system the gap will be $8.50 and under our system it will be $4.65. No wonder he does not understand it: he does not want to understand it. He also said that this would lead to the doctors charging AMA fees. They have been charging AMA fees ever since they were put out. He did not say that 70 per cent of fees charged to non-bulkbilled patients are at AMA levels or higher. That will not stop. Doctors are entitled to a fee commensurate with their training, expertise and experience.

I have never charged less than an AMA fee. Many times I have charged no fee. A third of my time has been spent at public hospitals where no fee is charged. Apart from that, patients who attend privately are not required to pay if they are in financial trouble. I could go on and on with examples of the inadequacies of the present Medicare system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Please do.

—Thank you, Senator. On Friday we debated an attempt by the Government to limit the cost of pathology. What was the answer to limiting the cost of pathology? Close down the collection centres so that people cannot have their pathology. The fact that they had to drive further to get them would not influence the Government. I picked up the paper on Friday and, as I mentioned to Senator Tate, the Prime Minister's wife was dragged into it. The paper stated:

SPEECH.PARA: "Sunday is world Aids day. So I'd like you to take this Aids test".
The Government is trying to cut down pathology and yet we have full page advertisements in the newspapers of Australia telling people—

TALK.START.PARA: —Telling them to increase it.

—Not actually saying that they should have an AIDS test. I ask: what would honourable senators think if they saw that headline? The Government's argument about limiting pathology is to close collection centres down. The next day, the paper stated:

SPEECH.PARA: "Sunday is world Aids day. So I'd like you to take an Aids test".
That is the implication. God help us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us increase pathology services.

—Yes. A pathology led recovery. Why is the current Medicare system inadequate? It is inadequate because the present system does not provide incentive for people to look after themselves. Because young people find private health insurance gives a low return for their investment, they remain in the public sector. Consequently, the elderly are faced with higher rates for health insurance which commonly prohibit them from entering the private sector. The most appropriate solution to spiralling public health bills must be to reduce the number of Australians reliant on Medicare so that it may be reserved for the genuinely needy. We must have a solid health insurance industry to cater for the needs of the massive elderly community of the twenty-first century. The impetus to increase private health insurance requires government to provide tax rebates and subsidies to lower income earners to encourage participation in the insurance scheme. I move:

PARA.TAB: At end of motion, add ", and that the Senate encourages Australians to Fightback by insuring themselves for both hospital and medical expenses".

SPEECH.PARA: There have been dramatic changes in health care in the last 18 years. As I mentioned earlier, the system was flawed because the principles were flawed. The Government's plan was to ration health care where people were not prepared to look after their health. Ration all of those people who are overweight? I could mention three honourable senators on the other side of the chamber who would qualify immediately. One does not need much of an imagination to work them out—even one reading a book at the moment could be included in that category. What about the smokers? We could influence the smokers by putting higher premiums on them. What about the drinkers—dare I say it in this environment? That is what rationing means—and people over 80 who have reached the term of their natural life? Do we not spend any more money on them? That is the obvious extrapolation of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an old mum of 88.

—She is finished under the system of the present Government. There is an answer; there is hope. The hope is the Fightback program of John Hewson. The principle is correct—it is based on freedom of choice; it is based on the freedom of individuals to look after their health care. We will retain Medicare and improve it. We will restore the balance between public and private systems by encouraging individuals to provide their own health care. Financial subsidies will be offered, and they will be heavily weighted to those with low incomes and the aged.

PARA.TAB: The clever aspect of our policy is that higher income earners who do not take private health insurance but who occupy public beds and thus deny pensioners and the disadvantaged access to those beds will be encouraged to take out private insurance. Those with family incomes of more than $50,000 per annum or $40,000 for singles will be encouraged to either take out private health insurance or pay a surcharge on the Medicare levy approximately equal to the cost of private health insurance. The amounts payable under this surcharge will be $800 per family and $400 per single. The surcharge will be completely avoided by taking out private health insurance. It will be tapered in over the preceding $5,000 of income. Insurers will be able to provide catastrophe insurance of close to half the cost of these charges.

The Government monopoly on medical insurance—that is, cover for medical items rather than hospital charges, which are already coverable under private insurance—will be discontinued. Two components will be available via the private health funds: the funds will be able to act as agents for Medicare and offer additional medical cover up to a higher schedule fee which they will negotiate with the Australian Medical Association. Gap insurance will allow the funds to offer different levels of cover up to the AMA schedule level, but they will not be allowed to rebate more than 85 per cent of the fees, leaving the patient to pay a co-payment. The other clever aspect of it is that there will be a safety net. The fees will be subject to a maximum co-payment of $30 per item or $300 per family per year.

Bulkbilling will be retained for more than four million pensioners, veterans, war widows, health care card holders and the disabled. It will no longer be available to the rest of the population. The current Medicare rebates of 85 per cent for pensioners and others who are bulkbilled will remain. The rebates for in-patient services will remain at 75 per cent. Rebates for other than in-patient services, excluding pathology which will remain at 70 per cent, will also be 75 per cent of the Medicare schedule fee.

In other words, there is a co-payment where patients will have to find the money out of their pockets and will ask the doctors, `Why are you ordering this test? Why is it necessary for me to have this test?'. At the moment, under the stupid Medicare system, there is nothing to stop patients asking for anything they like and, if they are bulkbilled, there is no restriction on the doctor ordering it. If ever we wanted to invent a crazy system, that was the way to go about it. We could not have done better to invent a system that was going to bankrupt the country than the present Medicare system.

As Senator Watson has said, the present Medicare system has allowed the exploiters, the entrepreneurs, the Edelsteins of this world to flourish, and they are still flourishing. Bulkbilling: `whack the patients through as fast as you can and bring `em back again'. I can tell Senator Collins how they function. They whack them through in six-minute consultations; they get a pathology test or x-ray done on them; and then they bring them back the next day for another consultation to give the findings of the report.

I have to laugh because they are doing this with the optometrists now. The rebate for optometrists under the new schedule will be higher than an eye specialist for a second consultation, and they are allowed four call-backs at the same high level feel for an optometrist. I do not know who is designing this up there, but I bet it is the same fellow who gave the advice to the Minister tonight. It suddenly came to me that it has to be that same man or woman. There is somebody in that Department, and I would not want to be that person at the moment because he or she is going to get shot more than in the mouth. It is going to be a bit higher up, I think. It has to be that sort of person who is doing the designing of that system with optometrists. The whole mad thing comes together when we think of those aspects of it.

Our policy is also going to continue with the principle of community rating to protect the elderly and the chronically sick in our society. There will be no reduction in services or benefits for war veterans, war widows, pensioners and welfare beneficiaries. The coalition will allow pharmacies to act as agents for Medicare. This will significantly improve access to Medicare, particularly for those living in isolated areas. The coalition has got an answer. It is based on freedom of choice; it is based on private insurance; its principles are correct—

TALK.START.PARA: —Here is Senator Crowley. Now we are in trouble.

—We are not in trouble because Senator Crowley, no doubt, will have supported the former Minister for Health, Dr Neal Blewett, who, on 11 May 1989 in delivering the E.S. Meyers memorial lecture in Brisbane, said:

SPEECH.PARA: If there is a practical political message which I want to convey, it is that the practice of medicine and its ethical aims are best served by government intervention to guarantee access to care. This tyranny of the marketplace is ultimately both more restrictive of clinical practice and inequitable in patient outcomes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Blewett will have to take out private cover under us.
—It is interesting to note that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his wife went to St Vincent's Private Hospital—
—Where did Carmel Lawrence go?

—And all the others. In my former capacity, I operated on the Leader of the Labor Party in Queensland and his Deputy, both of them at various times. They both had private rooms in the best private hospitals in Brisbane and both were insured. I questioned them as dedicated socialists about this—I was not sure which factions they were in, whether it was the left guard or the right guard or the mudguard or what; I will check with Senator Crowley later, she might know—and they both said the same thing.
—I think that is a breach of medical ethics.

—They will not mind. They are friends of mine. I have been in practice for 35 years. They said, `This style of care is what we want for all Australians'. In other words, they reinforce and support what is now current coalition policy.

—The Senate is dealing with a series of taxation Bills in a package which includes the Fringe Benefits Tax Amendment Bill 1991. I want to speak on the effect on employment in this country of excessive taxation and the effect of the Fringe Benefits Tax Act, which is rarely appreciated but is really quite considerable. I will make a few introductory remarks about the other pieces of legislation that are before the Senate. Those of us on this side of the chamber have a number of concerns with these Bills which have been outlined by my colleagues Senator Short and Senator Herron, who have spoken previously.

PARA.TAB: One of the good things about this debate is that at least these Bills are being subjected to some debate rather than being subjected to the guillotine after an hour and a half as they were in the other place. It is impossible to justify the use of a guillotine to push legislation through. Those great defenders of human rights in the Australian Labor Party are never concerned about practising human rights and justice in any way at all. They are the most consummate of totalitarian regimes.

Taxation is one of the tasks, albeit an unpleasant task, that a government has to perform to provide essential services. This Hawke Government has continued to impose on our community a taxation system which is as old and archaic as any system now left in the industrialised world. This Government will not move to a modern system such as a goods and services tax. The Government does not realise that for people to be employed we must have successful business, and to have successful business we must have profitable business. Somehow or other, the barking dogs of the Labor Party think that a profitable business is somehow unclean and unethical. So we have an ever-increasing number of bankruptcies in this country and the ever-increasing level of unemployed swelling the ranks of the CES every morning—and, of course, we have figures such as the record figures that came down today of the blow-out in the balance of payments—simply because industry cannot produce anything profitably any more under the Labor Government.

It is no wonder the business community was very pleased with the Fightback package, which promises to take $20 billion—I emphasise that figure—and remove seven different taxes from the tax burden presently on Australian business. Unfortunately, it will be a while yet before we can have an election and get rid of this Government. What we will do is really of little comfort to those people who make up the 50 per cent increase in bankruptcies this year, many of whom have been sent bankrupt by the policies and the inadequate legislation that is coming from this Government.

I move to the fringe benefits tax. I voted against that tax when it came in and I am as opposed to it today as I was then. I am opposed to it because it offends a very important principle in our community. Our policy with respect to taxation has always been that those who receive the benefit pay the tax. Because the Labor Party lacked the backbone and because it lacked any courage and principle, it taxed the donors of the benefit rather than the recipients of it. We have this shameful system where we have a fringe benefits tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eh!

—Although the fringe benefits tax has been in operation for years, all the smarties, all the yuppies and all the Labor Party trendy Left voters around Sydney and Melbourne are paying tax on about $35,000 to $40,000 a year and receiving a benefit of about $150,000 on the merchant banks. In other words, the fringe benefits tax simply has not worked; the smarties have beaten it.

PARA.TAB: The area where the fringe benefits tax has really bitten is rural Australia. I speak here with some feeling as a rural producer. The fringe benefits tax has been most unfair for the rural community. It has led to increases in unemployment and a lost situation for a number of rural producers. I emphasise the point that Senator Collins, with his limited perception, has difficulty understanding. The smarties in the city have unofficially lowered their taxable income to moderate rates and transferred the payment for their income to the companies. It is not only the companies that are paying the tax but also, at the end of the day, the shareholders in the company who are paying a tax which really should be paid by the employees. The fringe benefits tax is grossly unfair on those grounds alone.

The Government is proposing to alter the rates of the fringe benefits tax. I refer here to country producers. Many people could be employed on country properties if the owners or the operators of the properties were not slugged with this fringe benefits tax.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Senator Herron's speech on the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill earlier he made a claim that Dr Deeble had been seen in my office not long before he had asked to be a witness before the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, which was looking at legislation. At no time since I have been in this place, since 1983, has Dr Deeble been in my office. My only contact with him during that week was, quite properly, as Chair of the Committee trying to sort out the program for that hearing. Whoever has given the information to Senator Herron is either in error or mischievous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak in the adjournment debate tonight about the AIDEX exhibition held in Canberra last week.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not surprisingly, the media emphasised confrontation outside AIDEX and totally ignored the point of impact conference. Honourable senators opposite might learn something different if they listen to this instead of interjecting all the time. The point of impact parallel conference was held at the ANU at the same time as AIDEX. This conference was held to draw attention to the people at the receiving end of the military equipment being peddled at the National Exhibition Centre. The speakers came from Fiji, Bougainville, East Timor, the Philippines and Sri Lanka—all countries which have been associated with Australia in recent years through the defence cooperation program or military exports. They spoke of the devastating effects of the military on their society—of the military coup in Fiji; of the blockade of Bougainville; of Indonesian military repression and the death of one-third of the population of East Timor since 1975, as well as the more recent massacres on which a lot of attention has been focused; of President Aquino's policy of total war in the Philippines; and of the devastation of civil war in Sri Lanka.

PARA.TAB: I am not surprised that the media ignored their moving testimonies, preferring to concentrate on the negative side of the campaign against AIDEX and the arms trade. I would like to pay tribute to the Australian Quaker Peace Committee and the Peace Research Centre at the ANU, which organised the point of impact conference, and to Penny Duckworth who worked to prepare for that conference over the last three months.

It is hard for Australians to understand what it is like to live under military rule or to know what a war is like when it is going on around people or directed at them as an ethnic minority or because they are poor and landless. That is outside the recent experience of most Australians. The men in suits at AIDEX admiring the video clips, looking at the models of submarines and missiles or picking up the glossy literature probably have no idea of what it is like to be at the receiving end of their products. Some reports have made out that there were very few offensive weapons on display at AIDEX but it is worth pointing out that wars since Vietnam have been fought more and more on the electronic battlefield and the men who kill often cannot see their targets. Of course, we heard about that during the Gulf war.

Computers and defence electronics are just as lethal as a gun or a cluster bomb on the electronic battlefield. Nor can the front-end offensive capability function without the non-lethal equipment such as boots, tents, blankets, catering packs, mats, Land Rovers, armoured cars and so on. They are all part of the killing machine when contracts are let to the military. They are just as necessary to a war as the bullets and bayonets. It has been argued that equipment is defensive. This ignores the fact that if we invent something such as a radar system or an anti-submarine warfare device, the other side then sets out to invent something to evade it, such as the Stealth bomber or quieter submarines. This encourages the arms trade.

Another international aspect of the protest against AIDEX comes in the form of letters of support from other countries. I will quote from just one of those letters which came from Germany, although other letters from Norway, France, Britain and Germany came to organisers here. I will quote just one paragraph of the letter from this organisation in Germany, the Kampagne `Produzieren fur das Leben', headed `Protest Statement Against "AIDEX 91"'. The final paragraph says:

SPEECH.PARA: We appeal to your government: stop "AIDEX 91" immediately! We support the campaign "Stop AIDEX". In the event that your government allows "AIDEX 91" to take place, we are resolved to take further actions of protest and pressure against your country, for example a boycott of Australian products.
It is not just Australians who are concerned about this; it is people in other countries as well.

PARA.TAB: I mention Professor Roland Simbulan from the Philippines—one of the point of impact speakers brought here for the conference last week—who brought testimonies from 11 cause-oriented coalitions protesting against AIDEX in the Philippines. I will read the names of these organisations to give the Senate an idea of the kinds of groups that have to organise against the level of militarism which is really devastating for the people in that country.

There was the Protestant Lawyers League of the Philippines; Promotion of Church People's Rights; Children's Rehabilitation Centre—many children suffer the devastating impact of militarisation in that country; Medical Action Group, Inc.; Children in War: The Filipino Perspective; Alliance of Advocates for Indigenous Peoples Rights; the Justice and Peace Commission; Repressions and Violations of Peasant Rights in the 90's: Forum for Rural Concerns; the Citizens Disaster Rehabilitation Centre, Inc.; the Philippine Alliance of Human Rights Advocates; and the Society of Ex-detainees for Liberation Against Detention and for Amnesty. They are the groups in the Philippines which sent very moving testimonies asking that the Australian Government not support AIDEX.
I will read just part of one of those testimonies which comes from the Protestant Lawyers League of the Philippines. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that the AIDEX `91 will only serve to encourage governments like that of Mrs. Corazon Aquino to increase their military or defense spending on the pretext of upgrading their defense capabilities. In our case, the truth of the matter remains that the "defense capabilities" our government is talking about does not refer to the defense against external aggressors. It is meant to support its anti-insurgency program and prop up its military capability against the local insurgents that had existed for twenty three years now. The tragedy behind these modern and sophisticated arms lies on the fact that most often than not they are procured by governments to pursue military solutions to the internal political and social problems confronting them. Of late, the Philippine government declared a "Total War" policy against the insurgents that led into a phenomenon called "Internal Refugees" when some one million Filipinos were driven out of their towns, villages and homes during and after military offensives. . . harassments, intimidation, arrests and detentions and caused untold death and destruction of lives and properties.

The story goes on. There are one million internal detainees in the Philippines, and I believe our Government has to take some responsibility for aiding and abetting that situation by providing defence cooperation and training to the Philippines military. A further paragraph of the statement states:

For these reasons, the arms exhibition of AIDEX `91 is a shame to humanity for it exhibits and sells instruments of death and destruction and thereby violates the very rights of peoples to life and dignity.
I think we really have to take this very seriously and acknowledge some responsibility.

PARA.TAB: I now move to the portrayal of AIDEX protesters in the last week. AIDEX organisers, the media and the police tell only part of the story. For example, a Channel 7 news report last Wednesday night stated, `Violence was interrupted by a wedding at the gates of AIDEX, and then it was back to business—scuffles and clashes', et cetera. I was very deeply offended by that news report. It was blatantly untrue. That situation did not occur at AIDEX that day, and I know because I was there. I was there when the wedding took place in the afternoon and there certainly were not scuffles and people did not go back to the business of violence after the wedding, as the voice-over had indicated. When people at Channel 7 were challenged about this, they said they did not have time to fuss with the details. The footage that had been shown as though it had taken place after that ceremony had, in fact, taken place before it and they said that that was a mere detail. They were not concerned about the truth.

This has been fairly typical of the media representation of what went on out there and, unfortunately, of some of the people who used the media and believed what the police told them without getting the other side of the story. There are always at least two sides to every story. The AIDEX organisers would have us believe that the situation was much worse and that there was a lot of violence outside the gates. They did not bother to listen to the people who were outside exercising their democratic rights to protest.

Sir William Keys, former President of the RSL, in which capacity I think he did a good job, was stereotyping the protesters, calling them thugs and accusing them of acting like terrorists. I think that is highly irresponsible for somebody in his position. He was, of course, employed by AIDEX as one of its public relations persons. To have exaggerated in the way he did hardly did its cause a good service, although, as I said, a lot of people believed him and believed the media, and that was grossly unfair.

A great cross-section of society formed the 1,000 or so people who were protesting at AIDEX. For example, the Western Australian contingent included three grandmothers, a barrister who is also a minister of the Uniting Church and who was prepared to stand up for his principles and get arrested twice at the gates of AIDEX, a Catholic community worker, a university lecturer, a mother of four, a mother of someone who had been detained by the authorities in South Africa for many years, and other younger people in full time employment. That is a representative sample of the Western Australian group. There was not one person from the Western Australian group who fitted Sir William Keys's stereotype negative imaging.

On Monday last week, when I was arrested —and I was proud to be there with the protesters and proud to be arrested committing civil disobedience at the gates of AIDEX—I was put in a cell with 13 other women for about five hours. There again, no-one fitted the negative image and stereotyping that Sir William Keys was so keen to portray. That was a random sample of people who were arrested by the police in any old order, thrown into a paddy-wagon and then thrown into a police cell for five hours. All of the inmates of that cell were employed people or people who had just finished university exams. There were professional young women and some older women, as well as another Catholic worker, a nun and another grandmother—all kinds of people were involved in that protest. To hear Sir William Keys carry on about it, one would think that everybody there was, as he said, a thug acting like a terrorist. It is highly offensive.

Very few of all the protesters there used any verbal violence or physical violence against the police. I do not support either. But open public demonstrations cannot choose the cast, any more than anybody here could choose all the company at a football match. No-one wants to be held responsible for all types of behaviour in any large crowd. We should not be assuming guilt by association. Everyone there was united against AIDEX. They had a strong commitment to being there. I commend all those who were prepared to be out there in difficult circumstances making a strong witness against weapons, a strong witness against the trade in these deadly weapons, as we have heard evidenced by the people in the Philippines and all the other speakers at the point of impact conference begging Australia to desist from trading in these weapons of death, because they know the point of impact and the suffering that is caused.

All the protesters at the AIDEX gates were camped in very difficult situations. For example, there were no showers, so of course some of them did look scruffy. So what? Let us talk about the real terrorists, the ones who sell the weapons and the ones who use the weapons. They are terrorists. I beg to differ in the strongest possible terms with Sir William Keys for casting all the protesters in a very negative light and daring to call them terrorists and say they were behaving like thugs.

The resolve of the protesters was firm and to be appreciated rather than abused, especially when so many people in our society do not seem to care much about anything. The protesters care very deeply about the future of the planet and work towards a better world for future generations everywhere. Some of them were angry and some were alienated youth who feel that in so many ways society is failing them. But, as the Reverend Neville Watson said—he was one of the protesters; the barrister to whom I referred before and who was arrested twice—it is better to be angry than apathetic. I agree. Whilst I do not agree with all the tactics of all the protesters, I do applaud their dedication.

I doubt whether some of the stereotypical claims of organisers and police are true. I know for a fact one claim is wrong, and that is that faeces was spread on the faces of the demonstrators. I have already referred to that in the Senate earlier today. It was ochre—o-c-h-r-e; mud—which was spread on the faces of a few of the protesters for sun protection. A lot of the sun protectors that you get out of tubes and bottles are actually very harsh on sensitive skin. It is very expensive, too, for people who might be on the dole, so a few people had mud smeared on them. There was none of the other stuff around.

The best kind of non-violent protest, of course, is one where all the protesters agree to abide by certain rules. This did not happen at this site, and perhaps it should have. I would like to mention one of the best protests I have ever been involved with, and I have been involved in quite a few. This was at the Nevada test site in the United States in 1987. There were 3,000 people camped out in the desert and 800 people got arrested in an incident of mass civil disobedience. It was highly organised. Anybody who was wanting to commit civil disobedience had to be prepared to sign a statement that they would not break certain rules which had been agreed to beforehand by a large group of organisers. The rules included such things as no verbal abuse, no physical abuse, no drugs, no alcohol, no running and no unexpected activities. The police had been told in advance that this protest, this mass civil disobedience, this mass commission of trespass, was to take place. They were well prepared for it, as were the protesters. The best kind of non-violent civil disobedience occurs where there is police liaison.

There was quite a lot of police liaison before the activities outside AIDEX last week. The protesters were very disappointed that the police either seemed to disregard what they had been told in advance or were prepared to follow different orders once the protest got under way. This protest would have been more peaceful had it been organised more like that one in Nevada. But there is, with a minority of groups attending, a resistance to rules even though they have been worked out beforehand by a representative cross-section of participants. So it was not a perfect protest. Hardly anything is perfect in this life. But it certainly made the point that many Australians are strongly opposed to the deadly trade in weapons.

It is important to point out, as I have mentioned, that the individuals did not fit the Sir William Keys stereotype. Neither did the groups. There were church groups there, women's groups, peace groups, people concerned to see foreign aid spent on development rather than on defence cooperation, trade unions, and young people, of course, so there were all kinds of individuals and groups represented.

Unfortunately, once there was a violent incident the police became the enemy in the minds of some people. The police had a difficult job to do and I regret the injuries which some of them suffered. There was also a very long list of injuries suffered by the protesters, and many statutory declarations have been made against the police who used unnecessary force to remove demonstrators. These claims need to be investigated. A long list of allegations was presented to Senator Tate this afternoon by Senator Spindler and Senator Childs; two of the organisers, Jan and Jacob Grech; and me.

One of the most telling and poignant of these statutory declarations was that of Sean Kenan, a community worker in Canberra who has worked for quite a long time with young unemployed people, assisting them to be more positive in their attitudes to life. He has been doing all the kinds of things, that I am sure everybody in this chamber would appreciate and would applaud, in his work with unemployed youth. He was given particularly harsh treatment by the police, who seemed to have singled him out. They knew his name; they knew they wanted to get him, as they said. They threatened that he would be `dead meat', and they used all kinds of violent language against him as he was in the paddy wagon and in the police cells where he was held on his own for many hours. People trying to find where he was were given a different story by the police every time they phoned. They were told he had been released, which was not true. He was threatened with being taken to ward 12B at Woden Valley Hospital, which is the psychiatric ward. He did not end up there, thank goodness, but he did end up at Calvary Hospital. He was very shaken by the experience and he suffered a lot of pain that was deliberately inflicted on him by police officers in the cells.

These allegations need very careful investigation. We have the word of the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, that the Ombudsman will conduct a thorough investigation. Obviously there needs to be better training in non-violence on both sides. Each group should refrain from stereotyping the other.

As well as the confrontations, there were many good moments between police and protesters and between protesters and AIDEX officials. A lot of humanising interaction was necessary and it did happen. But that is not the stuff of which media reports are made. Unfortunately, I have to point out the hypocrisy of the AIDEX promoters. The offer by Sir William Keys in the Canberra Times last Tuesday, saying that critics were welcome to go on a guided tour of the exhibition centre, was not honoured.

I was one person who was denied access to the Exhibition Centre—on the word, evidently, of Mr Bob Day, the Desiko organiser. For some reason or other, he took a personal exception to me and did not want me to be there, despite the fact that I am an elected representative of the people and I am a member of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade of the Parliament. He decided that it was not appropriate for me to enter his precious exhibition so I was not allowed to go in. The offer by Sir William Keys was dishonoured by the organisers. The following day, which was last Wednesday, Sir William Keys was quoted in the Canberra Times berating Rosemary Follett and other members of the ACT Government for not going in to inspect his precious exhibition, yet still I was denied entry.

Despite the media, the organisers and the police telling only part of the story, the protest was very successful. I want to mention a few of the ways in which it was successful. Entry to the site was limited and in some cases possible only when the police cut the fences to get the display material into the grounds. I presume that police officers will be held responsible for repairing the fence which they had to cut.

It is very interesting that there has been a call for the protesters to remove the ribbons, streamers, balloons and decorations which were placed on the gates of the Natex site by the women's protest last Wednesday. I think that it was Senator Campbell who made this call. He had to admit that it did look very attractive, but he said that the protesters should go out and clean up. I wonder whether he would be so concerned about the war makers cleaning up every last item of their debris after a war. I can hardly imagine that they would go around and pick up every shell, nail and other leftover of war, to say nothing of the bits and pieces of human bodies that are thrown around on a battlefield. Let us get things into perspective.
Secondly, the protesters maintained a constant witness against this obscene trade fair for its entire duration. It was very important that they did that; that was the main purpose of being there.

Thirdly, exhibitor numbers were way down on predicted figures. There were 200 exhibitors at AIDEX 89. This year, 25 per cent more were expected; that is what the promoters were boasting about. However, there were only 148 stalls, 25 per cent fewer than last time. On the other hand, the protest outside was about twice as large as in 1989. On the outside we had a lot more opposition and on the inside we had a much smaller exhibition.

Further, the organisers will surely think twice about staging another exhibition in Australia, despite the bold statements of Mr Bob Day since the event finished. The Australian Capital Territory seems to be out. The ACT Assembly, which voted by a majority not to allow another AIDEX exhibition on ACT territory, is again to be congratulated. If the organisers try to take the exhibition to other cities there will be more protests. They will be bigger and the exhibitors will be put off even more than they were this time.

There has also been a suggestion that Commonwealth land—for example, Fairbairn air base—could be used so that the Army could handle crowd control. But this suggestion should be discounted because the Federal Government would be implicated far too much. It has been trying to back-pedal as hard as it could this time to distance itself because of community opposition. For example, the comment by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mr Bilney, that the Government is neither endorsing nor not endorsing AIDEX is quite ridiculous. He has been listening to the US Navy too much. It was a classic `neither confirm nor deny' statement, which is not good enough for an Australian government Minister.

Another victory for the protesters was the point that the police mucked up the arrest procedures. They were made to look foolish by using a common law dictate that arrestees should be bound over for breaches of the peace. The definition of `breach of the peace' is unclear and the police realised that they could not prove that each arrestee had been about to breach the peace. Obviously the charge should have been something more tangible if the police wanted to arrest all of those people. No doubt they will be evaluating the effectiveness or otherwise of their tactics, especially in the areas of legal options and non-violence training.

Another point about the exhibition itself is that some of the stands were not complete. The exhibitors did not manage to get all their information inside the Natex grounds on time. I know that people who went to see models and asked for particular things which had been advertised were told that certain demonstration models were not available and that, unfortunately, all the information that was sought could not be provided because the computer links had not been completed on time for the opening of the exhibition.

It will be interesting to see the figures that the AIDEX promoters come up with in respect of the transactions. This will be very difficult to prove because many of the transactions, many of the deals in these weapons of death, are done over time after the exhibition rather than on the site itself.

As an arrestee, I want to recall how intimidating it was last Monday to be demonstrating within my legal rights as a citizen on a roadway, which is a public place. When I joined the blockade at the secondary gate we were suddenly surrounded by hundreds of police. I believe that about 250 police arrived on buses. Then the tactical response group came trotting up behind in formation. I found myself thinking that this really was a police state. It was a horrible moment. I never expected to feel quite so intimidated by police in this country.

I saw the operations support group, which is really the correct terminology for the group that people generally refer to as the tactical response group, acting in a very provocative manner on several occasions. For example, on Wednesday afternoon two of the organisers who had decided to make their wedding vows outside the gates of AIDEX were interrupted when the tactical response group came trotting up, again in formation, to disperse the crowd. This was totally unnecessary and absolutely provocative. The police person in charge gave the protesters five minutes to leave the road.

People would have left the road. In fact, the side of the road was open. There was quite enough room for traffic to pass by anyway. But, no, the police had to make a big show of force and come in to say, `Five minutes and you have all got to clear the site'. As I said, this was unnecessary. People were pretty hot and thirsty after having been out on the road for a couple of hours. They would have moved along anyway. That was the kind of totally unnecessary provocation which I think the police could have done well not to have indulged in. It certainly has not improved the reputation of police handling of protesters, many of whom were young people who will go away with a very negative image of police management of such an event. I think that is a great shame all around.

Finally, I want to pay tribute to fellow Quakers who had a stall inside the exhibition, as they did in 1989, and to Kim Meredith in particular, who organised the roster and got the displays ready. The Quakers were displaying an absolute commitment to total non-violence. Of course, I support that and alternatives to war. It is very important to make that protest right inside the belly of the beast as they were doing.

I commend the act of resistance to militarism. There is an urgent need for more people to understand the concepts of active resistance, which is very different from passive resistance, and civil disobedience as well as lawful patient lobbying. A lot of that has gone on in the two years since the last AIDEX exhibition in 1989. At least 15,000 signatures have been presented here, for example. Fifty-one parliamentarians from parliaments all around the country were prepared to make a statement opposing AIDEX and calling on the Government to withdraw its support. So a great deal of lawful and patient lobbying went on, as well as the protest at the gates.

The Government was promised that the exhibition would be massively disrupted and so it was. If it is stupid enough to allow another exhibition to go ahead, it will again be massively disrupted and even more so—but I hope in a total spirit of non-violence next time.

In the spirit of peace and with genuine commitment to the transforming power of love, my hope is that the Australian Government will finally listen to the community concern, expressed in so many ways, and that it will never again promote, endorse or encourage in any way—not even to the tune of $66,000—another weapons trade exhibition in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to spend a few minutes outlining the work of a man I had the privilege to meet a few months ago. As people come face to face with the reality of unemployment, they also face total enforced leisure. Where people work in one or several part time jobs, finances may be limited and leisure time lengthy. Some people are tempted to take their limited money to a gambling venue to try to win enough to pay the power bill or another necessity.

PARA.TAB: Radio, television and lifestyle advertising promotes the stimulating urge to spend money, to buy fun, excitement and romance. Some people are particularly susceptible to advertising messages that invite people to participate in a gambling event and `experience the thrill of winning'. But as we all know, one does not always win.

The Reverend John Tully, a minister of the Uniting Church in Australia, who has been working outside a parish and without a church stipend since 1985, wrote a letter to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in December 1988 suggesting that State governments which license, promote and tax gambling activities ought to invest money in educational programs of the same size and vigour as the tobacco, alcohol and drug programs. The Tribunal initiated an inquiry and released a report in July 1989. It decided not to enforce the placement of educational and health warnings on advertisements. It did, however, state:

The Tribunal is in no doubt that the aim of betting and gambling advertisements on television and radio is to encourage members of the public to use the services of casinos, clubs, lottery commissions, TABs and such like and, in doing so, to part with their money in the hope of a return on their investment. Nor is there any doubt that the betting and gambling industry is a large employer of labour and a large contributor to general revenue. The Tribunal also accepts that compulsive gambling is a severe problem with serious repercussions for the individual and society in general.

SPEECH.PARA: As more people in our society have increased leisure time available to them, it appears that gambling will increase. We are consistently warned of the dangers surrounding the alcoholic and the drug addict, yet no-one warns us of the hazards of compulsive gambling. Just the reverse occurs. We are tempted and encouraged to gamble to the degree where we are considered wowsers if we do not have a bet of sorts.

PARA.TAB: In December 1986 the Salvation Army in Sydney conducted a phone-in seeking response from compulsive gamblers and/or their families. There were 352 callers. A brief analysis of the result is as follows: 75 per cent had lost all their savings; 67 per cent reported family disruption due to gambling; 61 per cent reported outstanding gambling debts—$20,860 was the average debt and this represents an average 49 weeks income, as revealed by 89 informants; 19 per cent reported criminal involvement due to gambling; and 7 per cent revealed that they had been to prison for gambling related crime.

The Reverend John Tully previously worked on his family's farm growing sugarcane, a few vegetable crops and dairying. He later worked as a public servant with the New South Wales Department of Agriculture. With his wife Annette and his three sons he served the church in many areas of New South Wales and the Gold Coast before resigning from parish work in 1984. In 1985 he established the registered charity, New Life Ministry at Street Level Inc. It was with this organisation that I had the privilege of spending some time with John Tully last month when we met numbers of unemployed people in the community.

I am one of the many people who, like John Tully, are not against gambling or casinos, but I believe that the casualties of the gambling industry must be considered, especially those who cannot afford to gamble. John is a foundation member of the Australian Council on Compulsive Gambling. He is also a foundation member of the National Association of Gambling Studies. These two bodies are able to make the community aware of some of the things that it should know concerning the plight of the families and friends of those who suffer from `pathological gambling', as it has officially been described in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual 1980 of the American Psychiatric Association.

The Reverend John Tully has written a book entitled Breaking the Losing Run. It is a self-help book for the gambler and family and, as such, is unique. I commend the book to the chamber and I shall personally see that a copy is placed in the Parliamentary Library. One very troubled man wrote to Reverend Tully after reading and re-reading a copy of his book:

SPEECH.PARA: I have been a gambler for many years. I have never had anyone teach me so much about gambling. Please make more of these books. Tell people to read this book before it is too late for them, like it was for me.
One parent recently expressed to Reverend Tully:
If I had the knowledge that you have now given me ten years ago, my son would not be in the trouble that he is in today.
Another person said:
The manuscript of your book has given me the key that helped me take control of my life. I like the
new me. My children like the new me. My marriage has been remade.
All the proceeds of sales go to the work of the New Life Ministry At Street Level Inc., a non-profit charitable group.

PARA.TAB: It is important that we acknowledge the social extent of this recession. This book attempts to do that and paints a realistic picture of life in the real world. Moderation in all things is a well-worn but sensible sentiment. I commend the Reverend Tully for the work he does and for the many families he has brought back together.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, upon notice, on 15 August 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Are the South Melbourne and Elsternwick Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) offices being considered for closure; if so: (a) has a decision on the possible closure of either office yet been reached and what are the intended dates of closure; (b) what are the reasons for such a consideration; and (c) what are the stated reasons for closure.
(2) Are either or both of these offices presently co-located with regional offices of the Department of Social Security.
(3) How many people are currently registered as unemployed awaiting placement, at each of the CES offices.

(4) Was more than $500,000 recently spent on refurbishing the South Melbourne CES office; if so: (a) what total sum was spent by the Commonwealth on the most recent refurbishment of the South Melbourne CES office; and (b) when was the refurbishment completed.
(5) Which CES offices have been closed in Victoria during the past 24 months.
(6) When were these offices closed.
(7) What were the stated reasons for closure.
(8) When were each of these offices last refurbished or fitted out and, for each office, what was the total cost of the refurbishment or fit-out.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The South Melbourne Office is being considered for closure, but no final decision has yet been taken. The Office was originally set up as a vacancy-servicing office. In recent years the business levels at the Office have decreased due to a large number of manufacturing industries moving out of the South Melbourne area. In the main the white collar industries which replaced them (for example advertising industries) do not tend to utilise the CES to the same extent.

ANSWER.PARA: As the business levels of the South Melbourne CES have been declining the business levels at nearby Elsternwick, St Kilda and Melbourne Offices have been increasing. Consideration is thus being given to the best use of available resources in the light of these changing patterns of demand.

PARA.TAB: (2) Neither office is currently co-located with a regional office of the Department of Social Security.
(3) Statistics on the number of people registered with the CES as unemployed awaiting placement are not released.

(4) Some refurbishments at a total cost of $182,000 were completed in April 1991. Subsequent to the refurbishment, however, it became evident that recent rapid changes in the Melbourne metropolitan labour market would necessitate some changes in CES representation at South Melbourne and surrounding areas in order to provide the most effective service for clients.

This Office closed on 13 December 1990 due to occupational health and safety reasons, such as fire danger and a lack of proper egress facilities. No refurbishment or changes to fit-out occurred in this Office.
This Office closed on 27 December 1990 as part of the refocussing of services to clients following the Client Services Review. No refurbishment or changes to fit-out occurred in this Office.

This Office closed on 29 March 1991, following proposals to refocus services under the client services reforms. Ultimately, the building owner refused to renew the lease and eviction followed. The Office was not refurbished.

This Branch Office closed on 21 December 1990. The Office was located in a rented "porta hut" at the rear of the Town Hall. The hut offered totally inadequate servicing facilities to both staff and clients, including: no security or privacy; cramped conditions/no waiting area; poor air-conditioning system; limited access to other shared facilities; and, inefficient use of staffing resources. The Office was not refurbished.

This Office, which operated three days per week, was closed on 30 June 1991. The Office was replaced by a CES agency as this arrangement provided a more effective use of resources and better services for clients. Specifically, the agency provides a job brokerage function, with specialised servicing available from the Industry Service Centre, the Youth Access Centre and the Special Services Centre at Shepparton. The Kyabram Part-time Branch Office had not been refurbished.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 20 August 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why has Telecom Australia procrastinated for many months over its decision to award compensation to former employees, Mr Daniel Moffat (59), Mr Johan Neinkemper (65) and Mr John Edwards (48), all of whom are now suffering from the asbestos-related disease, mesothelioma.

(2) For what length of time is Telecom Australia permitted to investigate the relationship between Mr Daniel Moffat and Mr Johan Nienkemper's mesothelioma disease and their work for Telecom in asbestos pits.
(3) When was the last time Telecom Australia granted compensation to a former employee proven to be suffering from an asbestos-related disease.
(4) What percentage of claims for compensation in relation to asbestos-related disease has Telecom paid out to date.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from Telecom:

PARA.TAB: (1) Telecom denies that it has procrastinated over the determination of its liability under the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 (CERC) in respect of claims by Messrs Moffat, Neinkemper and Edwards.

A determination was issued by Telecom on 24 January 1991 denying liability for his compensation claim. Medical reports received by Telecom do not indicate the probable causes of Mr Edward's condition. Mr Edwards also stated that he was unable to determine the exact location of contact with asbestos in the course of his employment with Telecom.
A request for reconsideration of the above decision was submitted by Mr Edwards on 13 February 1991.
The Determination of 24 January 1991 was affirmed by Telecom on 28 June 1991. Mr Edwards has unfortunately since died.

A determination was issued by Telecom on 7 June 1991 denying liability for his compensation claim in respect of mesothelioma. The report from Mr Moffat's treating doctor does not indicate that Mr Moffat's employment with Telecom contributed in a material degree to his medical condition. A further report from the Royal Hospital did not offer any evidence which linked employment with Telecom to Mr Moffat's ailment.
Mr Moffat was advised of the outcome through his solicitors, Slater and Gordon, who are preparing a request for reconsideration.

Mr Neinkemper's claim in relation to work related mesothelioma was first made on 15 August 1990 as a request of retirement invalidity. Telecom required time to fully investigate the claim and obtain expert medical opinion on the medical documentation supplied by Mr Neinkemper. Telecom has since made a determination on 29 August 1991 and advised Mr Neinkemper that it will accept liability for his condition of malignant pleural mesothelioma.

(2) The CERC does not prescribe a time within which Telecom must make a determination of liability. Telecom must be allowed sufficient time to fully investigate any claim made by an employee that is allegedly employment related and, whilst every endeavour is made to meet internally imposed time limits, more complex claims make this impracticable.

(3) and (4) At this time, Telecom has no central records or database which records details of compensation claims by former employees. Telecom is therefore unable to address this question without first canvassing all its local operational areas and undertaking an extensive time-consuming investigation of all the compensation files held by those areas. I do not propose to ask Telecom to undertake such a task as Telecom is currently enhancing the database with a view to recording details of this nature. It will be some months, however, before Telecom is in a position to provide information in relation to compensation claims by former employees.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 14 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Currently, are any Australia Post agencies permitted to open on Saturday; if so, how does Australia Post determine those which are allowed to open.

(2) Under the Government's Retail Post scheme, will postal agencies such as the one in Richmond, Queensland, be allowed to open on Saturday mornings, if the manager of the agency deems it profitable to do so.
(3) When does the Government expect the new scheme to be introduced in so far as it affects the ability of agencies, like the one at Richmond, to open on Saturday mornings.
(4) In the interim, will the Government take any measures to ensure that the citizens of towns such as Richmond have access to postal services on Saturday mornings.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Land Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Currently, some 1,285 (41 per cent) of post office agencies provide service to customers on Saturday mornings. The criteria for agencies to provide service on Saturday mornings is:
Country agencies—5 or more customers
Metropolitan agencies—10 or more customers.
(2) Yes. Under the Retail Post concept, individual agency managers will be able to determine whether they wish to open on Saturday mornings.
(3) It is anticipated that the Retail Post concept, as far as it affects post office agencies, will be introduced on 2 March 1992.

(4) Under present arrangements, it is considered that the volume of business likely to be transacted at the Richmond post office agency on Saturday morning would not justify the costs incurred in providing the service.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 7 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Direction given by the Department of Industrial Relations to the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) in its determination of redundancy arrangements, to refuse to recognise prior service with the Defence Forces as contributing towards continuous Commonwealth service for redundancy purposes:
(1) Why has the Minister refused to make himself available to meet the small committee of CAA ex-military officers who want to discuss this issue with him.
(2) Will the Minister give an undertaking to meet with the CAA committee before a final decision is made.
(3) Why does the Minister believe service in the Defence Force is not service to the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) It is simply not possible for Ministers to personally meet with all persons or groups from whom they receive representations. It is however essential that all representations are fully and fairly considered and responded to. This has occurred in this case.

On 21 August 1991 a member of my ministerial office—directly representing me and reporting back to me—together with a representative of the Department of Industrial Relations met with the group of ex-military officers to provide an opportunity for the group to represent the matter. At that meeting an opinion was provided by the group which sought to argue that there were grounds for challenging the policy position adopted by the Government. At the conclusion of the meeting it was agreed that further consideration would be given to this matter and a view provided on the information put forward.
On 16 September 1991 further discussions were held with representatives of the group and an officer of the Department of Industrial Relations to enable further representations to be made.
On 11 November 1991 the group was provided with a detailed report from the Department of Industrial Relations on the information tendered at the 21 August 1991 meeting.

My Office then suggested that after the group had considered this information a further meeting would be convened between the Department of Industrial Relations at senior level and the group to discuss outstanding matters and to clarify remaining concerns. This meeting took place on 26 November 1991. As a result, the Department of Industrial Relations is considering further matters pertaining to this case and will inform the group within two weeks.
I have given detailed consideration to the outcomes of these meetings.

(2) Every opportunity has already been provided to the group to represent this matter and I have given detailed consideration to the issue. I have taken all of the material and representations from the group into account in reviewing this matter. I do not now propose to meet personally with the group.
(3) I have never stated that service in the Defence Force is not service to the Commonwealth.

The Government position is that service with other Commonwealth employing authorities, including the Defence Forces, is recognised as service for redundancy provided that it is continuous service and the service with a former employer was not terminated because of voluntary retirement at or above the minimum retiring age applicable to the employee. Receipt of retirement superannuation benefits is a conclusive indicator of age retirement.

Where a former defence employee has retired, having reached the minimum retiring age, and is in receipt of a superannuation pension for that service, it is unacceptable to allow the employee to count that service again for redundancy purposes and thus enable double counting.

Recognition of service with other Commonwealth employers is a concession made for staff who have taken up further Commonwealth employment without having received any benefits from the previous employer, other than resignation benefits.

Prior service is recognised only where the method of termination of that service was consistent with an expectation of continued employment with the Commonwealth and receipt of a superannuation benefit is evidence that there was no expectation of continuing Commonwealth employment.

Having regard to the above factors and the fact that CAA has reached agreement with the unions on a memorandum of understanding which is consistent with Government policy in this area, it would be unconscionable to allow the CAA employees to double count the prior Defence service when they are in receipt of a pension for that service.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 11 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Were all the scheduled World Ocean Experiments conducted during the recent Aurora Australis voyage?
(2) Did the winch operate to its full capacity during the voyage?
(3) Was the CTD damaged as a result of hitting the ocean bottom?

(4) Have any Antarctic dogs recently escaped from their line and killed seals at an Australian Antarctic base; if so, how many seals were killed and what action has been taken to prevent a similar occurrence?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The science program undertaken on the recent Aurora Australis voyage was reduced because of severe weather conditions and problems with the oceanographic winch at the start of the voyage. However, the scheduled first oceanographic transect between Tasmania and Antarctica as part of Australia's contribution to the World Ocean Circulation Experiment (WOCE), and other projects, were conducted satisfactorily.

(2) Following repairs and deep-water trials of the oceanographic winch, it performed satisfactorily for the requirements of both the WOCE program and the thirteen other research projects undertaken during the voyage.

(3) No. A fault in the calibration of the CTD instrument created an inaccurate depth reading which caused the instrument package (of which the CTD is a part) to ground on the ocean bottom. Approximately 5 metres of cable immediately above the instrument package was damaged and was replaced at the end of the test. Neither the CTD winch nor the instrumentation was damaged as a result of this incident.

(4) Two dogs were found to have escaped from their line at Mawson station on the evening of 25 October and were not located until the next morning. Although it was not witnessed, it appears the dogs may have killed one seal pup and separated two others from their mothers. These pups unfortunately died despite attempts to reunite them. It is because of concern for the wildlife that dogs are required to be kept tethered at all times when not working. However, while precautions are taken, dogs do occasionally get loose, or wildlife strays into the dog lines. Following this incident the dogs' collars and chains were checked and new clips and collars have been fitted.
